Named Entity Recognition — Cluster Characters¶

#!pip install spacy
#!python -m spacy download en_core_web_sm

!pip install fuzzywuzzy

!pip install python-Levenshtein

import spacy

from collections import Counter

import pandas as pd

import itertools

import networkx 
from networkx.algorithms.components.connected import connected_components, node_connected_component

import itertools
from fuzzywuzzy import fuzz

import glob
from pathlib import Path

pd.set_option("max_rows", 400)

import en_core_web_sm
nlp = en_core_web_sm.load()

#nlp = spacy.load('en_core_web_sm')

filepath = "../texts/literature/Jones-Lost-in-The-City.txt"

text = open(filepath).read()

document = nlp(text)

displacy.render(document, style="ent")
THE GIRL WHO RAISED PIGEONS

Her father would say years later DATE that she had dreamed that part of it, that she had never gone out through the kitchen window at two or three CARDINAL in the morning to visit the birds. By that time in his life he would have so many notions about himself set in concrete. And having always believed that he slept lightly, he would not want to think that a girl of nine CARDINAL or ten could walk by him at such an hour in the night TIME without his waking and asking of the dark, Who is it? What’s the matter?

But the night TIME visits were not dreams, and they remained forever as vivid to her as the memory of the way the pigeons’ iridescent necklaces flirted with light. The visits would begin not with any compulsion in her sleeping mind to visit, but with the simple need to pee or to get a drink of water. In the dark, she went barefoot out of her room, past her father in the front room conversing in his sleep, across the kitchen and through the kitchen window, out over the roof a few steps to the coop. It could be winter DATE , it could be summer DATE , but the most she ever got was something she called pigeon silence. Sometimes she had the urge to unlatch the door and go into the coop, or, at the very least, to try to reach through the wire and the wooden slats to stroke a wing or a breast, to share whatever the silence seemed to conceal. But she always kept her hands to herself, and after a few minutes TIME , as if relieved, she would go back to her bed and visit the birds again in sleep.



What Betsy Ann Morgan PERSON and her father Robert PERSON did agree on was that the pigeons began with the barber Miles Patterson PERSON . Her father had known Miles PERSON long before the girl was born, before the thought to marry her mother had even crossed his mind. The barber lived in a gingerbread brown house with his old parents only a few doors down from the barbershop he owned on the corner of 3rd DATE and L GPE streets, Northwest ORG . On some Sundays DATE , after Betsy Ann PERSON had come back from church with Miss Jenny PERSON , Robert PERSON , as he believed his wife would have done, would take his daughter out to visit with relatives and friends in the neighborhoods just beyond Myrtle Street FAC , Northeast LOC , where father and daughter lived.

One CARDINAL Sunday DATE , when Betsy Ann PERSON was eight years old DATE , the barber asked her again if she wanted to see his pigeons, “my children.” He had first ORDINAL asked her some three years before DATE . The girl had been eager to see them then, imagining she would see the same frightened creatures who waddled and flew away whenever she chased them on sidewalks and in parks. The men and the girl had gone into the backyard, and the pigeons, in a furious greeting, had flown up and about the barber. “Oh, my babies,” he said, making kissing sounds. “Daddy’s here.” In an instant, Miles PERSON ’s head was surrounded by a colorful flutter of pigeon life. The birds settled on his head and his shoulders and along his thick, extended arms, and some of the birds looked down meanly at her. Betsy Ann PERSON screamed, sending the birds back into a flutter, which made her scream even louder. And still screaming, she ran back into the house. The men found her in the kitchen, her head buried in the lap of Miles PERSON ’s mother, her arms tight around the waist of the old woman, who had been sitting at the table having Sunday DATE lunch with her husband.

“ Buster WORK_OF_ART ,” Miles PERSON ’s mother said to him, “you shouldn’t scare your company like this. This child’s bout to have a heart attack.”

Three years later DATE Betsy Ann PERSON said yes again to seeing the birds. In the backyard, there was again the same fluttering chaos, but this time the sight of the wings and bodies settling about Miles PERSON intrigued her and she drew closer until she was a foot or so away, looking up at them and stretching out her arm as she saw Miles PERSON doing. “Oh, my babies,” the barber said. “Your daddy’s here.” One CARDINAL of the birds landed on Betsy Ann’s PERSON shoulder and another in the palm of her hand. The gray one in her hand looked dead at Betsy Ann PERSON , blinked, then swiveled his head and gave the girl a different view of a radiant black necklace. “They tickle,” she said to her father, who stood back.



For weeks DATE and weeks DATE after that Sunday DATE , Betsy Ann PERSON pestered her father about getting pigeons for her. And the more he told her no, that it was impossible, the more she wanted them. He warned her that he would not do anything to help her care for them, he warned her that all the bird-work meant she would not ever again have time to play with her friends, he warned her about all the do-do the pigeons would let loose. But she remained a bulldog about it, and he knew that she was not often a bulldog about anything. In the end he retreated to the fact that they were only renters in Jenny PERSON and Walter Creed PERSON ’s house.

“Miss Jenny PERSON likes birds,” the girl said. “Mr. Creed PERSON likes birds, too.”

“People may like birds, but nobody in the world likes pigeons.”

“Cept Mr. Miles PERSON ,” she said.

“Don’t make judgments bout things with what you know bout Miles PERSON .” Miles Patterson PERSON , a bachelor and, some women said, a virgin, was fifty-six years old DATE and for the most part knew no more about the world than what he could experience in newspapers or on the radio and in his own neighborhood, beyond which he rarely ventured. “There’s ain’t nothing out there in the great beyond for me,” Miles PERSON would say to people who talked with excitement about visiting such and such a place.

It was not difficult for the girl to convince Miss Jenny PERSON , though the old woman made it known that “pigeons carry all them diseases, child.” But there were few things Jenny Creed PERSON would deny Betsy Ann PERSON . The girl was known by all the world to be a good and obedient child. And in Miss Jenny PERSON ’s eyes, a child’s good reputation amounted to an assent from God on most things.

For years DATE after he relented, Robert Morgan PERSON would rise every morning before his daughter, go out onto the roof, and peer into the coop he had constructed for her, looking for dead pigeons. At such a time in the morning, there would be only fragments of first ORDINAL light, falling in long, hopeful slivers over the birds and their house. Sometimes he would stare absently into the coop for a long time, because being half-asleep, his mind would forget why he was there. The murmuring pigeons, as they did with most of the world, would stare back, with looks more of curiosity than of fear or anticipation or welcome. He thought that by getting there in the morning TIME before his daughter, he could spare her the sight and pain of any dead birds. His plan had always been to put any dead birds he found into a burlap sack, take them down to his taxicab, and dispose of them on his way to work. He never intended to tell her about such birds, and it never occurred to him that she would know every pigeon in the coop and would wonder, perhaps even worry, about a missing bird.



They lived in the apartment Jenny PERSON and Walter Creed PERSON had made out of the upstairs in their Myrtle Street FAC house. Miss Jenny PERSON had known Clara PERSON , Robert PERSON ’s wife, practically all of Clara PERSON ’s life. But their relationship had become little more than hellos and good-byes as they passed in the street before Miss Jenny PERSON came upon Clara PERSON and Robert PERSON one rainy Saturday DATE in the library park at Mt. Vernon Square FAC . Miss Jenny PERSON had come out of Hahn PERSON ’s shoe store, crossed New York Avenue FAC , and was going up 7th Street FAC . At first ORDINAL , Miss Jenny PERSON thought the young man and woman, soaked through to the skin, sitting on the park bench under a blue umbrella, were feebleminded or straightout crazy. As she came closer, she could hear them laughing, and the young man was swinging the umbrella back and forth over their heads, so that the rain would fall first ORDINAL upon her and then upon himself.

“ Ain’t you William WORK_OF_ART and Alice Hobson PERSON baby girl?” Miss Jenny PERSON asked Clara PERSON .

“Yes, ma’am.” She stood and Robert PERSON stood as well, now holding the umbrella fully over Clara PERSON ’s head.

“Is everything all right, child?” Miss Jenny PERSON ’s glasses were spotted with mist, and she took them off and stepped closer, keeping safely to the side where Clara PERSON was.

“Yes, ma’am. He—” She pushed Robert PERSON and began to laugh. “We came out of Peoples ORG and he wouldn’t let me have none a the umbrella. He let me get wet, so I took the umbrella and let him have some of his own medicine.”

Robert PERSON said nothing. He was standing out of the range of the umbrella and he was getting soaked all over again.

“We gonna get married, Miss Jenny PERSON ,” she said, as if that explained everything, and she stuck out her hand with her ring. “From Castleberg ORG ’s,” she said. Miss Jenny PERSON took Clara PERSON ’s hand and held it close to her face.

“Oh oh,” she said again and again, pulling Clara PERSON ’s hand still closer.

“ This Robert WORK_OF_ART ,” Clara PERSON said. “My”—and she turned to look at him—“fiancé PERSON .” She uttered the word with a certain crispness: It was clear that before Robert Morgan PERSON , fiancé was a word she had perhaps never uttered in her life.

Robert PERSON and Miss Jenny PERSON shook hands. “You gonna give her double pneumonia even before she take your name,” she said.

The couple learned the next week DATE that the place above Miss Jenny PERSON was vacant and the following Sunday DATE , Clara PERSON and Robert PERSON , dressed as if they had just come from church, were at her front door, inquiring about the apartment.

That was one of the last days DATE in the park for them. Robert PERSON came to believe later that the tumor that would consume his wife’s brain had been growing even on that rainy day. And it was there all those times he made love to her, and the thought that it was there, perhaps at first ORDINAL no bigger than a grain of salt, made him feel that he had somehow used her, taken from her even as she was moving toward death. He would not remember until much, much later the times she told him he gave her pleasure, when she whispered into his ear that she was glad she had found him, raised her head in that bed as she lay under him. And when he did remember, he would have to take out her photograph from the small box of valuables he kept in the dresser’s top drawer, for he could not remember her face any other way.

Clara PERSON spent most of the first months DATE of her pregnancy in bed, propped up, reading movie magazines and listening to the radio, waiting for Robert PERSON to come home from work. Her once pretty face slowly began to collapse in on itself like fruit too long in the sun, eaten away by the rot that despoiled from the inside out. The last month DATE or so she spent in the bed on the third ORDINAL floor at Gallinger Hospital FAC . One morning TIME , toward four o’clock TIME , they cut open her stomach and pulled out the child only moments after Clara PERSON died, mother and daughter passing each other as if along a corridor, one CARDINAL into death, the other into life.

The weeks DATE after her death Robert PERSON and the infant were attended to by family and friends. They catered to him and to the baby to such an extent that sometimes in those weeks DATE when he heard her cry, he would look about at the people in a room, momentarily confused about what was making the sound. But as all the people returned to their lives in other parts of Washington GPE or in other cities, he was left with the ever-increasing vastness of the small apartment and with a being who hadn’t the power to ask, yet seemed to demand everything.

“I don’t think I can do this,” he confessed to Miss Jenny PERSON one Friday DATE evening TIME when the baby was about a month old DATE . “I know I can’t do this.” Robert PERSON ’s father had been the last to leave him, and Robert PERSON had just returned from taking the old man to Union Station ORG a few blocks away. “If my daddy had just said the word, I’da been on that train with him.” He and Miss Jenny PERSON were sitting at his kitchen table, and the child, sleeping, was in her cradle beside Miss Jenny PERSON . Miss Jenny PERSON watched him and said not a word. “ Woulda PERSON followed him all the way back home…. I never looked down the line and saw bein PERSON by myself like this.”

“It’s all right,” Miss Jenny PERSON said finally. “I know how it is. You a young man. You got a whole life in front a you,” and the stone on his heart grew lighter. “The city people can help out with this.”

“The city?” He looked through the fluttering curtain onto the roof, at the oak tree, at the backs of houses on K Street FAC .

“Yes, yes.” She turned around in her chair to face him fully. “My niece works for the city, and she say they can take care of chirren like this who don’t have parents. They have homes, good homes, for chirren like her. Bring em up real good. Feed em, clothe em, give em good schoolin. Give em everything they need.” She stood, as if the matter were settled. “The city people care. Call my niece tomorra and find out what you need to do. A young man like you shouldn’t have to worry yourself like this.” She was at the door, and he stood up too, not wanting her to go. “Try to put all the worries out your mind.” Before he could say anything, she closed the door quietly behind her.

She did not come back up, as he had hoped, and he spent his first ORDINAL night alone with the child. Each time he managed to get the baby back to sleep after he fed her or changed her diaper, he would place her in the crib in the front room and sit without light at the kitchen table listening to the trains coming and going just beyond his window. He was nineteen years old DATE . There was a song about trains that kept rumbling in his head as the night TIME wore on, a song his mother would sing when he was a boy.

The next morning TIME , Saturday DATE , he shaved and washed up while Betsy Ann PERSON was still sleeping, and after she woke and he had fed her again, he clothed her with a yellow outfit and its yellow bonnet that Wilma Ellis PERSON , the schoolteacher next door, had given Betsy Ann PERSON . He carried the carriage downstairs first ORDINAL , leaving the baby on a pallet of blankets. On the sidewalk he covered her with a light green blanket that Dr. Oscar Jackson PERSON and his family up the street had given the baby. The shades were down at Miss Jenny PERSON ’s windows, and he heard no sound, not even the dog’s barking, as he came and went. At the child’s kicking feet in the carriage he placed enough diapers and powdered formula to last an expedition to Baltimore GPE . Beside her, he placed a blue rattle from the janitor Jake Horton PERSON across the street.

He was the only moving object within her sight and she watched him intently, which made him uncomfortable. She seemed the most helpless thing he had ever known. It occurred to him perversely, as he settled her in, that if he decided to walk away forever from her and the carriage and all her stuff, to walk but a few yards QUANTITY and make his way up or down 1st Street FAC for no place in particular, there was not a damn thing in the world she could do about it. The carriage was facing 1st Street Northeast FAC , and with some effort—because one of the wheels refused to turn with the others—he maneuvered it around, pointing toward North Capitol Street FAC .

In those days DATE , before the community was obliterated, a warm Myrtle Street FAC Saturday DATE morning TIME filled both sidewalks and the narrow street itself with playing children oblivious to everything but their own merriment. A grownup’s course was generally not an easy one, but that morning TIME , as he made his way with the soundless wheels of the carriage, the children made way for Robert Morgan PERSON , for he was the man whose wife had passed away. At her wake, some of them had been held up by grownups so they could look down on Clara ORG laid out in her pink casket in Miss Jenny PERSON ’s parlor. And though death and its rituals did not mean much beyond the wavering understanding that they would never see someone again, they knew from what their parents said and did that a clear path to the corner was perhaps the very least a widow man deserved.

Some of the children called to their parents still in their houses and apartments that Robert PERSON was passing with Clara PERSON ’s baby. The few grownups on porches came down to the sidewalk and made a fuss over Betsy Ann PERSON . More than midway down the block, Janet Gordon PERSON , who had been one CARDINAL of Clara GPE ’s best friends, came out and picked up the baby. It was too nice a day to have that blanket over her, she told Robert PERSON . You expectin to go all the way to Baltimore GPE with all them diapers? she said. It would be Janet PERSON who would teach him—practicing on string and a discarded blond-haired doll—how to part and plait a girl’s hair.

He did not linger on Myrtle Street FAC ; he planned to make the visits there on his way back that evening. Janet PERSON ’s boys, Carlos PERSON and Carleton PERSON , walked on either side of him up Myrtle GPE to North Capitol GPE , then to the corner of K Street FAC . There they knew to turn back. Carlos PERSON , seven years old DATE , told him to take it easy. Carleton, younger by two years DATE , did not want to repeat what his brother had said, so he repeated one of the things his grandfather, who was losing his mind, always told him: “Don’t get lost in the city.”

Robert PERSON nodded as if he understood and the boys turned back. He took off his tie and put it in his pocket and unbuttoned his suit coat and the top two CARDINAL buttons of his shirt. Then he adjusted his hat and placed the rattle nearer the baby, who paid it no mind. And when the light changed, he maneuvered the carriage down off the sidewalk and crossed North Capitol LOC into Northwest GPE .



Miles PERSON the barber gave Betsy Ann PERSON two CARDINAL pigeons, yearlings, a dull-white female with black spots and a sparkling red male. For several weeks DATE , in the morning TIME , soon after she had dutifully gone in to fill the feed dish and replace the water, and after they had fortified themselves, the pigeons took to the air and returned to Miles PERSON . The forlorn sound of their flapping wings echoed in her head as she stood watching them disappear into the colors of the morning, often still holding the old broom she used to sweep out their coop.

So in those first weeks DATE , she went first to Miles PERSON ’s after school to retrieve the pigeons, usually bringing along Ralph Holley PERSON , her cousin. Miles PERSON would put the birds in the two CARDINAL pigeon baskets Robert PERSON would bring over each morning TIME before he took to the street in his taxicab.

“They don’t like me,” Betsy Ann PERSON said to Miles PERSON one day DATE in the second week DATE . “They just gonna keep on flyin away. They hate me.”

Miles PERSON laughed, the same way he laughed when she asked him the first day DATE how he knew one was a girl pigeon and the other was a boy pigeon.

“I don’t think that they even got to the place of likin or not likin you,” Miles PERSON said. She handed her books to Ralph PERSON , and Miles PERSON gave her the two CARDINAL baskets.

“Well, they keep runnin away.”

“Thas all they know to do,” which was what he had told her the week before DATE . “Right now, this is all the home they know for sure. It ain’t got nothin to do with you, child. They just know to fly back here.”

His explanations about everything, when he could manage an explanation, rarely satisfied her. He had been raising pigeons all his life, and whatever knowledge he had accumulated in those years DATE was now such an inseparable part of his being that he could no more explain the birds than he could explain what went into the act of walking. He only knew that they did all that birds did and not something else, as he only knew that he walked and did not fall.

“You might try lockin em in for while,” he said. “Maybe two, three days DATE , however long it take em to get use to the new home. Let em know you the boss and you ain’t gonna stand for none a this runnin away stuff.”

She considered a moment, then shook her head. She watched her cousin peering into Miles PERSON ’s coop, his face hard against the wire. “I guess if I gotta lock em up there ain’t no use havin em.”

“Why you wanna mess with gotdamn pigeons anyway?” Ralph PERSON said as they walked to her home that day DATE .

“Because,” she said.

“Because what?” he said.

“Because, thas all,” she said. “Just because.”

“You oughta get a puppy like I’m gonna get,” Ralph PERSON said. “A puppy never run away.”

“A puppy never fly either. So what?” she said. “You been talking bout gettin a gotdamn puppy for a million years DATE , but I never see you gettin one.” Though Ralph PERSON was a year older DATE and a head taller than his cousin, she often bullied him.

“You wait. You wait. You’ll see,” Ralph PERSON said.

“I ain’t waitin. You the one CARDINAL waitin. When you get it, just let me know and I’ll throw you a big party.”

At her place, he handed over her books and went home. She considered following her cousin back to his house after she took the pigeons up to the coop, for the idea of being on the roof with birds who wanted to fly away to be with someone else pained her. At Ralph PERSON ’s L Street FAC house, there were cookies almost as big as her face, and Aunt Thelma PERSON , Clara PERSON ’s oldest sister, who was, in fact, the very image of Clara PERSON . The girl had never had an overwhelming curiosity about her mother, but it fascinated her to see the face of the lady in all the pictures on a woman who moved and laughed and did mother things.

She put the pigeons back in the coop and put fresh water in the bath bowls. Then she stood back, outside the coop, its door open. At such moments they often seemed contented, hopping in and out of cubicles, inspecting the feed and water, all of which riled her. She would have preferred—and understood—agitation, some sign that they were unhappy and ready to fly to Miles PERSON again. But they merely pecked about, strutted, heads bobbing happily, oblivious of her. Pretending everything was all right.

“You shitheads!” she hissed, aware that Miss Jenny PERSON was downstairs within earshot. “You gotdamn stupid shitheads!”



That was the fall of 1957 DATE .

Myrtle Street FAC was only one CARDINAL long block, running east to west. To the east, preventing the street from going any farther, was a high, medieval-like wall of stone across 1st Street FAC , Northeast LOC , and beyond the wall were the railroad tracks. To the west LOC , across North Capitol GPE , preventing Myrtle Street FAC from going any farther in that direction, was the high school Gonzaga, where white boys were taught by white priests. When the colored people and their homes were gone, the wall and the tracks remained, and so did the high school, with the same boys being taught by the same priests.

It was late spring DATE when Betsy Ann PERSON first ORDINAL noticed the nest, some two feet QUANTITY up from the coop’s floor in one CARDINAL of the twelve CARDINAL cubicles that made up the entire structure. The nest was nothing special, a crude, ill-formed thing of straw and dead leaves and other, uncertain material she later figured only her hapless birds could manage to find. They had not flown back to Miles PERSON in a long time, but she had never stopped thinking that it was on their minds each time they took to the air. So the nest was the first ORDINAL solid indication that the pigeons would stay forever, would go but would always return.

About three weeks later DATE , on an afternoon TIME when she was about to begin the weekly DATE job of thoroughly cleaning the entire coop, she saw the two CARDINAL eggs. She thought them a trick of the light at first ORDINAL — two CARDINAL small and perfect wonders alone in that wonderless nest without any hallelujahs from the world. She put off the cleaning and stood looking at the male bird, who had moved off the nest for only a few seconds TIME , rearrange himself on the nest and look at her from time to time in that bored way he had. The female bird was atop the coop, dozing. Betsy Ann PERSON got a chair from the kitchen and continued watching the male bird and the nest through the wire. “Tell me bout this,” she said to them.

As it happened, Robert PERSON discovered the newly hatched squabs when he went to look for dead birds before going to work. About six that morning TIME he peered into the coop and shivered to find two CARDINAL hideous, bug-eyed balls of movement. They were a dirty orange and looked like baby vultures. He looked about as if there might be someone responsible for it all. This was, he knew now, a point of no return for his child. He went back in to have his first cup of coffee of the day DATE .

He drank without enjoyment and listened to the chirping, unsettling, demanding. He would not wake his daughter just to let her know about the hatchlings. Two CARDINAL little monsters had changed the predictable world he was trying to create for his child and he was suddenly afraid for her. He turned on the radio and played it real low, but he soon shut it off, because the man on WOOK ORG was telling him to go in and kill the hatchlings.



It turned out that the first ORDINAL pigeon to die was a stranger, and Robert PERSON never knew anything about it. The bird appeared out of nowhere and was dead less than a week later DATE . By then, a year or so DATE after Miles PERSON gave her the yearlings, she had eight CARDINAL birds of various ages, resulting from hatches in her coop and from trades with the barber (“for variety’s sake,” he told her) and with a family in Anacostia GPE . One morning TIME before going to school, she noticed the stranger perched in one CARDINAL of the lower cubicles, a few inches QUANTITY up from the floor, and though he seemed submissive enough, she sensed that he would peck with all he had if she tried to move him out. His entire body, what little there was left of it, was a witness to misery. One CARDINAL ragged cream-colored tail feather stuck straight up, as if with resignation. His bill was pitted as if it had been sprayed with minute pellets, and his left eye was covered with a patch of dried blood and dirt and decaying flesh.

She placed additional straw to either side of him in the cubicle and small bowls of water and feed in front of the cubicle. Then she began to worry that he had brought in some disease that would ultimately devastate her flock.

Days later DATE , home for lunch with Ralph PERSON , she found the pigeon dead near the water tray, his wings spread out full as if he had been preparing for flight.

“Whatcha gonna do with him?” Ralph PERSON asked, kneeling down beside Betsy Ann PERSON and poking the dead bird with a pencil.

“Bury him. What else, stupid?” She snatched the pencil from him. “You don’t think any a them gonna do it, do you?” and she pointed to the few stay-at-home pigeons who were not out flying about the city. The birds looked down uninterestedly at them from various places around the coop. She dumped the dead bird in a pillowcase and took it across 1st Street FAC to the grassy spot of ground near the Esso ORG filling station in front of the medieval wall. With a large tablespoon, she dug two feet QUANTITY or so into the earth LOC and dropped the sack in.

“Beaver would say something over his grave,” Ralph PERSON said.

“What?”

“Beaver. The boy on TV.”

She gave him a cut-eye look and stood up. “You do it, preacher man,” she said. “I gotta get back to school.”

After school she said to Miss Jenny PERSON , “Don’t tell Daddy bout that dead pigeon. You know how he is: He’ll think it’s the end of the world or somethin.”

The two CARDINAL were in Miss Jenny PERSON ’s kitchen, and Miss Jenny PERSON was preparing supper while Betsy Ann PERSON did her homework.

“You know what he do in the mornin?” Betsy Ann PERSON said. “He go out and look at them pigeons.”

“Oh?” Miss Jenny PERSON , who knew what Robert PERSON had been doing, did not turn around from the stove. “Wants to say good mornin to em, hunh?”

“I don’t think so. I ain’t figured out what he doin,” the girl said. She was sitting at Miss Jenny PERSON ’s kitchen table. The dog, Bosco GPE , was beside her and one of her shoes was off and her foot was rubbing the dog’s back. “I was sleepin one CARDINAL time and this cold air hit me and I woke up. I couldn’t get back to sleep cause I was cold, so I got up to see what window was open. Daddy wasn’t in the bed and he wasn’t in the kitchen or the bathroom. I thought he was downstairs warmin up the cab or somethin, but when I went to close the kitchen window, I could see him, peekin in the coop from the side with a flashlight. He scared me cause I didn’t know who he was at first ORDINAL .”

“You ask him what he was doin?”

“No. He wouldn’t told me anyway, Miss Jenny PERSON . I just went back to my room and closed the door. If I’da asked him straight out, he would just make up something or say maybe I was dreamin. So now when I feel that cold air, I just look out to see if he in bed and then I shut my door.”



Sometimes, when the weather allowed, the girl would sit on the roof plaiting her hair or reading the funny papers before school, or sit doing her homework in the late afternoon TIME before going down to Miss Jenny PERSON ’s or out to play. She got pleasure just from the mere presence of the pigeons, a pleasure that was akin to what she felt when she followed her Aunt Thelma WORK_OF_ART about her house, or when she jumped double dutch for so long she had to drop to the ground to catch her breath. In the morning TIME , the new sun rising higher, she would place her chair at the roof’s edge. She could look down at tail-wagging Bosco GPE looking up at her, down through the thick rope fence around the roof that Robert PERSON had put up when she was a year old DATE . She would hum or sing some nonsense song she’d made up, as the birds strutted and pecked and preened and flapped about in the bath water. And in the evening she watched the pigeons return home, first ORDINAL landing in the oak tree, then over to the coop’s landing board. A few of them, generally the males, would settle on her book or on her head and shoulders. Stroking the breast of one, she would be rewarded with a cooing that was as pleasurable as music, and when the bird edged nearer so that it was less than an inch away, she smelled what seemed a mixture of dirt and rainy air and heard a heart that seemed to be hurling itself against the wall of the bird’s breast.

She turned ten DATE . She turned eleven CARDINAL .



In the early summer of 1960 DATE , there began a rumor among the children of Betsy Ann’s PERSON age that the railroad people were planning to take all the land around Myrtle Street FAC , perhaps up to L Street FAC and down to H Street FAC . This rumor—unlike the summer DATE rumor among Washington GPE ’s Negro ORG children that Richard Nixon PERSON , if he were elected president, would make all the children go to school on Saturday DATE from nine to twelve CARDINAL and cut their summer vacations in half CARDINAL —this rumor had a long life. And as the boys scraped their knuckles on the ground playing Poison PERSON , as the girls jumped rope until their bouncing plaits came loose, as the boys filled the neighborhood with the sounds of amateur hammering as they built skating trucks, as the girls made up talk for dolls with names they would one day DATE bestow on their children, their conversations were flavored with lighthearted speculation about how far the railroad would go. When one CARDINAL child fell out with another, it became standard to try to hurt the other with the “true fact” that the railroad was going to take his or her home. “It’s a true fact, they called my daddy at his work and told him we could stay, but yall gotta go. Yall gotta.” And then the tormentor would stick out his or her tongue as far as it would go.



There were only two CARDINAL other girls on Myrtle Street FAC who were comfortable around pigeons, and both of them moved away within a month DATE of each other. One CARDINAL , LaDeidre Gordon PERSON , was a cousin of the brothers Carlos PERSON and Carleton GPE . LaDeidre PERSON believed that the pigeons spoke a secret language among themselves, and that if she listened long enough and hard enough she could understand what they were saying and, ultimately, could communicate with them. For this, the world lovingly nicknamed her “ Coo-Coo WORK_OF_ART .” After LaDeidre GPE and the second ORDINAL girl moved, Betsy Ann PERSON would take the long way around to avoid passing where they had lived. And in those weeks DATE she found a comfort of sorts at Thelma PERSON and Ralph PERSON ’s, for their house and everything else on the other side of North Capitol Street LOC , the rumor went, would be spared by the railroad people.

Thelma Holley PERSON , her husband, and Ralph PERSON lived in a small house on L Street FAC , Northwest ORG , two CARDINAL doors from Mt. Airy Baptist Church ORG , just across North Capitol Street FAC . Thelma PERSON had suffered six CARDINAL miscarriages before God, as she put it, “took pity on my womb” and she had Ralph PERSON . But even then, she felt God had given with one hand and taken with the other, for the boy suffered with asthma. Thelma PERSON had waited until the seventh month DATE of her pregnancy before she felt secure enough to begin loving him. And from then on, having given her heart, she thought nothing of giving him the world after he was born.

Ralph PERSON was the first ORDINAL colored child anyone knew to have his own television. In his house there had been three CARDINAL bedrooms, but Thelma PERSON persuaded her husband that an asthmatic child needed more space. Her husband knocked down the walls between the two CARDINAL back bedrooms and Ralph PERSON then had a bedroom that was nearly twice as large as that of his parents. And in that enormous room, she put as much of the world as she and her husband could afford.

Aside from watching Thelma PERSON , what Betsy Ann PERSON enjoyed most in that house was the electric train set, which dominated the center of Ralph PERSON ’s room. Over an area of more than four square feet QUANTITY , running on three CARDINAL levels, the trains moved through a marvelous and complete world Ralph PERSON ’s father had constructed. In that world, there were no simple plastic figures waving beside the tracks. Rather, it was populated with such people as a hand-carved woman of wood, in a floppy hat and gardener’s outfit of real cloth, a woman who had nearly microscopic beads of sweat on her brow as she knelt down with concentration in her flower garden; several inches QUANTITY away, hand-carved schoolchildren romped about in the playground. One CARDINAL group of children was playing tag, and on one CARDINAL boy’s face was absolute surprise as he was being tagged by a girl whose cheek was lightly smudged with dirt. A foot or so away, in a small field, two CARDINAL hand-carved farmers of wood were arguing, one CARDINAL with his finger in the other’s face and the other with his fist heading toward the chest of the first ORDINAL . The world also included a goat-populated mountain with a tunnel large enough for the trains to go through, and a stream made of light blue glass. The stream covered several tiny fish of many colors which had almost invisible pins holding them suspended from the bottom up to give the impression that the fish were swimming.

What Thelma PERSON would not put in her son’s enormous room, despite years of pleadings from him, was a dog, for she had learned in childhood that all animals had the power to suck the life out of asthmatics. “What you need with some ole puppy?” she would tease sometimes when he asked. “You’ll be my little puppy dog forever and forever.” And then she would grab and hug him until he wiggled out of her arms.

By the time he was six DATE , the boy had learned that he could sometimes stay all day DATE in the room and have Thelma PERSON minister to him by pretending he could barely breathe. He hoped that over time he could get out of her a promise for a dog. But his pretending to be at death’s door only made her worry more, and by the middle of 1961 DATE , she had quit her part-time, GS-4 clerk-typist position at the Interior Department ORG , because by then he was home two CARDINAL or three CARDINAL times a week.



Gradually, as more people moved out of Myrtle Street FAC , the room became less attractive for Betsy Ann PERSON to visit, for Ralph PERSON grew difficult and would be mean and impatient with her and other visiting children. “You stupid, thas all! You just the stupidest person in the whole wide world,” he would say to anyone who did not do what he wanted as fast as he wanted. Some children cried when he lit into them, and others wanted to fight him.

In time, the boy Betsy Ann PERSON once bullied disappeared altogether, and so when she took him assignments from school, she tried to stay only the amount of time necessary to show politeness. Then, too, the girl sensed that Thelma PERSON , with her increasing coldness, felt her son’s problem was partly the result of visits from children who weren’t altogether clean and from a niece who lived her life in what Thelma PERSON called “pigeon air” and “pigeon dust.”



When he found out, the details of it did not matter to Robert Morgan PERSON : He only knew that his daughter had been somewhere doing bad while he was out doing the best he could. It didn’t matter that it was Darlene Greenley PERSON who got Betsy Ann PERSON to go far away to 7th ORDINAL and Massachusetts GPE and steal candy bars from Peoples Drug ORG , candy she didn’t even like, to go away the farthest she had ever been without her father or Miss Jenny PERSON or some other adult.

She knew Darlene PERSON , fast Darlene PERSON , from going to Ralph PERSON ’s (“You watch and see,” Darlene PERSON would whisper to her, “I’m gonna make him my boyfriend”), but they had never gone off together before the Saturday DATE that Thelma PERSON , for the last time, expelled all the children from her house. “Got any money?” Darlene PERSON said on the sidewalk after Thelma PERSON had thrown them out. She was stretching her bubble gum between her teeth and fingers and twirling the stuff the way she would a jump rope. When Betsy Ann PERSON shook her head, Darlene PERSON said she knew this Peoples ORG that kinda like y’know gave children candy just for stopping by, and Betsy Ann PERSON believed her.

The assistant manager caught the girls before they were out of the candy and toy aisle and right away Darlene PERSON started to cry. “That didn’t work the last time I told you to stay outa here,” the woman said, taking the candy out of their dress pockets, “and it ain’t gonna work now.” Darlene PERSON handed her candy over, and Betsy Ann PERSON did the same. Darlene PERSON continued to cry. “Oh, just shut up, you little hussy, before I give you somethin to really cry about.”

The assistant manager handed the candy to a clerk and was about to drag the girls into a back room when Etta O’Connell PERSON came up the aisle. “Yo daddy know you this far from home, Betsy Ann PERSON ?” Miss Etta PERSON said, tapping Betsy Ann PERSON in the chest with her walking stick. She was, at ninety-two CARDINAL , the oldest person on Myrtle Street FAC . It surprised Betsy Ann PERSON that she even knew her name, because the old woman, as far as Betsy Ann PERSON could remember, had never once spoken a word to her.

“You know these criminals?” the assistant manager said.

“ Knowed PERSON this one since the day DATE she born,” Miss Etta PERSON said. The top of her stick had the head of an animal that no one had been able to identify, and the animal, perched a foot or so higher than Miss Etta PERSON ’s head, looked down at Betsy Ann PERSON with a better-you-than-me look. The old woman uncurled the fingers of the assistant manager’s hand from around Betsy Ann PERSON ’s arm. “Child, whatcha done in this lady’s sto?”

In the end, the assistant manager accepted Miss Etta PERSON ’s word that Betsy Ann PERSON would never again step foot in the store, that her father would know what she had done the minute he got home. Outside, standing at the corner, Miss Etta PERSON raised her stick and pointed to K Street FAC . “You don’t go straight home with no stoppin, I’ll know,” she said to Betsy Ann PERSON , and the girl sprinted off, never once looking back. Miss Etta PERSON and Darlene PERSON continued standing at the corner. “I think that old lady gave me the evil eye,” Darlene PERSON told Betsy Ann PERSON the next time they met. “She done took all my good luck away. Yall got ghosties and shit on yo street FAC .” And thereafter, she avoided Betsy Ann PERSON .



Robert PERSON tanned her hide, as Miss Jenny PERSON called it, and then withheld her fifty-cents MONEY -a-week allowance for two months DATE . For some three weeks DATE he said very little to her, and when he did, it was almost always the same words: “You should be here, takin care a them damn birds! That’s where you should be, not out there robbin somebody’s grocery store!” She stopped correcting him about what kind of store it was after the first ORDINAL few times, because each time she did he would say, “Who the grownup here? You startin to sound like you runnin the show.”

The candy episode killed something between them, and more and more he began checking up on her. He would show up at the house when she thought he was out working. She would come out of the coop with a bag of feed or the broom in her hand and a bird sitting on her head and she would find him standing at the kitchen window watching her. And several times a day he would call Miss Jenny PERSON . “Yo daddy wanna know if you up there,” Miss Jenny PERSON would holler out her back window. Robert PERSON called the school so much that the principal herself wrote a letter telling him to stop.

He had been seeing Janet Gordon PERSON for two years DATE , and about three or four CARDINAL times a month, they would take in a movie or a show at the Howard PERSON and then spend the night TIME at a tourist home. But after the incident at Peoples ORG , he saw Janet PERSON only once or twice a month. Then he began taking his daughter with him in the cab on most Saturdays EVENT . He tried to make it seem as if it were a good way to see the city.

Despite his reasons for taking her along, she enjoyed riding with him at first ORDINAL . She asked him for one CARDINAL of his old maps, and, with a blue crayon, she would chart the streets of Washington GPE she had been on. Her father spent most of his time in Southeast GPE and in Anacostia GPE , but sometimes he went as far away as Virginia GPE and Maryland GPE , and she charted streets in those places as well. She also enjoyed watching him at work, seeing a part of him she had never known: The way he made deliberate notations in his log. Patted his thigh in time to music in his head until he noticed her looking at him. Raised his hat any time a woman entered or left the cab.

But the more she realized that being with him was just his way of keeping his eye on her, the more the travels began losing something for her. When she used the bathroom at some filling station during her travels, she found him waiting for her outside the bathroom door, his nail-bitten hands down at his sides, his hat sitting perfectly on his head, and a look on his face that said Nothin PERSON . Nothin PERSON ’s wrong. Before the autumn of 1961 DATE had settled in, she only wanted to be left at home, and because the incident at Peoples ORG was far behind them, he allowed it. But he went back to the old ways of checking up on her. “Tell him yes,” she would say when Miss Jenny PERSON called out her back window. “Tell him a million CARDINAL times yes, I’m home.”



Little by little that spring and summer DATE of 1961 DATE Myrtle Street FAC emptied of people, of families who had known no other place in their lives. Robert PERSON dreaded coming home each evening TIME and seeing the signs of still another abandoned house free to be picked clean by rogues coming in from other neighborhoods: old curtains flapping out of screenless windows, the street with every kind of litter, windows so naked he could see clean through to the backyard. For the first ORDINAL time since he had been knowing her, Miss Jenny PERSON did not plant her garden that year DATE , and that small patch of ground, with alien growth tall as a man, reverted to the wild.

He vowed that until he could find a good place for himself and his child, he would try to make life as normal as possible for her. He had never stopped rising each morning TIME before Betsy Ann PERSON and going out to the coop to see what pigeons might have died in the night. And that was what he did that last morning TIME in midautumn. He touched down onto the roof and discovered it had snowed during the night TIME . A light, nuisance powder, not thick enough to cover the world completely and make things beautiful the way he liked. Though there was enough sunlight, he did not at first ORDINAL notice the tiny tracks, with even tinier, intermittent spots of blood, leading from the coop, across his roof and over to the roof of the house next door, the schoolteacher’s house that had been empty for more than four months DATE . He did, however, hear the birds squawking before he reached the coop, but this meant nothing to him, because one CARDINAL pigeon sound was more or less like another to him.

The night before there had been sixteen CARDINAL pigeons of various ages, but when he reached the coop, five CARDINAL were already dead and three CARDINAL were in their last moments, dragging themselves crazily about the floor or from side to side in the lower cubicles. Six CARDINAL of them he would kill with his own hands. Though there were bodies with holes so deep he saw white flesh, essence, it was the sight of dozens CARDINAL of detached feathers that caused his body to shake, because the scattered feathers, more than the wrecked bodies, spoke to him of helplessness. He closed his eyes as tight as he could and began to pray, and when he opened them, the morning TIME was even brighter.

He looked back at the window, for something had whispered that Betsy Ann PERSON was watching. But he was alone and he went into the coop. He took up one CARDINAL dead bird whose left wing and legs had been chewed off; he shook the bird gently, and gently he blew into its face. He prayed once more. The pigeons that were able had moved to the farthest corner of the coop and they watched him, quivering. He knew now that the squawking was the sound of pain and it drove him out of their house.

When he saw the tracks, he realized immediately that they had been made by rats. He bent down, and some logical piece of his mind was surprised that there was a kind of orderliness to the trail, even with its ragged bits of pigeon life, a fragment of feather here, a spot of blood there.

He did not knock at Walter PERSON and Miss Jenny PERSON ’s door and wait to go in, as he had done each morning TIME for some thirteen years DATE . He found them at the breakfast table, and because they had been used to thirteen years DATE of knocking, they looked up at him, amazed. Most of his words were garbled, but they followed him back upstairs. Betsy Ann PERSON had heard the noise of her father coming through the kitchen window and bounded down the stairs. She stood barefoot in the doorway leading from the front room to the kitchen, blinking herself awake.

“Go back to bed!” Robert PERSON shouted at her.

When she asked what was the matter, the three CARDINAL only told her to go back to bed. From the kitchen closet, Robert PERSON took two CARDINAL burlap sacks. Walter PERSON followed him out onto the roof and Betsy Ann PERSON made her way around Miss Jenny PERSON to the window.

Her father shouted at her to go to her room and Miss Jenny PERSON tried to grab her, but she managed to get onto the roof, where Walter PERSON held her. From inside, she had heard the squawking, a brand new sound for her. Even with Walter PERSON holding her, she got a few feet QUANTITY from the coop. And when Robert PERSON told her to go back inside, she gave him the only no of their lives. He looked but once at her and then began to wring the necks of the birds injured beyond all hope. Strangely PERSON , when he reached for them, the pigeons did not peck, did not resist. He placed all of the bodies in the sacks, and when he was all done and stood covered in blood and viscera and feathers, he began to cry.

Betsy Ann PERSON and her father noticed almost simultaneously that there were two CARDINAL birds completely unharmed, huddled in an upper corner of the coop. After he tied the mouths of the sacks, the two CARDINAL birds, as if of one CARDINAL mind, flew together to the landing board ORG and from there to the oak tree in Miss Jenny PERSON ’s yard. Then they were gone. The girl buried her face in Walter PERSON ’s side, and when the old man saw that she was barefoot, he picked her up.



She missed them more than she ever thought she would. In school, her mind would wander and she would doodle so many pigeons on the backs of her hands and along her arms that teachers called her Nasty, nasty girl. In the bathtub at night TIME , she would cry to have to wash them off. And as she slept, missing them would take shape and lean down over her bed and wake her just enough to get her to understand a whisper that told her all over again how much she missed them. And when she raged in her sleep, Robert PERSON would come in and hold her until she returned to peace. He would sit in a chair beside her bed for the rest of the night, for her rages usually came about four CARDINAL in the morning and with the night TIME so near morning TIME , he saw no use in going back to bed.

She roamed the city at will, and Robert PERSON said nothing. She came to know the city so well that had she been blindfolded and taken to practically any place in Washington GPE , even as far away as Anacostia PERSON or Georgetown GPE , she could have taken off the blindfold and walked home without a moment’s trouble. Her favorite place became the library park at Mount Vernon Square FAC , the same park where Miss Jenny PERSON had first seen Robert PERSON and Clara PERSON together, across the street from the Peoples ORG where Betsy Ann PERSON had been caught stealing. And there on some warm days DATE Robert PERSON would find her, sitting on a bench, or lying on the grass, eyes to the sky.

For many weeks DATE , well into winter DATE , one CARDINAL of the birds that had not been harmed would come to the ledge of a back window of an abandoned house that faced K Street FAC . The bird, a typical gray, would stand on the ledge and appear to look across the backyards in the direction of Betsy Ann’s PERSON roof, now an empty space because the coop had been dismantled for use as firewood in Miss Jenny PERSON ’s kitchen stove. When the girl first noticed him and realized who he was, she said nothing, but after a few days DATE , she began to call to him, beseech him to come to her. She came to the very edge of the roof, for now the rope fence was gone and nothing held her back. When the bird would not come to her, she cursed him. After as much as an hour it would fly away and return the next morning TIME .

On what turned out to be the last day DATE , a very cold morning TIME in February DATE , she stepped out onto the roof to drink the last of her cocoa. At first ORDINAL she sipped, then she took one CARDINAL final swallow, and in the time it took her to raise the cup to her lips and lower it, the pigeon had taken a step and dropped from the ledge. He caught an upwind that took him nearly as high as the tops of the empty K Street FAC houses. He flew farther into Northeast LOC , into the colors and sounds of the city’s morning. She did nothing, aside from following him, with her eyes, with her heart, as far as she could.





THE FIRST DAY DATE




On an otherwise unremarkable September morning TIME , long before I learned to be ashamed of my mother, she takes my hand and we set off down New Jersey Avenue FAC to begin my very first day DATE of school. I am wearing a checkeredlike blue-and-green cotton dress, and scattered about these colors are bits of yellow and white and brown. My mother has uncharacteristically spent nearly an hour TIME on my hair that morning TIME , plaiting and replaiting so that now my scalp tingles. Whenever I turn my head quickly, my nose fills with the faint smell of Dixie Peach PERSON hair grease. The smell is somehow a soothing one now and I will reach for it time and time again before the morning TIME ends. All the plaits, each with a blue barrette near the tip and each twisted into an uncommon sturdiness, will last until I go to bed that night TIME , something that has never happened before. My stomach is full of milk and oatmeal sweetened with brown sugar. Like everything else I have on, my pale green slip and underwear are new, the underwear having come three CARDINAL to a plastic package with a little girl on the front who appears to be dancing. Behind my ears, my mother, to stop my whining, has dabbed the stingiest bit of her gardenia perfume, the last present my father gave her before he disappeared into memory. Because I cannot smell it, I have only her word that the perfume is there. I am also wearing yellow socks trimmed with thin lines of black and white around the tops. My shoes are my greatest joy, black patent-leather miracles, and when one is nicked at the toe later that morning TIME in class, my heart will break.

I am carrying a pencil, a pencil sharpener, and a small ten-cent MONEY tablet with a black-and-white speckled cover. My mother does not believe that a girl in kindergarten needs such things, so I am taking them only because of my insistent whining and because they are presents from our neighbors, Mary Keith PERSON and Blondelle Harris PERSON . Miss Mary PERSON and Miss Blondelle PERSON are watching my two CARDINAL younger sisters until my mother returns. The women are as precious to me as my mother and sisters. Out playing one day DATE , I have overheard an older child, speaking to another child, call Miss Mary PERSON and Miss Blondelle PERSON a word that is brand new to me. This is my mother: When I say the word in fun to one of my sisters, my mother slaps me across the mouth and the word is lost for years DATE and years DATE .

All the way down New Jersey Avenue FAC , the sidewalks are teeming with children. In my neighborhood, I have many friends, but I see none of them as my mother and I walk. We cross New York Avenue FAC , we cross Pierce Street FAC , and we cross L PRODUCT and K ORG , and still I see no one who knows my name. At I Street, between New Jersey Avenue ORG and Third Street LOC , we enter Seaton Elementary School ORG , a timeworn, sad-faced building across the street from my mother’s church, Mt. Carmel Baptist PERSON .

Just inside the front door, women out of the advertisements in Ebony PERSON are greeting other parents and children. The woman who greets us has pearls thick as jumbo marbles that come down almost to her navel, and she acts as if she had known me all my life, touching my shoulder, cupping her hand under my chin. She is enveloped in a perfume that I only know is not gardenia. When, in answer to her question, my mother tells her that we live at 1227 DATE New Jersey Avenue FAC , the woman first ORDINAL seems to be picturing in her head where we live. Then she shakes her head and says that we are at the wrong school, that we should be at Walker-Jones ORG .

My mother shakes her head vigorously. “I want her to go here,” my mother says. “If I’da wanted her someplace else, I’da took her there.” The woman continues to act as if she has known me all my life, but she tells my mother that we live beyond the area that Seaton ORG serves. My mother is not convinced and for several more minutes TIME she questions the woman about why I cannot attend Seaton ORG . For as many Sundays DATE as I can remember, perhaps even Sundays DATE when I was in her womb, my mother has pointed across I Street to Seaton ORG as we come and go to Mt. Carmel PERSON . “You gonna go there and learn about the whole world.” But one of the guardians of that place is saying no, and no again. I am learning this about my mother: The higher up on the scale of respectability a person is—and teachers are rather high up in her eyes—the less she is liable to let them push her around. But finally, I see in her eyes the closing gate, and she takes my hand and we leave the building. On the steps, she stops as people move past us on either side.

“Mama, I can’t go to school?”

She says nothing at first ORDINAL , then takes my hand again and we are down the steps quickly and nearing New Jersey Avenue FAC before I can blink. This is my mother: She says, “ One CARDINAL monkey don’t stop no show.”

Walker-Jones ORG is a larger, newer school and I immediately like it because of that. But it is not across the street from my mother’s church, her rock, one of her connections to God, and I sense her doubts as she absently rubs her thumb over the back of her hand. We find our way to the crowded auditorium where gray metal chairs are set up in the middle of the room. Along the wall to the left are tables and other chairs. Every chair seems occupied by a child or adult. Somewhere in the room a child is crying, a cry that rises above the buzz-talk of so many people. Strewn ORG about the floor are dozens CARDINAL and dozens CARDINAL of pieces of white paper, and people are walking over them without any thought of picking them up. And seeing this lack of concern, I am all of a sudden afraid.

“Is this where they register for school?” my mother asks a woman at one CARDINAL of the tables.

The woman looks up slowly as if she has heard this question once too often. She nods. She is tiny, almost as small as the girl standing beside her. The woman’s hair is set in a mass of curlers and all of those curlers are made of paper money, here a dollar bill, there a five-dollar MONEY bill. The girl’s hair is arrayed in curls, but some of them are beginning to droop and this makes me happy. On the table beside the woman’s pocketbook is a large notebook, worthy of someone in high school, and looking at me looking at the notebook, the girl places her hand possessively on it. In her other hand she holds several pencils with thick crowns of additional erasers.

“These the forms you gotta use?” my mother asks the woman, picking up a few pieces of the paper from the table. “Is this what you have to fill out?”

The woman tells her yes, but that she need fill out only one.

“I see,” my mother says, looking about the room. Then: “Would you help me with this form? That is, if you don’t mind.”

The woman asks my mother what she means.

“This form. Would you mind helpin me fill it out?”

The woman still seems not to understand.

“I can’t read it. I don’t know how to read or write, and I’m askin you to help me.” My mother looks at me, then looks away. I know almost all of her looks, but this one is brand new to me. “Would you help me, then?”

The woman says Why sure, and suddenly she appears happier, so much more satisfied with everything. She finishes the form for her daughter and my mother and I step aside to wait for her. We find two CARDINAL chairs nearby and sit. My mother is now diseased, according to the girl’s eyes, and until the moment her mother takes her and the form to the front of the auditorium, the girl never stops looking at my mother. I stare back at her. “Don’t stare,” my mother says to me. “You know better than that.”

Another woman out of the Ebony PERSON ads takes the woman’s child away. Now, the woman says upon returning, let’s see what we can do for you two CARDINAL .

My mother answers the questions the woman reads off the form. They start with my last name, and then on to the first ORDINAL and middle names. This is school, I think. This is going to school. My mother slowly enunciates each word of my name. This is my mother: As the questions go on, she takes from her pocketbook document after document, as if they will support my right to attend school, as if she has been saving them up for just this moment. Indeed, she takes out more papers than I have ever seen her do in other places: my birth certificate, my baptismal record, a doctor’s letter concerning my bout with chicken pox, rent receipts, records of immunization, a letter about our public assistance payments, even her marriage license—every single paper that has anything even remotely to do with my five-year-old DATE life. Few of the papers are needed here, but it does not matter and my mother continues to pull out the documents with the purposefulness of a magician pulling out a long string of scarves. She has learned that money is the beginning and end of everything in this world, and when the woman finishes, my mother offers her fifty cents MONEY , and the woman accepts it without hesitation. My mother and I are just about the last parent and child in the room.

My mother presents the form to a woman sitting in front of the stage, and the woman looks at it and writes something on a white card, which she gives to my mother. Before long, the woman who has taken the girl with the drooping curls appears from behind us, speaks to the sitting woman, and introduces herself to my mother and me. She’s to be my teacher, she tells my mother. My mother stares.

We go into the hall, where my mother kneels down to me. Her lips are quivering. “I’ll be back to pick you up at twelve o’clock TIME . I don’t want you to go nowhere. You just wait right here. And listen to every word she say.” I touch her lips and press them together. It is an old, old game between us. She puts my hand down at my side, which is not part of the game. She stands and looks a second ORDINAL at the teacher, then she turns and walks away. I see where she has darned one CARDINAL of her socks the night before. Her shoes make loud sounds in the hall. She passes through the doors and I can still hear the loud sounds of her shoes. And even when the teacher turns me toward the classrooms and I hear what must be the singing and talking of all the children in the world, I can still hear my mother’s footsteps above it all.





THE NIGHT RHONDA FERGUSON WAS KILLED




Cassandra G. Lewis PERSON , the girl the boys called Tank and Mack Truck PERSON behind her back, sat on that low brick wall outside Cardozo High School ORG , eating two-year-old DATE Christmas DATE candy when she wasn’t smoking Chesterfields. She’d been there since after her lunch period, and now it was nearing the end of the seventh DATE period and the girl was getting bored because the teacher hadn’t come out to get popped. At Cassandra GPE ’s feet on the sidewalk was a small pile of cigarette butts and match stems, and behind her, on the grass on the other side of the wall, was a pile of candy wrappers a wind coming up 13th Street FAC was now blowing here and there.

She had been waiting for her homeroom teacher to look out the window on the second ORDINAL floor and see her wasting her life away on the wall. She’d been hoping the teacher would come out and, as the woman had done that morning TIME in the second ORDINAL -period English LANGUAGE class Cassandra PERSON had with her, bark more shit in her face. Potential, Cassandra GPE had thought all the time she had been eating and smoking on the wall, I’ll show her all the goddamn potential in the world! She had walked out before the end of the second ORDINAL period and come straight down to the wall, itching for the chance to knock the teacher on her bony ass. But now all the candy and cigarettes were beginning to turn her stomach and she wanted only to be somewhere else.

Parked across Clifton Street FAC in front of her was a green 1957 DATE Hollywood Hudson PERSON , a piece of shit that belonged to her brother-in-law, who, in his drunken moments, often called the car “my old mule.” She had spent last night TIME —and the six nights TIME before that—in her sister and brother-in-law’s apartment on Kenyon Street FAC , the first ORDINAL time in a month DATE or so she had slept a week straight in the same place. But that morning TIME her brother-in-law had gotten up on the wrong side of the bed and picked a fight with her because she had eaten five CARDINAL eggs and four CARDINAL biscuits. After he’d gone to work and after her sister had taken the kids to the baby-sitter’s before going to work herself, Cassandra PERSON had stolen the old mule to get even. She would have popped her brother-in-law before he left, as she had done a year ago DATE , but she thought it would hurt her sister and nieces too much to see Daddy laid out cold again on the kitchen floor.

She stood up now and brushed ashes from her blouse and pants. The school bell rang, announcing the end of the seventh DATE period. She gave one final look to the corner window on the second ORDINAL floor. She knew the bitch had seen her out there on the wall, but just didn’t have the heart to come out. She’d made the death mistake of thinking she and Miss Bartlett PERSON were getting along fine, the way the teacher had always seemed to get along with the other girls. Miss Bartlett PERSON had even begun to include her in that small group of girls she invited to her apartment some evenings for meals and girl talk. It was there, over several weeks DATE beginning in September DATE , among twelve CARDINAL or so girls Cassandra PERSON wouldn’t have given a shit about before, that she had begun to share, sitting on that brown carpet that was thicker than some beds she’d known. Among all those books and pictures of the teacher’s smiling relatives, she’d said things only her sister and Rhonda Ferguson PERSON knew about.

But lately, for no reason at all, the teacher seemed to be in her face all the time, and that morning TIME the teacher had made the death mistake of bringing up Cassandra GPE ’s father and mother. Had said that her parents must be turning over in their graves to know the way their child was living, going from pillar to post with no real home. Had said all that and more in front of the dick people who couldn’t stand Cassandra and were just waiting to hear some real personal shit about her life so they could talk behind her back. Then, like putting her personal business in the street wasn’t enough, the teacher had gone into all that other stuff about potential and blah-blah-blah and then, after that, some more blah-blah-blah.

She had made up her mind to get in the car and take off for God knew where when someone honked and she saw Rhonda Ferguson PERSON and Rhonda PERSON ’s father, waiting at the light at 13th DATE and Clifton ORG . The car turned when the light changed and pulled up in front of her. Rhonda PERSON , in the passenger seat, waved her over. Students were coming out of school and they passed behind Cassandra LOC leaning in the car window.

“I hope your bein out here so soon don’t mean you played hooky,” Rhonda PERSON said. “Hi you doin?”

“Fine. Goin to a party all dressed up like that?” Cassandra PERSON said.

Rhonda PERSON smiled and grabbed Cassandra PERSON ’s arm eagerly. “You haven’t been around, or you’d know: I think I’m going to sign the contract today DATE . We got a meetin downtown with the people from the record company. I think this is it,” she said, crossing her fingers. “I haven’t been able to think straight. I stayed home playin with Alice PERSON all day DATE .”

Rhonda PERSON ’s father leaned across the seat. “Hi you doin, baby girl? We looked for you last night TIME . Been lookin for you every night TIME this week DATE .” He had a large stomach and his stomach was touching the bottom of the steering wheel.

“I been stayin with my sister, Daddy Ferguson PERSON ,” she said. Cassandra winked at Rhonda GPE and then said, once again, “When you get out there makin all them millions CARDINAL , you won’t forget me, willya?”

“Why do you always keep talkin that way, girl? You comin with me. Everybody’s comin with me.” She squeezed Cassandra GPE ’s hand. “I’d sooner forget Alice PERSON or Jeffrey PERSON than you. And you know I never lie to you.”

Cassandra PERSON nodded, but there was nothing behind the nod. She carried in her pocket, each wrapped in tinfoil, articles about Rhonda PERSON published in the Afro GPE and the Evening Star ORG . CARDOZO ORG H.S. SINGER ON THE RISE, the Star ORG headline said. FAMILY PERSON IS THE SECRET TO SINGER’S SUCCESS ORG , the Afro GPE headline said. And in the photograph accompanying that story, Cassandra PERSON was sitting on the couch beside Rhonda PERSON ’s youngest brother, who sat next to Rhonda PERSON . Rhonda PERSON was in the middle, holding her daughter Alice PERSON on her lap. The child was the only person in the picture who did not look directly into the camera. On the other side of Rhonda PERSON was her mother, and behind Rhonda PERSON were two CARDINAL older brothers and her father, who peered out through thick glasses. Beside Mr. Ferguson PERSON and directly behind Rhonda PERSON was Jeffrey Stanford PERSON , the father of Rhonda PERSON ’s child. His hand was resting on Rhonda PERSON ’s shoulder.

“But if you’re gonna take care of my business for me,” Rhonda PERSON said, “you’re gonna to have to get a education. How will I know if they cheatin me if you don’t know more than they know?”

“Thas right, baby girl,” her father said to Cassandra GPE . He was holding the steering wheel in the enthusiastic way a small child would, as if he were playing at driving the car. “We best get on now, so we won’t be late. But you go on by the house. Mabel cookin up a mess of fish and waitin for you. I wanna see you at the house when I get back.”

Rhonda PERSON pulled Cassandra GPE ’s face down and kissed her cheek. The sidewalk was now full of kids. Rhonda PERSON and her father drove down Clifton Street FAC , and all along the way to 11th Street FAC , students, noticing Rhonda GPE , would greet her. Some of them sang bits of the songs she was known for. Some of them danced.



Cassandra decided right then to make nice and return her brother-in-law’s car. But after she started it up, the car would only cough and shake and didn’t seem to want to move. After trying several times to get it going, she thought she’d give it time to make up its mind about going. She passed the time listening to radio music that came out mostly static because she had deliberately damaged the radio five months ago DATE after an argument with her brother-in-law. Toward three thirty TIME , as she was counting her cigarettes, Melanie Cartwright PERSON , on her way home, tapped on the roof. Melanie PERSON was a friendly sort who seemed to have a new boyfriend, a new “truest love,” every other month DATE . She was good for cigarettes, but she only smoked Viceroys GPE .

“Missed you in school today DATE ,” Melanie PERSON said. She had her notebook and two CARDINAL books in her arms and her pocketbook was hanging from her shoulder from a long strap. She was a second ORDINAL cousin of Cassandra GPE ’s brother-in-law, and at the wedding of Cassandra GPE ’s sister, Melanie PERSON and another girl had caught the bouquet together and nearly killed each other over who it belonged to.

“Wasn’t up for school today DATE ,” Cassandra PERSON said. She lit up a Chesterfield GPE .

Melanie PERSON was with Anita Hughes PERSON , a quiet girl Cassandra PERSON had met at Miss Barlett PERSON ’s apartment. Cassandra knew next to nothing about Anita PERSON , but she would forever remember the look on Anita PERSON ’s face when Anita PERSON told the story one evening TIME of how she had trembled and sung for her grandfather one final time at his funeral.

“I see you got Willie PERSON ’s car again,” Melanie PERSON said, laughing. “I bet he don’t know you got it.” Melanie PERSON and Anita PERSON stood in the street at the driver’s window, and whenever a car passed behind them, they leaned close to the car.

Cassandra blew out smoke and sucked her teeth. “ Willie PERSON always know when I got his car.”

“ Listen WORK_OF_ART ,” Melanie PERSON said, “you wanna make some money? You know Gladys Harper PERSON ? She lookin for someone to take her to her father’s in Anacostia GPE .”

Cassandra GPE thought a moment. “I don’t know,” she said. “She gonna pay some chump change or real money?”

“I think she said her mother’ll pay twenty dollars MONEY . She gotta take some things over there and they figure it’s cheaper than sendin Gladys alone by cab ORG .”

Anita PERSON said that Gladys ORG was still standing in front of Cardozo ORG , and Melanie PERSON stepped into the middle of the street and whistled her over. Gladys explained that her mother wanted a few small boxes of stuff taken to Gladys ORG ’s father in Anacostia GPE . Cassandra PERSON didn’t know Gladys at all, except to see her now and again passing in the school’s halls. Taking boxes from the mother to the father all the way in Anacostia PERSON seemed strange to Cassandra GPE , but being an orphan set adrift in the world she had learned that unless it could involve a death mistake, it was best to ask as few questions as possible. And besides, twenty bucks MONEY was twenty bucks MONEY . Anita GPE and Melanie PERSON said they wouldn’t mind coming along: Melanie PERSON ’s boyfriend had football practice, and Friday DATE evenings Anita PERSON ’s parents allowed her a bit more leeway than they did on school nights.

“Will this thing hold up down there and back?” Gladys said of the Hudson LOC , looking at it from front to back and up and down. “I don’t want to get stuck out there with my gotdamn father and his bitch whore.”

“It’ll do what I tell it,” Cassandra PERSON said, thinking she might get to see a fight. She and Gladys ORG waited while Anita PERSON and Melanie PERSON took their books home, a short distance away. When they returned, Cassandra PERSON started up the car without any trouble and the four CARDINAL drove down Clifton Street FAC to Gladys ORG ’s house on 12th Street FAC . The house and the yard were uncommonly immaculate. Such houses made Cassandra GPE nervous, because she associated them with owners who, without warning, smacked the hands of visiting children reaching out with curiosity to touch something.

Mildred Harper PERSON set the four CARDINAL girls at her kitchen table and fed ORG them a dinner of reheated fried chicken, string beans, potato salad, and rolls. “My husband and I,” she said to Cassandra GPE as she set out the food, “are separated. My son would take him the things, but he’s out of town right now, and I can’t get any of the other children to take him the stuff. He’s not well enough to come get them.” They sounded like words she had already said a thousand CARDINAL times, had learned to say to get it all out and over with. Anita PERSON and Melanie PERSON must have heard it before, because they didn’t seem surprised at what the mother was saying. After she had set out the food and told them to help themselves, Mildred Harper PERSON gave Cassandra a twenty-dollar MONEY bill and three dollars MONEY for gas and disappeared into another part of the house.



It was a pleasant Friday DATE evening TIME in early November DATE . The girls set off with an hour TIME or so of the day’s light remaining, and that light came through the last of the autumn DATE leaves still clinging to the trees. The birds, somewhere among those leaves and among the nooks and crannies of buildings, were making a racket as they bedded down. Cassandra felt good, because her stomach was full and she had a little piece of change in her pocket and she had a bed waiting that night TIME at Rhonda FAC ’s. At Elson PERSON ’s at 11th ORDINAL and T she filled up the gas tank. They continued on down 11th Street FAC . As usual when she drove, Cassandra PERSON leaned forward, her arms folded over the top of the steering wheel, the cigarette in her mouth bouncing up and down whenever she said anything. Gladys sat in the back, beside Anita PERSON , and in her lap was a small box of family photographs, the ones Mildred Harper PERSON could bear to part with. In the car’s trunk were two CARDINAL larger boxes, containing the last of her father’s stuff he had left at the house. Melanie PERSON , beside Cassandra GPE , was trying to get a decent station on the radio.

“Why don’t you leave it alone,” Cassandra PERSON said to her. “You want some music, make your own damn music.”

“I bet not even a hearse radio sound this bad,” Melanie PERSON said, and she began to sing “My Guy.”

“Sing it on. Sing it on,” Cassandra PERSON said. “I remember the first ORDINAL time I heard Rhonda PERSON sing that.”

“At that talent show, right?” Anita PERSON said.

“Right,” Cassandra PERSON said. “People started standin up and shit and cheerin and everything. I felt sorry for the other people who had to come on after her, cause nobody wanted to hear em. This one girl came on and she was tryin to play the guitar and people started callin for Rhonda PERSON , and this girl just gave up and left.”

“I paid my money and didn’t get a good seat,” Melanie PERSON said. She had turned the radio volume down, but she continued trying to get a clear station. “Yall better get all the lookin you can at Rhonda PERSON now, cause when she gets famous, you won’t be able to get within a hundred feet QUANTITY of her. She won’t even remember your name.”

“You don’t know what you talkin about, girl,” Cassandra PERSON said. “ Rhonda PERSON ’s gonna stay the same. I know her. You don’t even know her all that well.”

“They all change, and Rhonda PERSON ’s gonna change the most. Move out to Georgetown GPE or Chevy ORG Chase PRODUCT , if she still livin round here, and be with all them white people.”

“Oh, fuck you, Melanie PERSON !” Cassandra PERSON said.

“Fuck you back, Cassandra GPE . I gotta right to say what I think.”

“Not in my car, and not when you don’t know what you talkin about. And if you don’t like it, you can get out and walk your sorry ass back home.”

Melanie PERSON became quiet.

“Sing another song, Melanie PERSON ,” Anita PERSON said. “ Sing ‘My Guy’ WORK_OF_ART again.”

“No, thas all right,” Melanie PERSON pouted, turning off the radio and folding her arms.

“She sound like a gotdamn cat anyway,” Cassandra PERSON said.
