The birds in their trees continued to make a racket as they turned off 11th ORDINAL onto P Street. Just before 9th ORDINAL , they passed a group moving boxes and furniture into an apartment building across from Shiloh Baptist ORG .

At the light at 9th ORDINAL , Gladys ORG , looking back, asked if Cassandra GPE could back up. “I think thas Joyce PERSON and Pearl PERSON ,” she said. Cassandra backed up until she was in front of the pickup with a used couch in it. “Hey! Hey!” Gladys shouted to a man with a load of boxes. “That Joyce Moses PERSON in there?” The man nodded, and Cassandra PERSON parked the Hudson LOC behind the truck.

Upstairs, in the front apartment on the second ORDINAL floor, they found Joyce Moses PERSON and her friend Pearl Guthrie PERSON , heads in kerchiefs, standing in the middle of a nearly empty living room lit by one CARDINAL naked light bulb. Practically everyone at Cardozo ORG knew them— two CARDINAL pregnant girls who had dropped out of school to pool their church mice resources in an effort to make the best head start for themselves and their babies.

“Where the damn party?” Gladys asked.

“Wherever it is, you ain’t invited,” Pearl PERSON said, and the two CARDINAL embraced. Cassandra embraced Joyce PERSON , took Joyce PERSON ’s blouse in two CARDINAL fingers, shook it and wanted to know why she wasn’t showing at two months DATE “like all the other cows.” Melanie PERSON , after her hellos, went snooping in all the rooms of the apartment. Anita PERSON knew only Pearl PERSON and held back, standing in the doorway.

The movers were Joyce PERSON ’s father and Pearl PERSON ’s father and their relatives and friends. They were finishing up with the couch. Pearl PERSON , still with one arm around Gladys ORG , pointed to the place where she and Joyce PERSON wanted the couch, and the men set it in place. The room still looked empty. “We gonna make the rounds of Goodwill and Salvation Army ORG tomorrow DATE ,” Pearl PERSON said, seeing that Gladys noticed how empty the room was.

“If everything where yall want it,” Joyce PERSON ’s father said, “I’d best be gettin back.” He took his daughter in his arms and he kissed her forehead.

“ Tell Mama I WORK_OF_ART ’ll try to call her tomorrow,” Joyce PERSON said. “Tell her I hope she feelin better soon.”

“She’ll be feelin better tomorrow DATE just before you call. You got my word on that,” her father said.

Pearl PERSON ’s father gave her some money and embraced her. Then, as if embarrassed with others about, he withdrew and simply held her elbow. Though the room was full of people, there were no sounds except the movement of feet and the noise from outside. The other men had already gone downstairs, and Joyce PERSON ’s father and Pearl PERSON ’s father soon followed them. Joyce PERSON and Pearl PERSON went to the curtainless window to watch them go away. For three or four minutes TIME , as if they had completely forgotten that they had visitors, they stood watching at the window. Then Pearl PERSON began to cry and Joyce PERSON , once more, told her that it would be all right. “ Hush PERSON ,” she said. “ Hush PERSON now.”

“Where the hell was them sorry men a theirs?” Cassandra PERSON wanted to know when the four CARDINAL were back in the car. “Where the hell was Rufus PRODUCT ?”

“I know he was at football practice the other day DATE , cause Dwayne PERSON told me he was,” Melanie PERSON said. “And nobody in the world know where Kelvin PERSON at.”

“I feel like shootin PERSON both a them,” Gladys ORG said.

“I’m all for that,” Cassandra PERSON said, honking at the slow driver in front of her, “cept for that damn it-take-two-to-tango rule.”



The sun had set by the time they reached 8th ORDINAL and H GPE streets Northeast LOC , and after they had crossed East Capitol Street FAC , Cassandra GPE pulled over to ask directions to Anacostia of a young man.

“Oh, he was sooo cute,” Melanie PERSON said, when they were on their way again. “But he not as cute as Dwayne PERSON .”

“Thas all you ever think about is some dick,” Cassandra PERSON said. Anita PERSON and Gladys PERSON laughed.

“I’ll have you know me and Dwayne PERSON are engaged,” Melanie PERSON said.

“ Anita PERSON knows how to sing. She got a good voice,” Gladys said, wanting something to take the image of her friends standing at the window out of her mind.

“I don’t sing all that well,” Anita PERSON said. “I just sing in the choir.”

“Oh, oh. Better cut out all that cussin, ladies,” Cassandra PERSON said. “We got one CARDINAL of them choir girls in the car. Where your Bible WORK_OF_ART , honey?”

“I just sing in the choir,” Anita PERSON said again. “Nobody sings like Rhonda PERSON .”

“You got that right, sugar,” Cassandra PERSON said. “And for your information, Melanie PERSON , Rhonda PERSON went down to sign some contracts today DATE and she already offered me a job with her. Any kind of job I want. Put that in your pipe and smoke it.”

“She gonna quit school?” Anita PERSON said.

“You kiddin PERSON ? Her father wouldn’t let her do that in a million years DATE , singin contract or no contract.”



Despite the heavy traffic of people going home from work, they found Gladys ORG ’s father without much trouble. He lived in a small house on Maple View Place ORG , down the road from St. Elizabeths GPE and not far from Curtis Brothers ORG furniture store. Melanie PERSON wanted to stop at the store to see the giant chair they had in the parking lot, but Cassandra PERSON told her to get a good look as they drove by because that was as close as Melanie PERSON was going to get.

Gladys was out of the car as soon as they stopped and refused anyone’s help with the boxes. She put the small box of pictures under her arm as she carried the larger boxes to the front porch. The woman her father lived with opened the door and helped her take in the boxes, then the woman closed the door. The other girls got out of the car. Melanie PERSON , seeing three CARDINAL young men harmonizing up the street, sauntered up to them, and Cassandra GPE and Anita PERSON sat on the hood of the car, with Cassandra LOC smoking a Chesterfield GPE and Anita PERSON thinking that this was the first ORDINAL time in her life she was seeing Anacostia ORG .

“My grandfather used to say people in Anacostia ORG still lived with chickens and cows,” Anita PERSON said after a while.

“Shows you how much you know: They don’t allow em to do that anymore,” Cassandra PERSON said. She flicked the cigarette butt into Gladys ORG ’s father’s yard. “Even if they did, it wouldn’t tell you much— Anacostia ORG people the best people I ever met in the whole world, chickens or no chickens.” She counted how many cigarettes she had in the pack and decided to hold off on the next smoke. “My mama and daddy came from Anacostia ORG , then they had to go cross the fuckin river to live and get killed in some car crash.” She changed her mind and lit up another Chesterfield GPE , blew out the match, and flicked it into the yard.

Gladys came out of the house, followed by her father. Anita PERSON was the only one of the other girls who had ever seen him, and as he walked down to the gate she could see that he was weaker and weighed less than she remembered. At the gate he took his daughter in his arms and kissed her cheek twice, then twice more. The woman he lived with stood in the doorway, her arms crossed and a sweater around her shoulders.

Glady PERSON ’s father was saying something to her that the two CARDINAL girls could not hear, then, after a few moments, his daughter told him they had to go.

“You call me now, you hear?” her father said. Gladys nodded, but Anita PERSON could see that the nod had no truth in it.

Cassandra PERSON had to go get Melanie PERSON , who was talking under a street lamp with a boy who was standing extremely close to her.

“We goin in the next gotdamn second ORDINAL ,” Cassandra PERSON said, “with or without you, Miss Engaged.”

“ Whew WORK_OF_ART ,” Melanie PERSON said after everyone was in the car, “I’m glad you got me outta there. The singin was nice and he was cute, but he had the worse breath I ever smelled.”

Gladys ORG was looking back at her father, who stood holding the gate with one hand and waving with the other.

“Must be all them cows and chickens they live with, huh, Choir ORG Girl?” Cassandra PERSON said to Anita PERSON .

“I don’t know, Cassandra PERSON ,” Anita PERSON said. “But I do know that my name ain’t Choir Girl.”

“Ohhh. Ohh,” Cassandra PERSON said. “Excuse me very very much.”

“I felt like slappin that little bitch into next week DATE ,” Gladys ORG said. Though they were many blocks from her father, she continued looking back. “The whole time I was standin there I kept askin myself: What does this little bitch have that my mother doesn’t have? And she was treatin my father like he didn’t have a brain in his body. ‘ Honey PERSON , you chilly? Honey PERSON , you wanna put on your sweater? Honey PERSON , give her some money fore she go. Honey PERSON , make sure you give her our phone number….’” She spewed out the words, as if it were a matter of talking or exploding.

“What we need is a party,” Melanie PERSON said. “Help pick us up.”

“Thas what you always seem to need,” Cassandra ORG said.

Melanie PERSON ignored her and turned around in the seat to speak to Anita PERSON and Gladys. “This guy told me about a party on F Street FAC in Northeast LOC .” She looked out her window to see where they were. “ Twelve oh nine CARDINAL F Street FAC .”

“ Nine CARDINAL one two CARDINAL ,” Cassandra PERSON said.

“What?” Melanie PERSON said.

“You sure he didn’t say nine CARDINAL one two F Street FAC ? Or nine CARDINAL oh one two CARDINAL ? One CARDINAL two CARDINAL nine F Street FAC ? Or maybe E Street, or C Street FAC ?” Cassandra PERSON said. “You flicted bitch, you tryin to get us lost, looking for some damn party.”

Melanie PERSON deflated and sat back in her seat.

“Why not?” Gladys said. “Why don’t we see if it was twelve CARDINAL oh nine CARDINAL , Cassandra GPE . We ain’t got nothin else better to do. Besides, we still drivin on gas my mother paid for.”

“Sure, why not?” Anita PERSON said.

Melanie PERSON perked up and Cassandra ORG shrugged her shoulders, saying, “If we get lost, it ain’t my damn fault.” She patted the dashboard for good luck and turned off 8th ORDINAL Southeast onto C Street FAC . But they had no sooner crossed East Capitol LOC when Cassandra GPE began to feel the car hesitate, and just beyond D Street it stopped after Cassandra GPE managed to pull it to the curb. She got out, rocked the trunk a few seconds TIME , and cursed it in a voice passersby could not hear. She was in a different country, and she thought the laws might not be the same for her here.

It was a fairly quiet street, with a few older people sitting on their porches and children playing on either side of the street. Most of the noise was coming from a house across the street where there seemed to be a party going on. A hi-fi was bouncing noise off houses. In front of the house with the hi-fi, a fellow was under the hood of a car and a small boy was beside him shining two CARDINAL flashlights into the maw. The fellow came out of the car, wiped his hands on a rag he pulled from his back pocket. He looked at Cassandra GPE and her car as if deciding what to do, and then came toward her, looking back once or twice to the little boy. He was an awesomely muscled young man no more than eighteen. The muscles looked even more dramatic as the street lamp behind first ORDINAL silhouetted him, then gave way to the brightness of a street lamp on Cassandra GPE ’s side of the street.

“Look like you got trouble,” he said to Cassandra GPE , who had opened the hood with Anita PERSON ’s help. He smelled like the world of dirt and oily metal and rubber Cassandra PERSON found under the hoods of all cars. The small boy had followed the guy, but he seemed interested only in shining the flashlights up and down the street, first ORDINAL on this house, then another.

The hi-fi music had pulled Melanie PERSON out of the car toward the house, and Gladys ORG followed her.

“I’m Wesley,” the guy said to Cassandra GPE . “You want me to see what I can do with it?” He was country, stone Bama PERSON .

“Oh, no. Not really. We just waitin for the midnight TIME train to come by.”

“What?” Wesley PERSON said. He had a funny booklike jaw, square and unreal, and Cassandra ORG had the urge to stroke it.

“She means we’d appreciate any help you can give us,” Anita PERSON said.

The little boy stepped confidently up to the car and shone the flashlights under the hood. Wesley bent down into the car. Anita PERSON followed Melanie PERSON and Gladys ORG into the house. Several times Wesley PERSON went back across the street to get tools, and Cassandra PERSON tried not to let him or the boy or the people on their porches see how much pleasure it gave her to see him walk. He had a very tiny behind that she felt she could cup in both her hands. He seemed entirely comfortable with himself, but was far from being a showoff, and this made him even more endearing. Is this me? she asked herself as she watched him walk. She wanted to believe that the muscles were the result of a life of hard work, not a life in a gym with dozens CARDINAL of other men and tons of dumbbells. “I’ll hold them,” she said to the little boy after a time and took the flashlights. The boy resisted until Wesley PERSON told him it was all right. Cassandra leaned into the car beside Wesley PRODUCT and made certain their thighs were touching.

Before long, Wesley PERSON had the car running again, and Cassandra ORG cursed it silently.

“It’ll take you home, lady,” Wesley PERSON said, “but I wouldn’t trust it after that. A beautiful thing if you take care of it.”

“What do I owe you, Mississippi LOC ?” Cassandra PERSON said, handing the flashlights back to the boy. “I hope it ain’t much, cause I’m just a poor widow woman.”

Wesley PERSON raised his eyebrows, then shook his head, no charge. “No one in this city talks straight, do they?” he said. “You live round here?” The little boy had stepped into the street and was again shining the lights about the houses.

“No. I live in Northwest GPE . Across town. That straight enough for you?”

He nodded. “ Bob PERSON , get out the street.” And to Cassandra PERSON , “Thas my cousin. I live with him and his family over there”—he pointed to the hosue with the music—“my PRODUCT uncle and everybody. Came up from South Carolina GPE to learn some things.” The boy, after a few moments, got in the back seat of Cassandra GPE ’s car and at first ORDINAL pretended to fall asleep, then he climbed over the front seat and sat behind the wheel. “You go to movies, lady? Go to picture shows?”

“Every one I can,” Cassandra PERSON said.

He took a pencil and piece of paper from his back pocket. “Well, if you give me your phone number, I’ll call you sooner than you can say your name. If you don’t mind. If your people don’t mind.”

As she wrote her sister’s telephone number down, there was a scream from the house with the music. When Cassandra GPE and Wesley PERSON reached the porch, Melanie PERSON , crying, was coming out of the house with her blouse torn, Anita PERSON and Gladys on either side of her.

“What happened!” Cassandra PERSON yelled. “What the fuck happened!”

“That guy got rough with me,” Melanie PERSON managed to say.

“Who?” Cassandra PERSON said. “Who was it?”

A young man followed them out of the house. “It was all a misunderstandin,” he said.

“Was it you, you sonofabitch!” Cassandra PERSON grabbed his throat and squeezed. “You try to rape my friend?” The guy was able only to shake his head before Wesley PERSON took her arm, held it. “Lady, please don’t do that. He my cousin,” Wesley PERSON said.

“I don’t give three CARDINAL fucks who he is!” Cassandra PERSON said. She began to struggle, but he held both her arms and the more he held her, the calmer she became. Whatever had been in his eyes before Melanie PERSON screamed was there no more and she would have given her arms to have it back.

“It wasn’t him. It was Roger PERSON ,” a girl said from inside. “He been drinkin too much.”

“Yeah,” Melanie PERSON said, “it was that Roger PERSON . He got rough. Too rough.”

Wesley PERSON called for Roger PERSON to come explain himself, but someone said Roger PERSON had run out the back door. The three CARDINAL girls helped Melanie PERSON into the car. Wesley PERSON asked her if she needed anything and she shook her head. Then, all the while looking at Cassandra GPE , he stood with his hands in his back pockets beside the little boy as Cassandra PERSON started up the car, which purred into life on the first ORDINAL try. They did not say good-bye.



“That was a close call. Another lesson learned,” Melanie PERSON said after they had gone a few blocks. Anita PERSON had given her her sweater and Melanie PERSON was buttoning it. “This blouse is ruined, though. He’d be a real nice guy if he wasn’t so rough. Should learn to treat a woman like a lady. But he was cute.”

“You know,” Cassandra PERSON said, “I’m fuckin tired of all your talk about somebody bein cute all the time. You gettin on my nerves with that shit! You sound like a damn cuckoo clock with just one CARDINAL tune!” For the next two CARDINAL blocks or so she pounded on the horn and rocked her head in exasperation. “You know how many girls pull down their panties and give up the booty just cause some boy is cute! Just cause some boy has some shitty good hair! Just cause somebody has the best rap in the whole damn world! And you, you the leader of them all, Melanie PERSON !” Melanie PERSON slumped back in her seat. “Thas why nothin ain’t right no more,” Cassandra PERSON continued, “cause some dumb bitch like you think this dick-head and that dick-head is so cute! Get some brains, girl! I get so sick and tired of you!”

“I didn’t mean anything by it, Cassandra LOC .”

“That’s your trouble: You never mean anything by it.” She turned to look at Melanie PERSON . “And if you had any sense, you’d dump that dick-head Dwayne PERSON . He’s the dumbest thing in the world, but he playin you for eighty-nine CARDINAL kinds of fool. But you won’t see that cause he’s sooooo cute.”

“ Stop the car WORK_OF_ART ,” Melanie PERSON said calmly. “Just stop the car right now. I wanna get out.” She began jerking on the door handle. “Stop the car, I said!”

“Don’t tell me what to do! Nobody tells me what to do!”

“I really wanna get out, Cassandra PERSON ,” Melanie PERSON said, moving the handle up and down. “Why do you hate me so much? What have I ever done to you in my whole life to make you hate me so much?” She began to cry. “What harm did I ever do you, thas what I wanna know. Why you against me just because I’m in love with Dwayne PERSON ? What bad thing I ever did to you in my whole life, Cassandra PERSON ?”

Melanie PERSON got the door open and Cassandra PERSON braked. Melanie PERSON stumbled out into the street and made her way to the sidewalk. Anita PERSON and Gladys PERSON followed her. Melanie PERSON , first ORDINAL thinking it was Cassandra GPE , pushed Gladys when she put her arm around her shoulders. Anita PERSON walked on her other side. Cassandra PERSON followed them slowly in the car as the three CARDINAL went down 8th Street FAC . She could not hear what they were saying, but she could see Melanie PERSON shaking her head no no no.

At 8th ORDINAL and H GPE streets, the girls stopped and Cassandra GPE , after waiting for the light, turned the car around and parked at the corner, ignoring the NO PARKING sign. Anita PERSON , walking backward to face Melanie PERSON , held her by the shoulders, and she and Gladys ORG said things that made Melanie PERSON look Anita PERSON directly in the eye. Little by little Melanie PERSON calmed down and stopped crying. She nodded her head once, but Cassandra PERSON could see that it was not the yes to get back in the car. She watched them go into the Mile Long LOC at the corner and saw them order sodas and stand at the counter and drink them.

Cassandra PERSON wanted a cigarette, but she hadn’t the will to open the glove compartment and pull one from the pack. Across 8th Street FAC a drunk was dancing with the wobbliness of a puppet. Just as he seemed about to fall, his legs collapsing, he would straighten himself and dance around the two CARDINAL little boys who were watching him, then his legs would give out again and the boys would reach out to catch him. The boys’ mother, waiting for a bus, ignored the drunk. Cassandra watched the girls drink the sodas as if they had all the rest of their lives to do it. Gradually, Melanie PERSON began to smile, but she continued to hold her soda with both hands. Melanie PERSON did not seem to be saying anything, only listening to what the other two CARDINAL said. Serve the bitches right if I take off and leave them here. But Cassandra PERSON did not leave, and when the bus came and took the mother and her boys away, she began to worry that the drunk would spot her and come over and dance and make her the center of attention.

Anita PERSON was the first ORDINAL to return to the car. “I thought you might have left us,” she said, handing Cassandra a soda.

“It never crossed my mind to do that,” Cassandra PERSON said. She set the soda between her legs and did not open it.

“Sure it did,” Anita PERSON said. “You were thinkin about what our faces would look like when we got out here and found we didn’t have a ride back to Northwest ORG .” She sat facing Cassandra LOC , her left arm over the back of the seat. “You sat here thinkin how good it would feel to ride off and leave us stranded. You know how I know? Cause I woulda been thinkin the same thing.” She opened the glove compartment and took a cigarette from the pack, stuck it in Cassandra GPE ’s mouth, and lit the cigarette. “Probably dyin for one a these, I bet.” Cassandra inhaled and blew smoke out of the side of her mouth. Cassandra looked directly ahead, and then, after she had inhaled again, she closed her eyes with relief. Anita PERSON unwrapped a straw and stuck it through the plastic top of the soda cup EVENT .

In a few minutes TIME , Melanie PERSON got in the back with Gladys ORG . No one said anything until they were well out of Northeast LOC . Gladys asked Melanie PERSON to sing something, but Melanie PERSON said she wasn’t in the mood for no song.

“Well, what about you, Anita PERSON ?” Gladys said. “What you feel like hearin PERSON , Melanie PERSON ? ‘My Guy’?” Melanie PERSON said nothing. “What about you, Cassandra PERSON ? What happened to the party we was supposed to have? Anita PERSON , how bout ‘Will You Still Love Me’?”

“It’s called ‘ Will You Love Me Tomorrow WORK_OF_ART .’” Cassandra PERSON said.

“I hear the money going down in the jukebox,” Anita PERSON said. “Kerchink, ker-chink.” Anita PERSON sang:

Tonight TIME you’re mine completely;

You give your love so sweetly.



“I’d pay a quarter DATE for that,” Gladys said.

Anita PERSON sang:

Tonight TIME the light of love is in your eyes,

But will you love me tomorrow DATE ?



“I’d pay a hundred bucks,” Cassandra PERSON said and honked the horn.

Anita PERSON sang:

Tonight TIME with words unspoken

you say that I’m the only one

But will my heart be broken

when the night TIME meets the morning sun?



That was how they went the rest of the way home.

Anita PERSON sang:

I’d like to know that your love

Is love I can be sure of.

So, tell me now and I won’t ask again,

Will you still love me tomorrow DATE ?



Cassandra parked on 12th Street FAC a few doors down from Gladys ORG ’s house. She decided to leave the car there for the night TIME and return it to her brother-in-law in the morning TIME . Gladys went home, and the three CARDINAL girls went on up Clifton ORG toward 13th Street FAC . They were about halfway up the block when a little boy ran past them coming from 13th DATE . “ Rhonda PERSON ’s been shot!” he shouted to no one in particular. “ Rhonda PERSON ’s been killed!” The three CARDINAL all knew the boy as the biggest liar in the world. He was followed by his mother, who carried a switch as long as the boy. “You better stop!” the mother hollered. “You just gonna make it worse when I catch you!” The girls laughed.

The chaos on 13th Street FAC began at the corner, with dozens CARDINAL of people standing from the corner up to Rhonda PERSON ’s house in the middle of the block. The girls could see that 13th Street was blocked off from Clifton ORG to Euclid. There were five or so CARDINAL police cars parked every which way about the street. One had come onto the sidewalk and was facing the low stone wall at Rhonda GPE ’s place. Cassandra PERSON had begun walking faster after she turned the corner and crossed 13th Street FAC , pushing her way violently through the crowd. Anita PERSON held on to her back, and Melanie PERSON held Anita PERSON ’s back. Anita PERSON ’s mother was standing a few feet QUANTITY from the front of Rhonda FAC ’s house where two CARDINAL policemen, unsmiling, arms folded, stood as if they would never again do anything as important. One CARDINAL kept telling people, “Get back, get back.”

“Mama, what happened?” Anita PERSON said.

“ Jeffrey PERSON shot Rhonda PERSON ,” her mother said. “ Jeffrey PERSON killed Rhonda PERSON .”

“You shouldn’t say that,” Cassandra PERSON said. She began calling Rhonda PERSON ’s name. She called her friend’s entire name, even the two CARDINAL middle ones, which Rhonda PERSON hated. There were plainclothesmen in the yard and even more in the house. All the lights in the house seemed to be on, and Cassandra PERSON could see the strange men on the first ORDINAL floor and in the basement walking by the windows and talking among themselves. She called Rhonda PRODUCT ’s name. Nothing seemed real, not the buzzing of the crowd, not that house lit up from top to bottom as if for a party.

“Honey, it’s true,” Anita PERSON ’s mother said to Cassandra GPE and took the girl by the arm. Cassandra continued to call. At any moment the hated middle names would bring Rhonda PERSON , pretending to be angry, to the window.

“This is Rhonda PRODUCT ’s best friend, Mama,” Anita PERSON said.

A woman next to Anita PERSON ’s mother said, “He just shot her for no reason at all. I was playin out there with my grandbaby and I could see her practicin in the basement.” Cassandra PERSON stepped toward the policemen with the folded arms and one told her, “Get back, get back.” “He shot her and then just came out here and sat down on the steps,” the woman said, “like he was waitin for a ride to come pick him up.”

Rhonda PERSON ’s father was a very thrifty man, and had he been there, Cassandra GPE knew, had his daughter been in the basement, alive and practicing, all those lights would not have been on. Melanie PERSON took Cassandra PERSON ’s other arm and began to cry. They took Cassandra PERSON back through the crowd and across the street to Clifton Terrace PERSON , where Anita PERSON lived. Melanie PERSON , still crying, hugged the three CARDINAL women, then, as if she had forgotten what she had just done, she hugged Cassandra LOC twice more and went home.



Anita PERSON ’s father and brother were playing chess at the kitchen table when they came in. Anita PERSON and her mother took Cassandra PERSON into the girl’s room. Cassandra sat on the bed with her hands in her lap and looked out the window. Anita PERSON stood at the foot of the bed, one arm around the bedpost, looking down at Cassandra GPE . An eyeless and very old teddy bear leaning back against her bed pillows had fallen over when Cassandra GPE sat down. The ticking of the Big Ben clock Anita PERSON ’s grandfather had given her was the loudest sound in the room. In the kitchen, her brother was proclaiming victory over their father for only the third ORDINAL or fourth ORDINAL time in the boy’s life. Beyond her window Anita PERSON could see the twinkling lights of Washington GPE .

Anita PERSON ’s mother came in and gave Cassandra a cup of cocoa sitting in a saucer.

“I got to be goin…I got to be goin to home,” Cassandra PERSON whispered, saying bome as if it were a foreign word. Anita PERSON told her to drink. Anita PERSON watched as her mother helped Cassandra PERSON off with her clothes and into one of her mother’s nightgowns.

She made a pallet for her daughter beside the bed and turned out the light when she left the room. Occasionally, Cassandra GPE would drift into what Anita PERSON thought was sleep. All the while Cassandra PERSON gritted her teeth. Sometime way late in the night TIME , Cassandra ORG spoke out, and at first ORDINAL Anita PERSON thought she was talking in her sleep: She asked Anita PERSON to sing that song she had sung in the car on the way home. Anita PERSON sang; long after her parents had gone to bed, long after she stopped wondering if Cassandra GPE was listening, Anita PERSON sang. She sang on into the night TIME for herself alone, her voice pushing back everything she did not yet understand.





YOUNG LIONS




He stood naked before the open refrigerator in the darkened kitchen, downing the last of the milk in a half-gallon carton. Carol PERSON , once again, had taped a note to the carton. Caesar Matthews PERSON did not have to read it to know that it told him she loved him with all her heart, or that she would miss him all that day. She used to pin such notes to her pillow before she went off in the morning, leaving him still asleep. But in the night TIME , when she brushed her hair as she prepared for bed, she would find the notes still pinned to the pillow, undisturbed and so perhaps unread. So now she taped them to milk cartons, for he could not begin his day without drinking milk, or she taped them to his gold key ring, or pinned them to the zippers of the expensive pants she knew he would wear that day DATE . In more than two years DATE , the wording on the notes had not changed very much. Sometimes, when he thought of it, he would fold the paper with the words and place it on the kitchen table between the salt and pepper shakers, to let her know he had come upon it before he ventured out.

This morning TIME , after he had finished the last of the milk, without reading the words, he tossed the carton in a high arc across the room into the trash can. He pulled up the window shade and let in the morning light. He was anxious to be out in the streets; there was nothing like an empty apartment to bring down the soul.

The night before TIME , for the fourth ORDINAL time in a week DATE , he had dreamed about the retarded woman. Sherman PERSON would have told him such dreams were a good sign. Caesar PERSON was left now with only fragments of the dreams, the splintered memory that he had been roaming about in some foreign land, and the retarded woman had been standing among tall trees in that land. She never seemed to be hiding, as she should have been, but appeared to wave to him. He could not remember anything after she waved. He did remember with certainty that in all the dreams the woman was known to him not as being retarded but as being feeble-minded, which was the phrase his father had always used.

He was still naked when the telephone rang, standing at the bathroom door wondering if he wanted a shower. “These are the times,” Carol PERSON would have joked, “when we miss our mothers most.”

Manny PERSON , on the telephone, asked if he wanted to tend bar that evening and make some change. “I was about to hop over your place,” Caesar ORG said. He never liked Manny Soto PERSON calling his apartment, for Manny PERSON always whispered on the phone and made each word he spoke sound obscene. “He talk that way cause he’s a fence and every other bad thing in the world,” Sherman PERSON had said once. “He think people are listenin to everything he says, and maybe by whisperin, they’ll hear a little less.”

“Coincidences. Coincidences. Heh, heh,” Manny PERSON said. “Good minds think a lot, they say. I was just checking to be sure, heh, heh, to see if you might be available, heh, heh.” The inappropriate laughing was also why he didn’t like Manny PERSON calling.

“But listen: You heard what Sherman PERSON is doing now, heh, heh, heh?” Manny PERSON said. This time he obviously felt the whole thing was funny, and he asked Caesar ORG again.

Caesar PERSON told him no, that he had last seen Sherman PERSON in Howard Hospital ORG . “ Two CARDINAL , three months ago DATE ,” he said.

“Well, since you last saw him, he’s gone up in the world. Or gone down, whichever the case may be, heh, heh.” He hung up without another word.

While dressing, Caesar ORG found another note pinned to the collar of his shirt. He read it, crumbled it for effect, and propped it against a picture they had had taken together at a Southeast NORP club. He would remind Carol PERSON of all the notes when he told her about the retarded woman. “Dancing with me don’t end that way,” were the first ORDINAL words she had ever spoken to him. “Try me and see.” He had gone to Manny PERSON ’s place with Sherman Wheeler PERSON and Sherman PERSON ’s old lady, Sandra Wallington PERSON , and, after a good bit of coaxing by Sandra PERSON , he had asked a woman sitting alone two CARDINAL tables away to dance. He and the woman had slow-dragged through one CARDINAL record, then another, and as the woman ground her body into his, she would bite and tug at his earlobe with her lips. When the second ORDINAL record ended, she unwound herself and went back without a word to her table. There was now a man at her table, and the man stood and pulled the woman’s chair away from the table for her. The man and the woman sat down. The woman’s back was to Caesar ORG , who stood dumbly looking at the back of her neck and at the man. The man stood again, and he looked at Caesar ORG with the patience of someone who had nothing better to do. “No one,” the man said finally, “gets more than two CARDINAL dances free.” He sat again and Caesar ORG , after a few moments, found his way back to Sherman PERSON and Sandra PERSON .

“Dancing with me don’t end that way.” He had been about to sit when Carol PERSON tugged at his shirt sleeve. He allowed her to lead him away to the dance floor. “Try me and see.”



He decided that morning TIME on the desert-brown leather jacket, a present from Carol PERSON for his twenty-second TIME birthday two years ago DATE . It was October DATE , and in that month DATE and in November DATE before the days DATE turned colder heading into December DATE , he enjoyed wearing the jacket, enjoyed the opulent sound of leather with each move he made. He checked the jacket’s pockets to make certain he had his address book. There was not much in the book—a few names and telephone numbers of people he knew from Manny PERSON ’s. But there were also the addresses and phone numbers of the three CARDINAL women—their names coded to read like male friends in case Carol PERSON saw them—he would go to when he and Carol PERSON argued, or when he simply wanted to spend the night TIME with a woman whose body, whose responses, he could not easily anticipate.

He put the Beretta PRODUCT in one CARDINAL of the jacket’s pockets. The moment he touched it the memory of the times he had used it came back to him. He liked remembering. The last time had been eight months ago DATE when they crossed into Maryland GPE and he shot the 7-Eleven clerk in the face. A few miles QUANTITY from the store, back in D.C. GPE , Caesar GPE was still laughing about how the man’s face had drained of blood as the gun came toward his face. A month before that he had placed the pistol beside the head of a man he and Sherman PERSON had caught far up New Hampshire Avenue FAC near the Silver Spring FAC line. The man had looked insulted to be robbed, and Caesar PERSON , dangling the man’s watch before his eyes, had pulled the trigger to scare him into the proper frame of mind. “I wasn’t gonna take this cheap-ass thing,” Caesar PERSON said about the watch, “but you just ain’t got the proper attitude.” The bullet had nicked the man’s ear, and so it didn’t count the way a blast in the face counted. The nice thing about the retarded woman was that he wouldn’t even have to take the pistol out of his pocket.

Sherman Wheeler PERSON had rarely carried a gun. “My daddy got his toe shot off tryin to quick-draw one a those things,” he said once. “Sides, my mind is the only gun I need.” Then he had made his hand into a gun, placed it against his temple, and pretended to pull a trigger. He hadn’t liked Caesar ORG carrying a gun, and in their first months DATE together he pulled rank and told him to leave the guns at home when they weren’t needed, but Caesar ORG would sneak them out anyway. From the beginning, with the first ORDINAL cheap piece he had stolen during a burglary at a home in Arlington GPE , Caesar GPE had liked carrying a gun. And now, having to work alone without Sherman PERSON , he would not step outside the apartment without one.

II

In the vestibule of Manny PERSON ’s Haven at Georgia Avenue FAC and Ingraham Street FAC , there was an impressive collection of Polaroid ORG pictures displayed behind a locked glass case. In most of the dozens CARDINAL of photographs, Manny PERSON , always wearing a Hawaiian NORP shirt, stood in the center, his arms around Washington GPE politicians, two CARDINAL -bit celebrities, customers for whom he had a special affection, or wild-eyed, out-of-town relatives. At the very bottom of the display, in two and a half CARDINAL rows, there were also photographs of men who had, as Manny PERSON put it, “made irredeemable fools of themselves in my house,” as he called his bar. Most of these men, usually too drunk even to remember where they were, had refused to leave the bar when told, and Manny PERSON had had the bouncers toss them out. But throwing them out was never enough, and he would also have the bouncers beat them on the sidewalk. “Take his picture! Take his goddamn picture!” became his euphemism to the bouncers for throwing a man out and putting a hurting on him. The majority of the men were photographed leaning against the front of the bar just below the neon sign that blinked Manny PERSON ’s Haven. They were alone in their pictures with their bloodied faces, except, now and again, for the hand of some unseen bouncer that kept the fellow from falling over.

Manny PERSON was reading the Post ORG aloud at a table near the bar when Caesar ORG arrived that morning TIME . Manny PERSON was alone, which didn’t make Caesar PERSON happy. The whole place was dark, except for the tiny lamp on the table. Manny PERSON did not look up at first ORDINAL when Caesar ORG sat down across from him and said, “ Mornin PERSON .”

Manny PERSON finished the page and put the newspaper aside, took off his glasses and rubbed his closed eyes with his knuckles. “ Young Blood WORK_OF_ART ,” he said, squinting. “Ain’t seen you in a month of Sundays DATE . Thought you mighta gone away on vacation.” Manny PERSON dressed the way a very small child would without the help of an adult. “I always expect to look under the table and find him with his shoes on the wrong feet,” Sherman PERSON had said once, “with knots and shit in the shoelaces, insteada little bows.” Manny PERSON had hundreds CARDINAL of Hawaiian NORP shirts, including some very expensive ones dating back to the 1920s and DATE 1930s DATE . He wore one every day of the year DATE . This morning TIME he had on a particularly loud silk and rayon thing with palm trees that looked not like trees but tiny green explosions. He was quite a thin man, and all his shirts hung loosely on him, the way they would hang on wire hangers.

“I’ll need you for tonight TIME and two three CARDINAL more nights this week DATE ,” Manny PERSON said. “You got time for that?”

Caesar ORG nodded. Bartending would tide him over until things were finished with the retarded woman. He could hear the rumblings of the men in the basement, sorting and cataloging the stolen stuff Manny PERSON had bought from thieves. Manny PERSON would send all of it on to an apartment on Florida Avenue FAC where people came shopping to buy it for a little more than what Manny PERSON paid for it.

“What’s this about you not hearing about Sherman PERSON ?” Manny PERSON said. “Thought you two CARDINAL was closer than dick PERSON and his two CARDINAL nuts.”

“We was once,” Caesar ORG said. Manny PERSON blinked, waiting for more. He undoubtedly knew everything already, but Caesar ORG knew that having to tell him was the price of doing business with him. Besides, there was nothing to betray. He told Manny PERSON what little Sherman PERSON had told him in the hospital the last time he saw him: Sherman PERSON had ODed ORG at the home of a woman who catered to a small group of people with “functional habits,” people who could work and carry on their lives without the rest of the world knowing they needed special recreation in their off hours TIME . A person could go to one CARDINAL of Regina PERSON ’s houses on M Street FAC and relax in one of her small rooms, and after a few hours TIME of traveling, get up and go home.

“I know this woman,” Manny PERSON said. “ Regina Carstairs WORK_OF_ART . Oh, such a fine house in the Gold Coast LOC . I went to her place for a function once, raising money for the mayor. The house where no junkie is allowed. But I didn’t enjoy myself because she had somebody watch me all the time like I was going to steal something.” Manny PERSON indicated with his fingers that he wanted more.

There’s not much more, Caesar ORG said. Sherman PERSON had traveled out on a far limb one night TIME with just a one CARDINAL -way ticket. Regina PERSON thought he was dead or near-dead and had people dump him in a tree box on a street blocks and blocks from her house. (“Another satisfied customer,” Manny PERSON interjected. “ One million CARDINAL and counting.”) Caesar ORG did not tell Manny PERSON that in the hospital he and Sandra PERSON , Sherman PERSON ’s woman, had argued, with Sandra PERSON accusing him of dumping Sherman PERSON at death’s door. He had looked to Sherman PERSON for support, but in the end Sherman PERSON had raised the arm without the IV and begged Caesar PERSON to go. “I’ll call you,” Sherman PERSON had said.

“I got some pictures here you might be interested in, heh, heh,” Manny PERSON said. “Got some nice pictures. Oh, do I got the nice pictures. Bet a million CARDINAL you didn’t know he was on that heroin shit, did you?”

Caesar ORG said no.

“Well, I did. It’s hard to tell with some fools, but I knew.” He was leaning back in his chair, his arms crossed. He was thin enough for Caesar ORG to see the edges of the chair on either side of him. “That’s the thing with that heroin shit. You see, with your average crackhead, they’re climbing the walls and everything. You ask them the time and they’re ready to kill you cause you ain’t got your own watch. But with heroin, you ask them the time, and they’re ready to give you the watch. And Sherman PERSON was the mellowest man I knew.” He leaned forward. “You wanna see my pictures, heh, heh? The proof from our man Polaroid ORG that our man from Sixteenth Street FAC has come up in the world.”

Caesar PERSON was curious, but he did not want to see. It was as if someone had asked if he wanted to see pictures of his naked father. “We can take him,” Caesar PERSON had said once about Manny PERSON . “We can take him. Come in wearin masks and shit. We can clean his ass out and live like kings.” “And then where we gonna live?” Sherman PERSON had said. “Even if we got a million dollars MONEY from him, where in the fuckin world would we live? Stop bein such a hothead all the time, man. Manny PERSON still payin people back for some small thing they probably did to him when he was five years old DATE .”

“ Come on,” WORK_OF_ART Manny PERSON said. “Peek on the wild side.” In fall and winter DATE , Manny PERSON ’s Hawaiian NORP shirts had two CARDINAL pockets, and he took a set of photographs out of the left pocket.

The pictures were of a security guard standing with folded arms between two CARDINAL paintings in what was clearly a museum. The man seemed to stand with an air of importance and authority, but the more Caesar ORG studied the first ORDINAL pictures the more he saw that the man would never be anything more than a guard whose job was simply to stand between two CARDINAL paintings. The man’s expression changed but slightly in the series of photographs, but in the last one, as if he was finally aware that he was the photographer’s real subject, he was turning his head away and the camera caught only a blur. The guard, in a dark blue uniform, wore a dark blue hat with a shiny shield in the front, and though the hat was pulled down low over his forehead, Caesar PERSON could see that the mouth and chin were Sherman PERSON ’s. “My father gave me my eyes and nose, but I got my mouth and chin from my old lady.” Sherman PERSON had been on his own since he was ten CARDINAL , but he always spoke of his parents as if he had had a full life with them.

“They were taken in the Smithsonian ORG ,” Manny PERSON was saying. “Not the one with that big elephant—that’s my favorite—but the art museum, the one with the paintings. When I heard he was working there, I just had to see it. So I had this guy and his whore that owed me a favor: Act like tourists and go down there and pretend they were Bamas in town to see the pictures, heh, heh.” Manny PERSON tapped his forehead. “ Smart WORK_OF_ART . Real smart.”

Caesar ORG got up. “I gotta be movin. Be back at seven CARDINAL , okay?”

“ Seven WORK_OF_ART ’s fine,” Manny PERSON said, kissing the pictures and putting them back in his pocket. “Any later and you’ll be late.”

III ORG

He felt suddenly exhausted and afraid and considered returning to the apartment, but Carol PERSON was not there and an empty place brought down the soul. Then he thought of the retarded woman and things brightened a bit. He took a bus downtown to see the woman for what would be the last time before Friday DATE .

He had been following her for all of two months DATE , since a week or so after DATE he saw Sherman PERSON in the hospital. He had first ORDINAL come upon her waiting for the bus with three CARDINAL of her housemates. They were all adults, all at least thirty years old, but they talked as if they were new to the world and excited about being in it. The two CARDINAL men talked very loudly, as if they were not afraid to share whatever they were saying. Caesar PERSON figured from the beginning that the larger of the two CARDINAL women was the weakest, would be the easiest to pick off.

He had stood a few feet QUANTITY from them, pretending he too was waiting for the bus. Days later DATE he learned that the retarded woman lived only two CARDINAL blocks from the bus stop in a house with perhaps six CARDINAL other retarded people of various ages and with a woman in her fifties. He figured the older woman was there to look after the seven CARDINAL . Except for the older woman, he learned, all of them worked, or at least did something that took them out of the house each morning TIME . The retarded woman he was interested in worked in a French NORP restaurant on Connecticut Avenue FAC near Lafayette Park FAC .

And so for two months DATE he had secretly placed himself in her life, doing all the scoping out, the drudgery that had once been left up to Sherman PERSON . “You’d fuck it up,” Sherman PERSON had said once. “I know you.” “Have some faith in me,” Caesar PERSON would laugh. “Have a little faith.” “I know you, mothafucka.”

Week after week DATE , Caesar ORG had followed the retarded woman as she made her way to work, sitting in the back of the bus so he could see when she got off. At K Street FAC , she always walked the block and a half to the restaurant. He hung around near the restaurant, sometimes for the entire day DATE , learning her schedule. He often saw her sweeping up the alley in the back where the employees entered and where deliveries were made. About two CARDINAL thirty or so most afternoons, after they had probably eaten lunch, the retarded woman and a much older woman would walk to Lafayette Park FAC and stay for up to thirty minutes TIME . After they went back to work, he would not see the girl again until about five CARDINAL , when she left work and took the bus home.

On Saturdays DATE , she came to work at noon TIME and stayed until eight or nine in the evening TIME . But it was only the Fridays DATE that concerned him now. For on Fridays DATE , each Friday DATE evening TIME , she left work and walked up Connecticut Avenue FAC to Dupont Circle GPE , where she deposited her paycheck at American Security ORG . He would stand beside her on most Fridays DATE over those months DATE as she took forever to fill out the deposit slip, making first ORDINAL one CARDINAL mistake, then another, then dropping the crossed-out slips into the wastebasket beside the table. After she got on line, he would pick up every slip she had dropped. Then he would stand behind her until she had completed things with the teller.



It was a little before two CARDINAL when he got to the restaurant. The retarded woman and her friend soon came out to Connecticut GPE , heading for Lafayette Park FAC . Not quite two CARDINAL thirty, but close enough to the times of other days not to worry. As the women often did, they walked holding hands. They wore green uniforms and though they seemed to polish their white shoes every day, he had noticed that they were scuffed plenty by midday TIME . He knew their first ORDINAL and last names, he knew where the old woman lived, having followed her home one evening TIME , he knew the retarded woman’s favorite candy, he even knew the station the old woman had her radio tuned to.

“I can see me sometime holdin my own little baby,” the retarded woman said after they sat down on a bench facing the White House FAC , “rockin her and feedin her and doin such.” The sun was warm, and Caesar ORG sat on the grass Indian NORP -style a few feet QUANTITY behind the women. He opened a newspaper he had taken from a trash can, but he watched the tourists taking photographs and the government people eating their lunches.

“Thought everything would work with Fred PERSON and me,” the retarded woman said. “He like the job they got him. Me and him would sit on the stoop, makin plans bout our future.”

Caesar PERSON knew about her Fred NORP , but he had never learned if he was one of those loud talkers he had seen in the first weeks DATE at the bus stop.

“People call us the lovebirds,” the retarded woman said. “‘Look at em. Look at them lovebirds.’”

The old woman was eating orange pieces from a small plastic bag, and now and again, when the breeze shifted, the smell of oranges came to Caesar ORG . He watched a black family come up to a very old white man at the Lafayette PERSON statue. The father gave his camera to the white man and then stood in front of the statue beside his wife and behind his three CARDINAL children. The oldest boy closed his eyes and would not open them again until it was all done. The old man took the family’s picture, and when the mother raised one CARDINAL finger, the old man advanced the film and snapped again.

“Then he commence to change. He talk back to Miss Prentiss PERSON ,” the retarded woman was saying. “His job call Miss Prentiss PERSON and said he all the time late. Wouldn’t do what they told him.”

“ Anna PERSON , he musta told you what was the matter,” the old woman said.

“No, ma’am, Miss Elsie PERSON ,” the retarded woman said. “He never did. Yesday PERSON I got home, a car came with two CARDINAL men and they took him back to Laurel GPE .” Caesar PERSON watched as the father read what was on the side of the statue and then the father looked up at the man on the horse, shading his eyes. His little girl did the same.

The black family crossed Pennsylvania Avenue FAC , and the father gave the oldest boy the camera so he could take pictures of the White House FAC . Then they went down to the corner and joined the line going in.

Caesar PERSON was only half listening; there was no more that would help on Friday DATE . The problem would be Carol PERSON . He put the newspaper aside and lay down, closing his eyes. He would not follow them back to work. On another day not long ago DATE , he had waited for the retarded woman across the street in front of the copier business until she got off from work. He had followed her to the bus stop. She was overweight, and he saw that walking was not easy for her in the heat. For the first ORDINAL time since he had been following her, she was not wearing her uniform. She had on a blue skirt and a pink blouse, which she wore outside the skirt. She had on tiny, gold-plated earrings a person might not notice until he was within a foot or so of her, and that was how close he was when he walked past her. She smelled of garlic and, beneath that, of a soap that reminded him of the halls in the hospital where his mother had died.



It was a crime, Sherman PERSON had said, to fall asleep anywhere but in a safe place, and so he was up and off a few minutes TIME after the women left. He felt he wanted to see Sherman PERSON and left the park at the corner of Pennsylvania GPE and 16th ORDINAL , heading in the direction where he thought the museum was. In both his lives, he had never come down to the world below Constitution Avenue FAC , except for those times when relatives came from out of town. His mother and father would bring everyone down to see the Washington GPE they put on postcards and in the pages of expensive coffee-table books. He knew that his father worked in one CARDINAL of the government buildings, but he didn’t know which one. His father was the kind of man who, if he looked out his office window and saw his son, would come down the stairs three CARDINAL at a time and hold him until someone called the police. “Call the law! I have a thief who robbed me! Call the law!”

At 15th ORDINAL and Constitution LAW , among the tourists and office workers, he gave up the idea of seeing Sherman PERSON . It would be better to start working on Carol PERSON . He could see no problems with Anna PERSON , the retarded woman, but retarded or not, she was still a woman and there was a danger of her being skittish. He called Carol PERSON at work.

He told her that he loved her, then he told her that he missed her. In his mind, he read the words written on her notes.

“I’m glad you told me,” she said. “I was beginning to wonder. You made my day DATE .”

He promised to fix her dinner before he went to Manny PERSON ’s and he told her once again that he loved her.

“I wish I could record that,” she said, “and play it back any time I wanted.”

IV

When people found out that Angelo Billings PERSON , Caesar PERSON ’s cousin, had in fact stolen the flowers from an I Street florist and taken them to the funeral home, they said he would never again have good luck. Never mind, they said, that he loved Caesar ORG ’s mother as much as he loved anyone and that stealing the flowers was his way of showing that love. There were some things God would not tolerate, and stealing flowers for the dead was one CARDINAL of them.

Caesar PERSON , though, was moved, and they grew closer after his mother’s funeral. Angelo PERSON introduced him to Sherman PERSON . Angelo PERSON , before Caesar PERSON gave up on school, would wait for him outside Cardozo High WORK_OF_ART , and they would go to Sherman PERSON ’s two CARDINAL -bedroom apartment on 16th Street FAC , a few blocks up from Malcolm X Park FAC . What fascinated Caesar PERSON most about the apartment was the dominance of sound, of noise, as if Sherman PERSON were afraid of silence. In every room, there was something playing each second ORDINAL of the day DATE , whether a radio or television or cassette player. In the bathroom, hanging from the shower curtain rod, there was a transistor radio that played around the clock. Sherman PERSON lived alone in the apartment, but he had two CARDINAL children by Sandra PERSON , who lived elsewhere in the building with the children. Most of the time when Caesar PERSON and Angelo PERSON visited, they would find Sherman PERSON wrapped in his bathrobe sitting on the couch, listening to one CARDINAL of dozens CARDINAL of cassette tapes that Sandra PERSON had recorded of the children talking and playing with each other. There were four CARDINAL speakers in the living room that stood three feet QUANTITY high, and he enjoyed playing those cassettes so loud that the noise of the children made it sound like a playground with a hundred CARDINAL children. Now and again, one CARDINAL child would hit the other or say something mean and there would be a fit of crying on the tape. Sherman PERSON would jump up and speed the tape past the crying to a place where the talking and playing resumed.

The apartment, despite the noise, became another home for Caesar PERSON and he began going there without Angelo PERSON after school. Before long, he was leaving home at least two or three days DATE a week and going not to school but straight to Sherman PERSON ’s place, where he’d drop his books at the door beside the two-foot QUANTITY -high porcelain bulldog and make a place for himself in front of the television. In the beginning, he was able to get back home in the evening TIME before his father arrived from work. But as the months DATE wore away to winter DATE , to spring, he was getting home later and later.

One night TIME in April DATE , Sherman PERSON dropped him off about three CARDINAL in the morning, and Caesar ORG stood on the sidewalk for a long while looking up at his house. For the first ORDINAL time, all the lights in the house were off. When he opened the front door, his father was standing before him in the darkened hall.

“I’m just slaving away my life to raise up another Angelo PERSON ,” his father hissed, turning on the hall light. “A goddamn no-account.” As soon as his hand was off the light switch, he slapped Caesar PERSON , knocking him back against the front door. Before Caesar PERSON could recover, his father had grabbed him by the shirt with one hand, opened the door with the other, and threw him out on the sidewalk.

“I gave you more chances than you deserved,” his father said and closed the inner and outer doors to the house. Caesar PERSON , still sprawled on the ground, saw the hall light go out. Seconds later, he saw the light in the upstairs front bedroom, his father’s room, go on, and a moment later, that light went out.

He got to his feet and looked up and down French Street FAC . The new leaves rattled as if something were shaking the trees, and the sound unnerved him. He brushed off his clothes, not because of dirt or debris, but because right then he did not know what else to do. Under the street lamp, he looked at the watch Sherman PERSON had given him the week before DATE , and it occurred to him that he had never before been awake at that hour in the morning TIME . A cool wind sauntered up the street and chilled him, unnerving him even more, and he suppressed the urge to cry.

He considered pounding on the door, calling his father as loudly as he could and then running away. But he stood quiet. For all of his life, he had been Lemuel Matthews PERSON ’s son, and even now, standing in the dark outside the walls of his father’s house, he was still his son and he knew he could not be a bad boy at such a place at such a time in the morning.

He saw the brighter lights at the half CARDINAL smoke joint at the 9th Street FAC corner and he went toward those lights. The place was closed, but he used the outdoor telephone to call Sherman PERSON . Sandra PERSON answered, and after he had told her what happened, she told him to stay put, that Sherman PERSON would be back down to pick him up. While he waited, he called his father’s house several times, stepping out of the telephone booth with the receiver as he listened to the ringing. He looked up tree-lined French Street FAC , but there was not enough light to distinguish his house from all the others.



It was true what people said about Angelo PERSON ’s bad luck. He robbed the Riggs Bank ORG on 15th Street in early May DATE , using a gun he had rented for twenty-five dollars MONEY a day and a Safeway FAC shopping bag. He was so curious about how much he had gotten away with that as he ran down M Street, he looked in the shopping bag, and at that moment the money, booby-trapped with a red dye packet, exploded in his face. He dropped the bag, cursing the bank teller, but he continued running, trying for the next several blocks to wipe the dye from his face and hands with the shirt he had taken off.

Sherman PERSON had thought that Angelo PERSON , eager, cocksure, had potential as a partner, but soon after the government people put Angelo PERSON away, he began to consider Caesar PERSON , who was now staying with him. Caesar PERSON knew Sherman PERSON didn’t have a real job, but he didn’t learn until he had been with him two months DATE what he did for a living. He was not particularly surprised or disappointed. Caesar PERSON was seventeen DATE , and for the first ORDINAL time in his life, he was living his days without the cocoon of family, and beyond that cocoon, he was learning, anything was possible.

“The first ORDINAL thing we do,” Sherman PERSON said one day DATE , “is get all your shit from your daddy’s place. You gotta have an identity. Get you out in the world so you can stop all that mopin.”

The next morning they drove down to the house on French Street FAC and waited in the car until Caesar ORG was certain his father had left for work and his brother and sister had gone to school. Caesar PERSON opened the front door with his key. He was surprised his father had not changed the lock, but Sherman PERSON was not surprised. “What’s there to be afraid of from his own little boy?” Sherman PERSON said. Caesar ORG stepped into the hall. Had his father suddenly appeared before him, it would have seemed the most natural thing. Indeed, he expected him, and when he stepped into the living room, he expected his father to be there as well. Sherman PERSON , silent, followed as Caesar PERSON went through the rooms on the first ORDINAL floor. Caesar touched nearly everything along the way—a lace piece made by his grandmother that was on the back of the easy chair in the living room; a drawing of the house ORG signed and dated by his sister taped to the refrigerator; the kitchen curtains he had helped his mother put up. In a corner of the kitchen counter he found wrapped in a rubber band the letters he had been sending to his father; only the first ORDINAL one had been opened.

“Let’s get your stuff,” Sherman PERSON said after a bit. “Enough of this.”

They went upstairs, and in the closet of his father’s bedroom, Sherman PERSON found a small metal box, broke its tiny lock with his hand, and leisurely went through the papers in the box, putting aside Caesar ORG ’s birth certificate and the Social Security ORG card he had gotten the year before DATE in hopes of finding an after-school job. Caesar PERSON watched.

“You want your mom’s death certificate?” Sherman PERSON said, reaching the end of the papers in the box.

“No.” He turned away and went to his sister’s room, where he touched the heads of the three CARDINAL stuffed animals sitting on the pillows of her bed. In the room he had shared with his brother, he took as many of his clothes as he could carry, his hands shaking each time he picked up an item.

In the hall, Sherman PERSON was waiting at the head of the stairs. He took some of the clothes from Caesar PERSON . “He had a little money in the box, some cash and some gold pieces,” Sherman PERSON said. “And I found a stack of pictures in a drawer. I got a few of em, mostly some with you in em. Must be your mother, too. I got a lot of em. You might want em later on when you start to forget.”

Caesar PERSON nodded. In a few minutes TIME they were on 11th Street FAC , heading back uptown. He knew what his father would look like when he realized he had been robbed: the fist pounding the air, that pulsating vein at the left side of his head. For months and months DATE after that, he could conjure up the image whenever he wanted and replay it. That night TIME , they went to Manny PERSON ’s and Carol PERSON said what she said about dancing with her not ending that way, about trying her and seeing. She took him home that night TIME , and when he woke up the next morning TIME , she was lying on her side watching him. She leaned over and kissed his forehead. “It’s all right,” she said, “I already went and brushed my teeth.” Aside from the ones in Sherman GPE ’s magazines, she was the first ORDINAL naked woman he had ever seen. She kissed his ear. “There’s a toothbrush in there with your name on it,” she said. “And I bet I spelled your name right.”



Two weeks DATE after Caesar ORG and Sherman PERSON went into Caesar ORG ’s father’s house, Sherman PERSON took him out for the first ORDINAL time, to burglarize a home in Chevy Chase ORG . Sherman PERSON peed on the sofa in the recreation room, having taken a quick dislike to a large painting behind the sofa of a man in a tennis outfit whom he took to be the owner. The next night TIME , in a light rain, they followed a light-skinned, well-dressed fellow from a bar on Capitol Hill ORG to his car parked a block away. The man had tottered the whole distance, not bothering to open the umbrella he was carrying. “Not a sound,” Caesar ORG said, placing the pistol at the man’s head just as he stuck his key in the car door. “Not a sound. No words. Not one CARDINAL word.” Sherman PERSON went through the man’s pockets, took his wallet and then his watch. “Please, please,” the man kept saying, his arms extended high into the air. The man was balding and the hair he had left was combed perfectly to either side of a bald path that went back to the middle of his head. With the light of the street lamps, the robbers could see the beads of rain on the bald path and on his eyeglasses. “Next time,” Caesar PERSON said as they stepped away from the man, “buy your shit in a liquor store and take it home to drink.”

V

On the way home from following Anna PERSON that last time, Caesar ORG bought white carnations for Carol PERSON and the ingredients for a shrimp creole dinner. He had dinner prepared when she came home, and after they had eaten, with her head swirling just a bit from the wine, he made love to her because he did not know what kind of mood he would be in when he returned from Manny PERSON ’s that night TIME .

Later, as he told her about the retarded woman, he rested his hand on her bare stomach. He could feel her tensing up with each word. He massaged her stomach, then he took her belly button between two CARDINAL fingers and rubbed it gently.

“Don’t ask me to do any of that,” she said. “Don’t bring me into any of that.” As long as she believed it did not involve another woman, she had never wanted to know what he and Sherman PERSON did. But now she felt all of the not-wanting-to-know had come due and she pulled the sheet up to her neck against the cold.

“There’s nothin to it,” Caesar PERSON said. “In an out. Before you know it, we’ll be back home, Carol PERSON . I promise.”

“Stop. I’m not like you. I don’t want to hurt anybody.”

“It’s just the money,” he said, getting up. He began to dress.

“Don’t go just yet,” she said. She was naked and she got out of bed and put her arms around him. The cold came in the window and she shivered.

“I don’t ask a whole fuckin lot of you,” he said, “and when I do, you act like this.” He left the room and she called to him as she put on her robe. He was out of the apartment before she got in the living room. He took the stairs two CARDINAL at a time, and she continued calling him as she leaned over the banister.



That was Monday DATE . He did not go back home all that week DATE . Manny PERSON told him on Friday DATE that he was tired of Carol PERSON calling the bar. “Talk to her,” Manny PERSON said. “Do something to shut that pussy up.”

“Come home,” Carol PERSON said when he finally called her Saturday DATE afternoon TIME . “Come home.”

“You forgot what I asked you to do?” he said.

“No, I didn’t forget,” she said. “Come home.”

“Then what do you have ta say bout what I asked?”

She said, “Yes. Yes. C, I can’t hurt anybody. I just can’t.”

“Who said anything about somebody gettin hurt? Nobody’ll get hurt. I already told you.”

“Come home,” she said.



The final days of that October DATE were pleasant, but as the sun set, it grew cooler. There had been rain a few evenings, and when there was no rain, a wind came up that chilled as much as the rain. Caesar PERSON wore the tan Burberry Carol PERSON had bought for him. And as he sat in Dupont Circle Park FAC watching Carol PERSON standing before American Security ORG , there was still enough sunlight left for him to see Anna PERSON , a block or so away, make her way with the crowd up Connecticut Avenue FAC .

Carol PERSON did not look over at him, and as she paced, she would occasionally pull from her purse the picture of a boy about three years old DATE , study it as if trying to memorize the boy’s features, and then return the picture to her purse. Caesar ORG had taken it from Manny PERSON ’s wall of Polaroids ORG , but no one at the bar, not even Manny PERSON , could remember who the child was. Carol PERSON , however, believed that Caesar PERSON knew the boy, and when Caesar PERSON laughed, she had flung the picture at him. It had taken him most of the rest of Thursday DATE evening TIME to calm her, convince her that, as his father would have said, he didn’t know the boy from Adam GPE .

Still, he could tell from the way she looked at the photograph that everything he had said and done that Thursday DATE was wearing off. Carol PERSON finally looked over at him. When Anna PERSON was but several yards QUANTITY from her, Caesar PERSON pointed at Anna PERSON and Carol PERSON walked to her. She took Anna PERSON by the arm and gently pulled her from the flow of the crowd. “Always say nice, soothin things,” he had told Carol PERSON . “Talk to her like you were longtime sisters or somethin.”

The lights in the park and along the streets came on. Anna PERSON ’s back was to him, but he could see Carol PERSON ’s face. She appeared calm and this surprised him. “The makins of a pro,” Sherman PERSON would have said. The boy in the picture, dressed in green swimming trunks with his back to some ocean, could well be a grown man by now, or he could be in his grave, Caesar PERSON thought, but today DATE , on that street, his mother was saying he needed five thousand dollars MONEY for an operation or he would die as sure as anything. “Always make it seem like the choice is hers—whether he lives or whether he dies.” Anna PERSON took the picture and she looked at it, holding it but a few inches QUANTITY from her face.

Just the way Anna PERSON was standing told him that of the million CARDINAL things in the world she could do, she would do the one thing he wanted. And knowing this made up for not being with Sherman PERSON . It made up for that old woman who had cut his hand two weeks DATE before when he ran by and tried to grab her money from her coat pocket.

Anna PERSON gave back the picture. Satisfied, he took his eyes from the women and watched the passersby heading home. Somewhere, Sherman PERSON was about to do the same. He could see Sherman PERSON closing a giant museum door so people could not see his roomful of paintings. “No more. No more for the day DATE .” It did not hurt as much to think of him now. He looked back at the women in time to see them enter the bank.

When they came out, they crossed the street, and Caesar ORG thought it a nice touch that Carol PERSON took Anna PERSON by the arm as they crossed. Anna PERSON sat on a bench across from Peoples ORG , and for a minute TIME or so more, Carol PERSON talked to her. Anna PERSON nodded. Everything now should be the closeout, he thought, and he felt she was taking too long. He waited until Carol PERSON walked by him and crossed the street, heading down Massachusetts Avenue FAC . When he caught up with her, he took her by the elbow and she pulled away.

“You did good,” he said, putting his arm around her. “You did real good. How much did you get?”

“ Can’t you wait WORK_OF_ART ?” she said. “ Can’t you even wait WORK_OF_ART !” They crossed 18th Street FAC . “Do we have to go into all this out here like this?”

“It’s all right, Carol PERSON ,” he said. “She back there. Nothin can happen now.” Midway down the block, he reached for her purse, but again she pulled away from him.

“Stop! Jesus PERSON !” She quickened her pace.

He stopped momentarily. “What’s wrong with you?”

At Massachusetts GPE and 17th, he managed to lead her into the tiny park. The place was empty except for a bum who was sleeping on a bench several yards QUANTITY away from them. “What the fuck’s wrong with you?” He took the purse.

“Don’t!” she said, taking it back. “For God sakes, don’t!”

He slapped her and grabbed for the bag with the other hand. It opened and everything inside fell out. Seeing the money fall to the ground, he slapped her again, and she began to cry. Her nose bled, and her bottom lip was split in two CARDINAL places, and it bled as well. The bum ORG had awakened, and seeing the woman get slapped, he asked, “What is it there with you two CARDINAL peoples?”

Caesar ORG dropped the purse, and Carol PERSON knelt down and began putting things back in it. He pulled her to her feet. “What the hell’s wrong with you?”

“Leave me alone. Just leave me alone.”

She knelt and he pulled her up again. “I said leave me alone.” He slapped her. He could now see the distance between them growing, and seeing that distance and knowing he no longer had the power to close it, he slapped her once more. The blow sent her back a few feet QUANTITY . She said ohh several times, but everything sounded to him like no. She put her hand to her face and trembled.

“Hey there, fella,” the bum ORG said. “We gentlemens don’t—”

“You want me to come over there and kick your ass?”

The bum ORG was silent. He knew these young lions. He eased himself off the bench and rolled under it. Better to face the rats and the filth than face a young lion in his wrath.

“ Carol PRODUCT , get the stuff and let’s go home.”

She watched him. Stepping up to her, he took out the Beretta PRODUCT and held it to her cheek. “Did you hear what I said?” There was no surprise in her face, and there was no fear. He realized that if he beat her with the pistol, that, too, would not surprise her. And had he shot her, in the face or through the heart, she would not have been surprised at that either. He pocketed the gun and stepped back.

She walked around him and was crying softly as she gathered up the money and her belongings. It had begun to rain and she shook each thing before putting it in the bag. When she was done, she stood and looked at him. Then, as if there was all the time in the world, she walked slowly out of the park, heading down Massachusetts GPE . He watched her until she disappeared among the lights of Dupont Circle GPE , and then he turned away.

There was something in the air, but he could not make out what it was. He walked out of the park. He kept looking behind him, expecting something or someone, but he was alone on the street and he saw nothing but the swirling of dead leaves. He continued looking behind him as he made his way up 17th Street FAC . He took out the address book, but found he could not read the names or the numbers under the feeble street lights. He hurried, hoping for a telephone booth where the light would be brighter. He began to run, and as he ran, he kept trying to read the names and numbers, but the rain was now turning them to blurs. He did not know what was in the air. He only knew that tonight TIME would not be a night TIME to be without shelter.





THE STORE




I’d been out of work three CARDINAL four months DATE when I saw her ad in the Daily News ORG ; a few lines of nothing special, almost as if she really didn’t want a response. On a different day DATE in my life I suppose I would have passed right over it. I had managed to squirrel away a little bit of money from the first ORDINAL slave I had, and after that change ran out, I just bummed from friends for smokes, beer, the valuables. I lived with my mother, so rent and food weren’t a problem, though my brother, when he came around with that family of his, liked to get in my shit and tell me I should be looking for another job. Usually, my mother was okay, but I could tell when my brother and his flat-butt wife had been around when I wasn’t there, because for days DATE after that my mother would talk that same shit about me getting a job, like I’d never slaved a day before in my life.

That first ORDINAL slave I had had just disappeared out from under me, despite my father always saying that the white people who gave me that job were the best white people he’d known in his life. My father never had a good word to say about anybody white, and I believed him when he said I could go far in that place. I started working there— the Atlas Printing Co. ORG (“ 75 YEARS DATE IN THE SAME LOCATION”)—right after I graduated from Dunbar GPE , working in the mailroom and sometimes helping out the printers when the mail work was slow. My father had been a janitor there until he got his third ORDINAL heart attack, the one that would put him in the ground when I was in my sophomore year DATE at Dunbar GPE .

At twenty CARDINAL I was still in the mailroom: assistant chief mail clerk or something like that, still watching the white boys come in, work beside me, then move on. My mother always said that every bullfrog praises his own poem, but I know for a natural fact that I was an excellent worker. Never late, never talked back, always volunteering; the product of good colored parents. Still…In the end, one CARDINAL bitching cold day DATE in January DATE , the owner and his silly-ass wife, who seemed to be the brains of the outfit, came to me and said they could no longer afford to keep me on. Times were bad, said the old man, who was so bald you could read his thoughts. They made it sound like I was the highest-paid worker in the joint, when actually I was making so little the white guys used to joke about it.

I said nothing, just got my coat and took my last check and went home. Somewhere along K Street FAC , I remembered I’d left some of my personal stuff back there—some rubbers I’d bought just that morning TIME at Peoples ORG , a picture of the girl I was going with at the time, a picture of my father, my brother, and me at four years old DATE on one of our first fishing trips. I had the urge to go back—the girl was already beginning not to mean anything to me anymore, so I didn’t care about her picture, but the fishing trip picture was special. But I didn’t turn back because, first ORDINAL of all, my balls were beginning to freeze.

My father always said that when the world pisses on you, it then spits on you to finish the job. At New York Avenue FAC and 5th ORDINAL I crossed on the red light. A white cop twirling his billy club saw me and came to spit on me to finish up what Atlas PERSON had done: He asked me if I didn’t know it was against D.C. GPE and federal law to cross on the red light.
