I was only a few blocks from home and maybe heat and thawing out my nuts were the only things on my mind, because I tried to be funny and told him the joke my father had always told—that I thought the green light was for white folks and the red light was for colored people. His face reddened big-time.

When my brother and I were in our early teens, my mother said this to us with the most seriousness she had ever said anything: “Never even if you become kings of the whole world, I don’t want yall messin with a white cop.” The worst that my mother feared didn’t happen to her baby boy that day DATE . The cop only made me cross back on the green light and go all the way back to 7th Street FAC , then come back to 5th Street FAC and cross again on the green light. Then go back to 7th ORDINAL to do it all over again. Then I had to do it twice more. I was frozen through and through when I got back to 5th ORDINAL the second ORDINAL time and as I waited for the light to change after the fourth ORDINAL time and he stood just behind me I became very afraid, afraid that doing all that would not be enough for him, that he would want me to do more and then even more after that and that in the end I would be shot or simply freeze to death across the street from the No. 2 CARDINAL police precinct. Had he told me to deny my mother and father, I think I would have done that too.

I got across the street and went on my way, waiting for him to call me back. I prayed, “Just get me back to one CARDINAL fifteen CARDINAL New York Avenue FAC safely and I’ll never come to their world again…. Just get me back to one CARDINAL fifteen CARDINAL New York Avenue FAC safely….” For days DATE after that I just hung out at home. My mother believed that a day DATE had the best foundation if you had breakfast, so after she fixed our breakfast, and went off to work, I went back to bed and slept to about noon TIME .

When I got some heart back, I started venturing out again, but I kept to my own neighborhood, my own world. Either my ace-boon, Lonney McCrae PERSON , would come get me or I would go looking for him and we’d spend the rest of the afternoon TIME together until our friends got off work. Then all of us would go off and fuck with the world most of the night.



Lonney PERSON was going to Howard PERSON , taking a course here and there, doing just enough to satisfy his father. I’d seen his old man maybe once or twice in all the time I knew Lonney PERSON , and I’d been knowing him since kindergarten. His father had been one of the few big-shot Negro ORG army officers in the Korea war GPE , and Lonney PERSON was always saying that after the war his father would be home for good. He was still saying it that January DATE when Kennedy PERSON was inaugurated.

Lonney PERSON liked to fuck bareback and that was how he got Brenda Roper PERSON pregnant. I think he liked her, maybe not as much as she liked him, but just enough so it wasn’t a total sacrifice to marry her. I was to be his best man. One night TIME , all of us—me and Lonney PERSON and his mother and Brenda PERSON and her parents—were sitting around his living room, talking about the wedding and everything. Someone knocked on the door and Lonney PERSON opened it. It was his old man, standing there tall and straight as a lamppost in his uniform. You know something’s wrong when a man doesn’t even have a key to his own house.

The soldier didn’t say Hello or Good to see you, son. He just stood in the doorway and said—and I know he could see everybody else in the room—“You don’t have anything better to do with your time than marrying this girl?” Lonney PERSON ’s mother stood up, in that eager, happy way women do when they want to greet their husbands home from a foreign land. Brenda PERSON ’s father stood up too, but he had this goofy look on his face like he wanted to greet his soon-to-be in-law. “I asked you something,” Lonney PERSON ’s father said. Lonney PERSON said nothing, and his father walked by him, nodded at Mrs. McCrae PERSON , and went on upstairs with his suitcase. The next morning TIME he was gone again.

Lonney PERSON married Brenda PERSON that March DATE , a few weeks DATE before I saw the ad in the Daily News ORG . I think that he wanted to make things work with Brenda PERSON , if only to push the whole thing in his father’s face, but the foundation, as my mother would have said, was built on shifting sand. In about a year or so DATE he had separated from her, though he continued to be a good father to the child, a chubby little girl they named after his mother. And some two years DATE after he married, he had joined the army ORG and before long he himself was in a foreign land, though it was a different one from where his father was.

The day DATE before I saw the ad I spent the evening TIME at Lonney PERSON and Brenda PERSON ’s place. They fought, maybe not for the first ORDINAL time as newlyweds, but for the first ORDINAL time in front of me. I felt as if I were watching my own folks arguing, as if the world I knew and depended on was now coming apart. I slept till one CARDINAL the next day DATE , then went down to Mojo’s near North Capitol GPE and Florida Avenue FAC and hung out there for most of the day DATE . Late in the day DATE , someone left a Daily News at a table and over my second ORDINAL beer, with nothing better to do, I read the want ads. Her ad said:

STORE HELPER. Good pay. Good hours.

Good Opportunity for Advancement.



Then she had the store’s location—5th and O streets Northwest ORG . The next morning TIME I forced myself to stay awake after my mother had left, then went off about eight o’clock TIME to see what the place was about. I didn’t want any part of a white boss and I stood outside the store, trying to see just who ran the place. Through the big windows I could see a colored woman of fifty CARDINAL or so in an apron, and she seemed to be working alone. Kids who attended Bundy Elementary School ORG down the street went in and out of the store buying little treats. I walked around the block until about nine CARDINAL , then went in. A little bell over the door tinkled and the first thing I smelled was coal oil from the small pump just inside the door. The woman was now sitting on a tall stool behind the counter, reading the Post ORG , which she had spread out over the glass counter.

She must have known I was there, but even after I was halfway to her, she just wet a finger and turned the page. I was inches from the counter, when she looked up. “Somethin you want?” she said. Oh shit, I thought, she’s one of those bitches. I could feel my balls trying to retreat back up into my body.

“I come about the job in the paper,” I said.

“Well, you pass the first ORDINAL test: At least you know how to read. What else you know how to do? You ever work in a store before? A grocery store like this?”

I gave her my work history, such as it was, and all the while she looked like she wanted to be someplace else. She kept reading and turning those pages. She seemed skeptical that the printing company had let me go without just cause.

“What you been doin since you lost that job?” she said.

“ Lookin WORK_OF_ART . I just never found anything I liked.”

That was not the right answer, I could see that right away, but by then I didn’t care. I was ready to start mouthing off like somebody was paying me to do it.

“The job pays thirty a week DATE ,” she said finally. “The work is from eight CARDINAL in the mornin till eight CARDINAL in the evenin. Every day but Sunday DATE and maybe a holiday here and there. Depends. You got questions?” But she didn’t wait for me to ask, she just went on blubbering. “I’ll be interviewin everybody else and then make my decision. Affix your name and phone number and if you’re crowned queen of the ball, I’ll let you know, sweetie.” She tossed a pencil across the counter and pointed to the top of a newspaper page where she wanted me to put my telephone number. I wrote down my name and number, and just before I opened the door to leave, I heard her turn the next page.



The next day DATE was Tuesday DATE , and I spent most of that morning TIME and the next few mornings TIME cleaning up what passed for the backyard of Al’s and Penny’s Groceries. I had been surprised when she called me Monday DATE night TIME , too surprised to even tell her to go to hell. Then, after she hung up, I figured I just wouldn’t show up, but on Tuesday morning TIME , way long before dawn TIME , I woke up and couldn’t get back to sleep. And so for a change I was up when my mother rose and I fixed our breakfast. She did days DATE work for some white people in Chevy ORG Chase PRODUCT , and that morning I noticed how fast she ate, “wolfing down” her food, she would have called it.

For the first ORDINAL time in a long while, I stood at the window and watched her skinny legs take her down New York Avenue FAC to hop the first ORDINAL of two CARDINAL D.C. Transits ORG that would take her to Chevy ORG Chase PRODUCT . Maybe it was watching her that sent me off that morning to the store. Or maybe it was that I came back to the table and saw that she hadn’t finished all of her coffee. My mother would have sold me back into slavery for a good cup of coffee, and no one made it to her satisfaction the way she did.

“ Good WORK_OF_ART ,” the store owner said to me after she parked her lavender Cadillac ORG and was opening the store’s door. “You passed the second ORDINAL test: You know how to show up on time.” It was about 7:30 TIME and I’d been waiting about fifteen minutes TIME .

She took me straight to the backyard, through the store itself, through a smaller room that served mostly as a storage area, to the back door, which took a hell of an effort for us to open. In the yard, two CARDINAL squirrels with something in their hands stood on their hind legs, watching us. No one had probably been in the yard for a coon GPE ’s age and the squirrels stood there for the longest time, perhaps surprised to see human beings. When they realized we were for real, they scurried up the apple tree in a corner of the yard. The store owner brought out a rake, shovel, wheelbarrow, everything I needed to do to the yard what no one had done for years DATE . I hadn’t worn any good clothes and I was glad of that. Right off I took my tools and went to the far end of the yard to begin.

“By the way,” she said, standing in the back door, “my name’s Penelope Jenkins WORK_OF_ART . Most people call me Penny PERSON . But the help call me Mrs. Jenkins PERSON , and you, buddy boy, you the help.”

Beyond the high fence surrounding the yard there were the sounds of schoolchildren getting into their day DATE . Well into the second hour TIME of work, after I knew I was getting dirty and smelly as hell, after the children were all in school, I started throwing stones at the damn squirrels, who, jumping back and forth from tree to fence, seemed to be taunting me. Just like on the cold evening TIME of the green light, I began to feel that I would be doing that shit forever.

The first ORDINAL thick layer of crap in the yard was slimy dead leaves from the autumn before, maybe even years DATE before, and the more I disturbed the leaves the more insects and slugs crawled out from the home they had created and made a run for it under the fence and to other parts of the yard. The more spiteful and stupid bugs crawled up my pants legs. Beneath the layer of leaves there was a good amount of soda bottles, candy wrappers PERSON , the kind of shit kids might have thrown over the fence. But I didn’t get to that second ORDINAL layer until Thursday morning TIME , because the yard was quite large, big enough for little kids to play a decent game of kickball. Sometimes, when I heard voices on the other side of the fence, I would pull myself up to the top and look over.

My father always told the story of working one week DATE for an undertaker in Columbia GPE , South Carolina GPE , one CARDINAL of his first ORDINAL jobs. He didn’t like the undertaker and he knew the undertaker didn’t like him. But, and maybe he got this from his old man, my father figured that he would give the undertaker the best goddamn week of work a fourteen-year-old DATE was capable of. And that’s what he did—for seven days DATE he worked as if that business was his own. Then he collected his pay and never went back. The undertaker came by late one evening TIME and at first ORDINAL , thinking my father wasn’t showing up because he was just lazy, the undertaker acted big and bad. Then, after my father told him he wouldn’t be coming back, the undertaker promised a raise, even praised my father’s work, but my father had already been two days DATE at a sawmill.

I didn’t think Mrs. Jenkins PERSON was the kind of woman who would beg me to come back, but I did like imagining her sitting on her high stool, reading her damn paper and thinking of what a good worker she had lost. That was the image I took home each evening TIME that week DATE , so sore and depressed I could not think of fucking the world or anybody else. My mother would fix me dinner and I would sit hunched down in my chair close to the food because I had little strength left to make the long distance from the plate to my mouth if I sat up straight. Then, before I could fall asleep in the chair, my mother would run water for me to take a bath, the same thing I had seen her do for my father so often when I was a child that I didn’t notice it anymore.

In the late mornings that week DATE , after she thought I had done enough in the yard, Mrs. Jenkins PERSON would have me sweep the area around the front of the store or provide some order to the merchandise in the storage room. On Tuesday DATE she wanted the boxes of stuff arranged just so, but then, as if she had some revelation during the night TIME , she wanted everything rearranged on Wednesday DATE . Then on Thursday DATE I had to do things different again, and then different still again on Friday DATE . And because she claimed she planned to repaint, she also had me up on a ladder, scraping away the peeling orange paint of the store’s exterior. The paint chips would fly off into my eyes and hair, and it took me until Thursday DATE to get smart about wearing a stocking cap and the goggles my father had once used.

Saturday DATE morning TIME I woke up happy. Again, I was there waiting for her to open up and again I did all the shit work while she chatted and made nice-nice with all the customers. I had already planned my weekend DATE , had, in my mind, spent every dollar I was to be paid. But I was also prepared to get cheated. Cheating folks was like some kind of religion with people like Mrs. Jenkins PERSON —they figured that if they didn’t practice it they’d go to hell. Actually, I was kind of hoping she would cheat me, just so I could come back late that night TIME and break all the fucking windows or something.

At the end of the day DATE , after she had locked the front door to any more customers and pulled down the door’s shade with the little CLOSED sign on it, she opened the cash register and counted out my money. It came to about twenty-five dollars after she took out for taxes and everything. She explained where every dollar I wasn’t getting was going, then she gave me a slip with that same information on it.

“You did a good job,” she said. “You surprised me, and no one in the world surprises me anymore.”

The words weren’t much and I had heard better in my time, but as I stood there deliberately counting every dollar a second ORDINAL and third ORDINAL time, I found I enjoyed hearing them, and it came to me why some girls will give their pussys to guys who give them lines full of baby this and baby that and I’ll do this and I’ll be that forever and ever until the end of time….

I just said yeah and good night TIME and thanks, because my mother had always taught me and my brother that the currency of manners didn’t cost anything. Mrs. Jenkins PERSON had untied her apron, but she still had it on and it hung loosely from her neck. She followed me to the door and unlocked it. “I’ll see you bright and early Monday DATE mornin,” she said, like that was the only certainty left in my whole damn life. I said yeah and went out. I didn’t look back.

Despite my aches, I went dancing with Mabel Smith PERSON , a girl I had gone to Dunbar GPE with. We stepped out with Lonney PERSON and Brenda PERSON . I didn’t get any trim that night, and it didn’t bother me, because there was something satisfying in just dancing. I danced just about every dance, and when Mabel PERSON said she was tired, couldn’t take it anymore, I took Brenda PERSON out on the dance floor, and when I had worn her out, I danced away what was left of the night TIME with girls at other tables.

I got home about six that Sunday morning TIME . In the dark apartment, I could see that slice of light along the bottom of my mother’s closed door.



I didn’t go back to the store on Monday DATE . In fact, I slept late and spent the rest of the day DATE running the streets. Tuesday DATE , I couldn’t get back to sleep after my old lady left, and about ten CARDINAL I wandered over to the store, then wandered in. She didn’t act mad and she sure didn’t act like she was glad to see me. She just put me to work like the week before DATE had been a rehearsal for the real thing. And she enjoyed every bad thing that happened to me. Tuesday DATE I restocked the cereal section of shelves behind the counter with the cash register. As I bent down to dust the bottom shelves, a box of oatmeal fell on my head from three or four CARDINAL shelves up. Hit me so hard I’m sure some of my descendants will be born dumb because of it. Mrs. Jenkins PERSON went into a laugh that went on and on for minutes TIME , and throughout the rest of the day DATE she’d come up behind me and shout “Oatmeal!” and go into that laugh again.

“In the grocery business,” she said after I replaced the box, “the first ORDINAL law of supply in them shelves is to supply em so that nothin falls over.”

And late that Friday DATE afternoon TIME , as I was checking the coal oil pump to see how much was in it, a customer rushed in and the door pushed me against the pump, soiling a good shirt with oily dirt and dust. None of Mrs. Jenkins PERSON ’s aprons fit me and she had said she was ordering one for me. “Sorry, sport,” the customer said.

“The first ORDINAL law of customer relations,” Mrs. Jenkins PERSON said after the guy was gone, “is to provide your customers with proper egress to and from your product.” Such bullshit would have been enough in itself, but then, for the rest of that day DATE , she’d look at me and ask, “ What am I thinkin WORK_OF_ART ?” And before I could say anything, she would say, “Wrong! Wrong! I’m thinkin oil.” Then the laugh again.



That was how it was for months DATE and months DATE . But each Monday DATE morning TIME , like a whipped dog that stayed because he didn’t know any other master but the one that whipped him, I was at the store’s front door, waiting for her to open up. And a thousand CARDINAL times during the week DATE I promised myself I would give her a week DATE of work that only my father could surpass and then, come Saturday DATE night TIME , get my pay and tell her to kiss my ass. But always there was something during the week DATE to bring me back on Monday DATE —she allowed me, for example, to wait on customers (but didn’t allow me to open the cash register and make change); and I got two CARDINAL new aprons with my name stitched in script over the left pocket; and I got a raise of one dollar MONEY more a week after I had been there six months DATE ; and eventually she allowed me to decide how much of what things we had to reorder. Often, at home in the evening, I would go over the day DATE and rate it according to how many times Mrs. Jenkins PERSON had laughed at me, and it became a challenge to get through the next day DATE and do things as perfectly as possible. By the time I got my raise I felt comfortable enough to push that laugh back in her face whenever she slipped up on something. I’d say, “The first ORDINAL law of bein a grocery store boss is to be perfect.”

Then, too, I found that there was something irresistible to girls about a man in an apron with his name stitched on it. I had to suffer with a lot of giggly little girls from Bundy ORG , who would hang around the store just to look at me, but there were also enough high school and older girls to make working there worth my while. Before my first year DATE was out, I was borrowing from next week DATE ’s pay to finance the good life of the current week DATE .

The first ORDINAL time I waited on Kentucky GPE Connors was just after Lonney PERSON separated from Brenda GPE and went back to a room in his father’s house. Mrs. Jenkins PERSON didn’t tolerate the type of friendliness with customers that led to what she called “exploiratation,” so when I wanted a date with someone who came into the store, I’d arrange to set up things after I got off. The night TIME Kentucky GPE came in that first ORDINAL time, I purposely failed to put her pack of gum in the bag and ran after her.

“Why, of all the men on this earth,” she said after I caught up with her and boldly told her to clear her calendar for that Saturday DATE night TIME , “would I think of going out with someone like you?” You can tell when girls are just being coy and want you to lay it on just a little thicker before they say yes. But there are others who have no facade, who are not seeking to be wooed, who give out smiles like each time they do it takes them a mile farther from heaven. And after they speak you’re a year older and a foot shorter. That was Kentucky GPE .

She actually stood there for several long seconds TIME as if waiting for me to give her some kind of fucking resume. Then she said, “I thought so,” and walked away. A thousand CARDINAL and one CARDINAL comebacks came much later, when I was trying to go to sleep.

You do manage to go on with your life. Over the next weeks DATE and months DATE , I had to put up with her coming in a few times a week, but for her there seemed to be no memory of me asking her out and she acted as though I was no more or less than the fellow who took her money and bagged her groceries. But her you’re welcome in response to my thanking her for her purchases contained no sense of triumph, of superiority, as I would have expected. I learned in bits and pieces over time that she lived in an apartment on Neal Place a few doors from 5th Street FAC , was a year out of Dunbar GPE , was a secretary with the government people, that her family lived in a house on N Street FAC that her mother’s parents had bought….



About a fifth of Mrs. Jenkins PERSON ’s customers bought things on credit and each purchase was carefully noted. On a chain beside the cash register she kept an elongated accounting book for nonmeat credit purchases. The meat case, with its small array of dressed chickens and parts, wrapped hamburger and stew beef, rolls of lunch meats, pork chops, etc., was catty-corner to the counter with the register. The meats had their own credit book, and perhaps no one—except maybe Mrs. Gertrude Baxter PERSON —had a longer bill than the Turner PERSON family. I rarely ever saw the father of the two CARDINAL Turner ORG children and I came to know that he worked as a night watchman. The mother seemed to live and die for her stories on television, and I rarely saw her either. The boy and girl were in and out all the time.

“My mama said gimme a small box of soap powder,” one CARDINAL of them would say. “Gimme” meant the mother wanted it on credit. “My mama said give her a pound of baloney and a loaf a Wonda Bread PERSON .” “My mama said give her two CARDINAL cans a spaghetti. The kind with the meatballs, not the other kind. She said you gave me the wrong kind the last time.” If you got a please with any of that, it was usually from the little girl, who was about seven CARDINAL or so. Mrs. Jenkins PERSON had a nice way with every customer as long as they didn’t fuck with her, but the Turner ORG girl seemed to have a special place in her heart. Which is why, despite what Mrs. Baxter PERSON went about telling the whole world, I know that Penny Jenkins PERSON would have done anything to avoid killing the Turner ORG girl.

The ten-year-old DATE Turner ORG boy, however, was an apprentice thug. He never missed a chance to try me, and he was particularly fond of shaking the door just to hear that tinkling bell. He never messed with Mrs. Jenkins PERSON , of course, but he seemed to think God had put me on the earth LOC just for his amusement. He also liked to stand at the cooler with the sodas and move his hand about, knocking the bottles over and getting water on the floor. Whenever I told him to get a soda and get out of the box, he would whine, “But I want a reeaal cold one….” He would persist at the box and I usually had to come and pull his arm out, and he’d back away to the door.

He’d poke his tongue out at me and, no matter how many old church ladies were in the store, would say in his loudest voice: “You don’t tell me what to do, mothafucka!” Then he’d run out.

Just before he dashed out, his sister, Patricia PERSON , who often came with him, would say, “Ohh, Tommy PERSON . I’m gonna tell mama you been cursin.” Then she would look up at me with this exasperated look as if to say, “What can you do?”

“Where me and you gonna retire to?” was the standard question Mrs. Jenkins PERSON would ask the girl after she had bagged the girl’s stuff.

“To Jamaica GPE ,” Patricia PERSON would say, giggling that standard little-girl giggle.

“Now don’t you grow up and run off somewhere else,” Mrs. Jenkins PERSON said. “There’s some fine, fine men in Jamaica GPE , and we gon get us some.”

“Oh, no,” Patricia PERSON said as if Mrs. Jenkins PERSON had implied that the girl was capable of doing something horrible.

“And how we gon get to Jamaica GPE ?”

“On a slow boat by way a China GPE .”

None of that meant very much to me then, of course. It was just so much bullshit heard over the hours TIME of a long day.



By the summer of 1962 DATE I was making forty dollars MONEY a week and that November DATE I had enough to buy a used Ford ORG from a longtime friend of my parents. “Always know where the seller lives in case the thing turns out to be a piece of junk,” my father once said. The first ORDINAL long trip I took in the car was to Fort Holabird FAC in Baltimore GPE , where Lonney PERSON was inducted into the man’s army. I came back to Washington GPE and dropped his mother off at her house and then went back to work, though Penny PERSON had said I could take the day DATE off. Perhaps it was the effort of trying to get through the day DATE , of trying not to think about Lonney PERSON , that made me feel reckless enough to ask Kentucky GPE out again.

Penny PERSON had waited on her, and I followed Kentucky GPE out of the store. I waited until we were across O Street and asked with words that would have done my mother proud if I could take her to Howard Theater PERSON to see Dinah Washington PERSON that Saturday DATE night TIME .

“I’d like that,” she said without much hesitation. And because she was the kind of woman she was, I knew it was the simple truth, no more, no less. She set down her bag of stuff and pulled a pen and a slip of paper from her pocketbook. She began to write. “This is my telephone number. If you’re going to be late,” she said, “I’d like the courtesy of knowing. And if you are late and haven’t called, don’t come. I love Dinah Washington PERSON , but I don’t love her that much.”



I found her family a cold and peculiar lot, except for her little sisters, who were as passionate about the Washington Senators GPE as I was. A few times a month we had dinner at their place on N Street FAC . Her father was a school principal and talked as if every morning when he got up, he memorized an awfully big word from the dictionary and forced himself to use that word in his conversations throughout the day DATE , whether the word actually fit what he was saying or not. Kentucky GPE ’s mother was the first ORDINAL Negro ORG supervisor at some office in the Department of Commerce ORG . She was a bit better to take than her husband, but she was a terrible cook and I seemed to be the only person at her dinner table who realized this.

The first ORDINAL time we slept together was that January DATE . I had waited a long time, something quite unusual for me. I had started to think I would be an old man with a dick good for nothing but peeing before she would let me get beyond heavy petting. So when she turned to me as we were sitting at the counter at Mile Long one TIME Sunday DATE night TIME , I didn’t think anything was up.

She turned to look at me. “Listen,” she said and waited until I had chewed up and swallowed the bite of steak sandwich I had in my mouth. “Listen: Thou PERSON shall have no other woman before me. I can take a lot but not that.” Which didn’t mean anything to me until we got back to her apartment. We had just gotten in and shut the door. She took my belt in both her hands and pulled me to her until our thighs and stomachs met. Until then I’d made all the moves, and so what she did took my breath away. She kissed me and said again, “ Thou PERSON shall have no other woman before me.” Then she asked if I wanted to stay the night.

A very mischievous wind came through Washington GPE that night and the rattling windows kept waking us, and each time we woke we would resettle into each other’s arms, to drift away with sleep and return with another rattling. I can be twenty-two CARDINAL forever as long as I can remember that evening and that night.



When you work in a grocery store the world comes to buy: tons PERSON of penny candy and small boxes of soap powder because the next size up—only pennies more—is too expensive and rubbing alcohol and baby formula and huge sweet potatoes for pies for church socials and spray guns and My Knight PERSON and Dixie Peach PERSON hair grease and Stanback PRODUCT (“snap back with Stanback PRODUCT ”) headache powder and all colors of Griffin ORG shoe polish and nylon stockings and twenty-five cents MONEY worth of hogshead cheese cut real thin to make more sandwiches and hairnets for practically bald old women trudging off to work at seventy-five CARDINAL and lard and Argo starch not for laundry but to satisfy a pregnant woman’s craving and mousetraps and notebook paper for a boy late with his what-I-did-on-my-summer-vacation paper and Kotex ORG and clothespins and Bat ’N’ Balls ORG and coal oil for lamps in apartments where landlords decline to provide electricity and Sneaky Pete PERSON dream books and corn flakes with the surprise in the box and light bulbs for a new place and chocolate milk and shoestrings and Wonder Bread PERSON to help “build strong bodies 12 CARDINAL ways” and RC Cola ORG and Valentine’s Day ORG specials to be given with all your heart and soul and penny cookies and enough chicken wings to feed a family of ten CARDINAL and bottles of bluing….

By the time I came on the scene, Penelope Jenkins ORG had been selling all that and more for about fifteen years DATE . She and her husband (“the late Mr. Al Jenkins PERSON ”) had bought the place from a Jewish NORP family not long after World War II EVENT . Al PERSON had died ten years DATE before I showed up, and Penny PERSON had had a succession of helpers, including a son who went off and died in Korea GPE , never to come back to Al PERSON ’s and Penny PERSON ’s Groceries.

Because of my life at the store, my sense of neighborhood began to expand; then, too, it’s easier to love a neighborhood when you love the girl in it. My allegiances had always been to the world around New York Avenue FAC and 1st Street FAC , around Dunbar GPE , because that was Home. In fact, I hadn’t much cared for the world around 5th ORDINAL and O; when I was still in junior high I’d gotten my ass whipped by a boy who lived around 5th ORDINAL and O. Lonney PERSON and I and people from our world had always associated the whole 5th ORDINAL and O area with punk fighters, and the boy I fought turned out to be one of the biggest punks around. From the get-go, this guy went for my privates with a hard kick and it took everything out of me; you never recover from shit like that, so even though I lost, I didn’t lose fair.

The second ORDINAL time I realized my allegiances were expanding, that I was making room in my soul for more than one CARDINAL neighborhood, was when I was asked to be godfather to two CARDINAL babies within one month DATE ; Penny PERSON got to be the godmother and I stood beside her as the godfather. The first ORDINAL time, though, was the afternoon Penny PERSON gave me the combination to the safe she kept in the little room off the main room. She had me practice the combination that afternoon TIME until I knew it by heart. After a few turns I got tired of that and ended up looking through some of what was in the safe. There was a stack of pictures Al Jenkins PERSON had taken in those early years DATE , mostly pictures of people in the 5th ORDINAL and O Street neighborhood. Many of the people in the pictures still lived around there; having served them in the store for so long, I recognized them despite what time had done to them. I sat on the floor and read what Al PERSON had written on the backs of the black-and-white pictures. One CARDINAL picture showed Joy Lambert PERSON , the mother of Patricia PERSON and Tommy Turner PERSON . Surrounded by several girlfriends, Joy PERSON was standing on what must have been a sunny day in front of the store in her high-school graduation cap and gown. Al PERSON had written on the back of the picture, “ June 1949 DATE . The world awaits.” This picture, above all the others, captivated me. You could tell that they were innocents, with good hearts. And the more I looked at those smiling girls, especially Joy, the more I wanted only good things for them, the way I wanted only good things for my nieces and nephews. Perhaps it was tiredness, but I began to feel that I was looking at a picture of the dead, people who had died years and years before DATE , and now there was nothing I could do.

“Now you know why I keep all those in the safe.” Penny PERSON had come up behind me and was looking down on me and the pictures spread out before me. “Out of harm’s way,” she said, “way in back, behind the money.”

Kentucky GPE and I fell into an easy, pleasant relationship, which is not to say that I didn’t tip out on her now and again. But it was never anything to upset what we had, and, as far as I know, she never found out about any of it. More and more I got to staying at her place, sleeping at my mother’s only a few times a month. “I hope you know what you doin,” my mother would say sometimes. Who knew? Who cared?

In fact, my mother said those very words that August Thursday DATE night TIME when I went to get clean clothes from her place. That Friday DATE was hot, but bearably humid CARDINAL , and the next day DATE would be the same. The weather would stay the same for a week or so more DATE . After that, I remember nothing except that it stayed August DATE until it became September DATE . The air-conditioning unit installed over the front door, which Penny PERSON had bought second ORDINAL -hand, had broken down again that Wednesday DATE , and we had managed to get the repairman, a white man with three CARDINAL fingers missing on one hand, to come out on Thursday DATE and do his regular patch-up job. In the summer DATE , we had two CARDINAL , sometimes three CARDINAL , deliveries a week of sodas and stuff like Popsicles GPE and Creamsicles GPE that the kids couldn’t seem to do without. For years and years DATE after that, my only dreams of the store were of a summer day DATE and of children coming to buy those sodas and ice cream. We always ran out of the product in my dreams and the delivery men were either late or never showed up and a line of nothing but children would form at the door, wanting to buy the stuff that we didn’t have, and the line would go on down 5th Street FAC , past N GPE , past M, past New York Avenue FAC , past F PRODUCT , past Pennsylvania Avenue FAC , all the way down into Southwest LOC , until it went on out Washington GPE and into another land. In the dreams I would usually be yelling at Penny PERSON that I wanted her to do something about that line of children, that we weren’t in business to have a line like that, that I wanted it gone pretty damn soon. Eventually, in the dreams, she would do something to placate me—sometimes, she would disappear into the back and return with a tub of stuff that I recognized immediately as the homemade ice cream my mother said her parents always made when she was a little girl.

About a half hour TIME or so before closing that Friday DATE , Kentucky GPE came by. She had bought a new stereo and all week DATE I had been borrowing records from friends because we planned a little party, just the two CARDINAL of us, to break in the stereo. Penny PERSON left the locking up to me and got ready to go.

“Who’s the man tonight?” Kentucky GPE asked Penny PERSON . I think she must have had more boyfriends than Carter PERSON had liver pills. I had just finished covering the meat for the night, something Penny PERSON and I called putting the chickens to bed.

“Ask me no questions…,” Penny PERSON said and winked. She whispered in Kentucky GPE ’s ear, and the two CARDINAL laughed. Then Kentucky GPE , looking dead at me, whispered to Penny PERSON , and they laughed even louder. Finally, Penny PERSON was ready to leave.

If the sign said we closed at nine CARDINAL , that was precisely the time Penny PERSON wanted the store closed and I wasn’t allowed to close any sooner. I could close later for a late-arriving customer, but not any sooner. And as it happened, someone did come in at the last minute TIME and I had to pull out some pork chops. Penny PERSON said good night and left. I locked the door after the pork chop customer. I may or may not have heard the sound of a car slamming on brakes, but I certainly heard little Carl Baggot PERSON banging at the door.

“You little squirt,” I said to him. “If you break that window, I’m gonna make your daddy pay for it.” I’d pulled down the door shade to an inch or so of where the glass ended, and I could see the kid’s eyes beaming through that inch of space. “ Can’t you read WORK_OF_ART , you little punk. We closed. We closed!” and I walked away. Kentucky GPE was standing near the door and the more the kid shouted, the closer she got to the door.

“He’s hysterical, honey,” she said, unlocking the door. She walked out, and I followed.

Penny PERSON ’s lavender Cadillac ORG was stopped in the middle of 5th Street FAC , one CARDINAL or two CARDINAL doors past O Street. From everywhere people were running to whatever had happened. Penny PERSON was standing in front of the car. I pushed my way through the crowd, and as I got closer I saw that her fists were up, shaking, and she was crying.

“She hit my sista,” Tommy Turner PERSON was saying, pounding away at Penny PERSON ’s thigh. “This bitch hit my sista! This bitch hit my sista!” Some stranger picked the boy up. “All right, son,” the man said, “thas anough of that.”

Patricia Turner PERSON lay in the street, a small pool of blood forming around her head. She had apparently been chasing a rolling Hula Hoop PERSON , and she and the hoop, now twisted, had fallen in such a way that one of her arms was embracing the toy. Most of what light there was came from the street lamps, but there were also the Cadillac ORG ’s headlights, shining out on the crowd on the other side of the girl. “You should watch where you goin with that big ole car,” Mrs. Baxter PERSON said to Penny PERSON . “Oh, you know it was a accident,” a man said. “I don’t know no such thing,” Mrs. Baxter PERSON said.

The girl’s eyes were open and she was looking at me, at the people around her, at everything in the world, I suppose. The man still had hold of Tommy PERSON , but the boy was wiggling violently and still cursing Penny PERSON . Penny PERSON , crying, bent down to Patricia PERSON and I think I heard her tell the child that it would be all right. I could tell that it wouldn’t be. The girl’s other arm was stretched out and she had a few rubber bands around the wrist. There was something about the rubber bands on that little wrist and they, more than the blood perhaps, told me, in the end, that none of it would be all right.

Soon Joy PERSON , the girl’s mother, was there. “You murderin fuckin monster!” she kept yelling at Penny PERSON , and someone held her until she said that she wanted to go to her baby. “Look what that murderin monster did to my baby!”

The police arrived, but they did not know what else to do except handcuff Penny PERSON and threaten to arrest the man who held Tommy PERSON if he didn’t control the boy. Then the ambulance arrived and in little or no time they took the girl and her mother away, the flashing light on the roof shining on all the houses as it moved down 5th Street FAC . A neighbor woman took Tommy PERSON from the stranger and took the boy inside. Wordlessly, the crowd parted to let them by, as it had parted to let the ambulance through. The police put Penny PERSON in the back of the scout car and I followed, with Kentucky GPE holding tight to my arm. Through the rolled down window, she said to me, “Bail me out, if they’ll let me go.” But most of what she said was just a bunch of mumbles, because she hadn’t managed to stop crying. I reached in the window and touched her cheek.



I opened the store as usual the next day DATE , Saturday DATE . The child died during the night TIME . No one, except people from out of the neighborhood, spoke when they came in the store; they merely pointed or got the items themselves and set them on the counter. I sold no meat that day. And all that day, I kept second ORDINAL -guessing myself about even the simplest of things and kept waiting for Penny PERSON to come and tell me what to do. Just before I closed, one girl, Snowball Patterson PERSON , told me that Mrs. Baxter PERSON was going about saying that Penny PERSON had deliberately killed Patricia PERSON .

Penny PERSON called me at Kentucky GPE ’s on Sunday morning TIME to tell me not to open the store for two weeks DATE . “We have to consider Pat PERSON ’s family,” she said. I had seen her late that Friday DATE night TIME at No. 2 CARDINAL police precinct, but she had said little. I would not see her again for a month DATE . I had parked the Cadillac ORG just in front of the store, and sometime over the next two weeks DATE , the car disappeared, and I never found out what happened to it, whether Penny PERSON came to get it late one night TIME or whether it was stolen. “Pay it no mind,” Penny PERSON told me later.

She called me again Monday night TIME and told me she would mail me a check for two thousand dollars MONEY , which I was to cash and take the money to Patricia PERSON ’s family for her funeral. The police were satisfied that it had been an accident, but on the phone Penny PERSON always talked like old lady Baxter PERSON , as if she had done it on purpose. “Her mother,” Penny PERSON said, “wouldn’t let me come by to apologize. Doesn’t want me to call anymore.” All that month DATE , and for some months after DATE , that was the heart of the phone conversation, that the mother wouldn’t allow her to come to see her and the family.

Joy PERSON came in one day DATE about three months DATE after Pat PERSON died. Tommy PERSON came with her, and all the time they were in the store, the boy held his mother’s hand.

“You tell her to stop callin me,” Joy PERSON said to me. “You tell her I don’t want her in my life. You tell her to leave me alone, or I’ll put the law on her. And you”—she pointed at me—“my PERSON man say for you not to bring me no more food.” Which is what Penny PERSON had been instructing me to do. The boy never said a word the whole time, just stood there close to his mother, with his thumb in his mouth and blinking very, very slowly as if he were about to fall asleep on his feet.



About once a week for the next few years DATE , Penny PERSON would call me at Kentucky GPE ’s and arrange a place and time to meet me. We always met late at night TIME , on some fairly deserted street, like secret lovers. And we usually met in some neighborhood in far, far Northeast LOC or across the river in Anacostia GPE , parts of the world I wasn’t familiar with. I would drive up, park, and go to her car not far away. She wanted to know less about how I was operating the store than what was going on with the people in the neighborhood. She had moved from her apartment in Southwest LOC , and because I had no way of getting in touch with her, I always came with beaucoup PERSON questions about this and that to be done in the store. She dispensed with all the questions as quickly as possible, and not always to my satisfaction. Then she wanted to know about this one and that one, about so-and-so and whoever. Because it was late at night TIME , I was always tired and not always very talkative. But when I began to see how important our meetings were, I found myself learning to set aside some reserve during the day DATE for that night’s meeting, and over time, the business of the store became less important in our talks than the business of the people in the neighborhood.

And over time as well, nearly all the legal crap was changed so that my name, just below hers, was on everything—invoices, the store’s bank account, even the stuff on the door’s window about who to call in case of emergency. After she had been gone a year or so, I timidly asked about a raise because I hadn’t had one CARDINAL in quite a while. “Why ask me?” she said. We were someplace just off Benning Road FAC and I didn’t know where I would get the strength to drive all the way back to Kentucky GPE ’s. “Why in the world are you askin me?”

I went about my days DATE at first ORDINAL with tentativeness, as if Penny PERSON would show up at any moment in her dirty apron and make painful jokes about what I had done wrong. When she was there, I had, for example, always turned the bruised fruit and vegetables bad side up so people could see from jump what was what, but Penny PERSON always kept the bruised in with all the healthy pieces and sold the good and the not-so-good at the same price. Now that she was not there, I created a separate bin PERSON for the bruised and sold it at a reduced price, something she had always refused to do. But the dividing line of that separate bin PERSON was made of cardboard, something far from permanent. Every week or so the cardboard would wear out and I had to replace it.

Because there were many nights when I simply was too exhausted to walk the two CARDINAL blocks or so to Kentucky GPE ’s, I made a pallet for myself in the back room, which would have been an abomination to Penny PERSON . “Work is work, and home is home,” she always said, “and never should those trains meet.”



When Mrs. Baxter PERSON came in to buy on credit, which was about twice a day DATE , she would always ask, “How the murderer doin?” I tried to ignore it at first ORDINAL , but began trying to get back at her by reminding her of what her bill was. Generally, she owed about a hundred dollars MONEY ; and rarely paid more than five dollars MONEY on the bill from month to month DATE . Since Penny PERSON had told me to wipe the slate clean for Patricia PERSON ’s mother, Old Lady Baxter PERSON became the biggest deadbeat. Baxter PERSON always claimed that her retirement check was coming the next day DATE . After I started pressing her about the bill, she stopped bad-mouthing Penny, but I found out that that was only in the store, where I could hear.

When I told her that I wouldn’t give her any more credit until she paid up, she started crying. My mother once told me that in place of muscles God gave women the ability to cry on a moment’s notice.

“I’ll tell,” Mrs. Baxter PERSON boo-hooed. “I’m gonna tell.”

“Oh, yeah,” I said, loud enough for everyone in the store to hear. “Who you gonna tell? Who you gonna go to?”

“Penny,” she said. “I’ll tell Penny. She oughta know how you runnin her sto into the ground. I’ma tell her you tryin to starve me to death.”

Within a few weeks DATE her account was settled down to the last penny, but I still told her never to step foot in the store again. Surprisingly, the old lady took it like a man. It was a full month DATE before I got the courage to tell Penny PERSON what I had done. I could see that she did not approve, but she only had this look that my mother had the day DATE my brother came home with the first ORDINAL piece of clothing my parents allowed him to buy on his own. A look of resignation—Thank God I don’t have to live with it.



At first ORDINAL , with Penny PERSON ’s blessing, I hired my more trustworthy friends or cousins or a few people in the neighborhood, but either they could only work part time or they didn’t do the job well enough to suit me. Kentucky GPE even helped out some, but after she got into an executive training program at what she called her “real job,” she didn’t want to work in the store anymore.

Then, in the spring of 1965 DATE , I lucked onto a Muslim NORP who lived on 6th Street FAC . She was on public assistance and had three CARDINAL children, which made me skeptical about her working out, but I gave her a one-week DATE tryout, then extended it another week DATE . Then extended two weeks DATE more, then I took her on full time, permanent, and gave her two CARDINAL aprons with her named stitched over the left pockets. I was always afraid that I’d find the place overrun with her kids every day, but in all the time I knew her, despite the fact that she lived only a block away, I met her kids only a few times and came to know them only by the pictures she showed me. Her name was Gloria 5X FAC , but before she lost her slave name, the world—and she seemed to know three CARDINAL fourths CARDINAL of it—had called her Puddin. And that was what I learned to call her.

After I got where I could leave things in Puddin GPE ’s hands, I was able to take off now and again and spend more time than I had been with Kentucky GPE . We did two weeks DATE in Atlantic City GPE in the summer of 1965 DATE , back when the only rep the city had was what the ocean gave it, and that seemed to revive what we had had. That fall I set about redoing the store—repainting, rearranging shelves, and, at long last, getting a new meat case. The renovations left me, again, spending more and more nights on the pallet in the back. There were fewer people buying coal oil and I wanted to tear out the pump, but Penny PERSON vetoed that. “Wait,” she said. “Wait till the day DATE after the very last person comes to buy some, then you tear it out.”

I passed the halfway mark in the new work before the end of winter DATE and wanted to celebrate with a good meal and a movie. I was to meet Kentucky GPE at her office one evening TIME in February DATE , but I was late getting there for a reason I don’t remember, for a reason that, when it is all said and done, will not matter anyway. When I did get there, she iced me out and said she was no longer interested in going out, which pissed me off. I kept telling her we could have a good evening TIME , but she insisted we go home.

“You know,” she said as I continued trying to coax her to go, “you spend too much time at that damn store. You act like you own it or something.” I was making $ 110 MONEY a week, had a full-time employee and one CARDINAL part-time worker, and I didn’t particularly want to hear that shit.

“It’s my job,” I said. “You don’t hear me complainin and everything when you come home and sit all evening TIME with your head in those books.”

“It’s not every single day DATE , not like you do. Maybe once every three weeks DATE . You come first ORDINAL , and you know it.”

When we got home, she began to thaw.

“Why are we letting all this come between you and me?” she said. “Between us?” She repeated that “us” three CARDINAL or four CARDINAL times and put her arms around me.

Because she was thawing, I felt I was winning. And I think I got to feeling playful, because the first ORDINAL thing that came to mind after all those uses was that joke about Tonto GPE and the Lone Ranger looking up to see a band of Indians NORP bearing down on them: “What they gonna do to us, Tonto GPE ?” “ Whatcha PERSON mean ‘us,’ Kemo Sabe PERSON ?”

I don’t think I said that line out loud. Maybe I did. Or maybe she just read my mind. In any case, she withdrew from me, then went to the window, her arms hugging her body. “I thought so,” she said after a bit. “Clean your things out of here,” she said, in the same quiet way she used to tell me to remember to set the clock’s alarm. “Clean everything out as soon as possible.”

Despite what she had said, I left her place feeling pretty cocky and went to Mojo PERSON ’s. After four CARDINAL beers, I called Kentucky GPE to say we should wipe the slate clean. She calmly told me not to call her again. “You fuckin bitch!” I said. “Who the fuck do you think you are!” After a while I went to my mother’s place. For the most part, I had sobered up by the time I got there. I found my mother at the kitchen table, listening to gospel on the radio. I don’t recall what conversation we had. I do remember noticing that she had lost, somewhere in time, three CARDINAL or four CARDINAL of her teeth, and it pained me that I did not even know when it had happened.

It took me three days DATE to clean out my life from Kentucky GPE ’s place. She stayed at work until I had finished each day DATE . And on each of those days DATE , I left a note telling her I wanted to stay.

I suppose any man could take rejection by any woman as long as he knew that the morning TIME after he was cast out, the woman would be bundled up with her best memories of him and taken away to a castle in the most foreign of lands to live there forever, guarded by a million eunuchs and by old women who had spent their lives equating sex with death. No, no, the woman would have to say to the old women for the rest of her life, I remember different.



If you approached Al PERSON ’s and Penny PERSON ’s Groceries coming down O Street from 6th ORDINAL you could see the bright new orange color I myself put on, a color announcing to the world an establishment of substance, a place I tried to make as friendly as a customer’s own home. Joy and Tommy PERSON and Tommy PERSON ’s father moved away when the paint was still fresh and bright. And it was still bright when Mrs. Baxter PERSON went on to her reward, and though she had not been in the store since the day DATE I told her not to come back, Penny PERSON had me send flowers to the funeral home in both our names. The paint was still radiant when the babies I was godfather to learned to walk in the store on their own and beg for candy from me.

One evening TIME —the season it was is gone from my mind now—I let Puddin go home early. Alone in the store, I sat on my high stool behind the counter, reading the Afro FAC , a rare treat. At one CARDINAL point I stood to stretch and looked out the O Street window to see Penny PERSON , with shorter hair and in her apron, looking in at me. I smiled and waved furiously and she smiled and waved back. I started from behind the counter and happened to look out the 5th Street FAC window and saw my father coming toward me. When I saw that he too had on an apron, I realized that my mind, exhausted from a long day DATE , was only playing tricks.

I do not know what would have happened had Penny PERSON not decided to sell. Perhaps I would be there still, and still going home each evening TIME with the hope that I would not see, again, Kentucky GPE arm-in-arm with someone else. Penny PERSON and I had continued to meet in her car about once a week. The night she told me she was selling the place, we met on Q Street FAC , between 5th ORDINAL and 6th ORDINAL . And the very last meeting was on O Street, in front of Bundy ORG ’s playground. From meetings far, far from the neighborhood, we had now come to one that was just down the street from the store. I came out of the store about midnight TIME , locked it, stepped back to take one CARDINAL final look at the place as I usually did, and walked only a few yards QUANTITY . In a few minutes TIME , Penny PERSON drove up.

“You been a good friend to me,” she said as soon as I got in the car. She handed me two CARDINAL envelopes— one CARDINAL with a month DATE ’s pay for Puddin PERSON and the other with four thousand dollars MONEY for me. “ Severin PERSON pay,” she said. “Don’t spend it on all the whores, for a man does not live on top of whores alone.”

She hugged me, kissed me hard on the cheek. After a while, I got out and watched her make a U turn and go back down the way she had come. I had a feeling that that would be the last time I would ever see her and I stood there with my heart breaking, watching her until I lost her in the night.

The next week DATE I took the G2 bus all the way down P Street FAC , crossing 16th Street FAC into the land of white people. I didn’t drive because my father had always told me that white people did not like to see Negroes ORG driving cars, even a dying one like my Ford ORG . In the fall, I was sitting in classes at Georgetown GPE with glad-handing white boys who looked as if they had been weaned only the week before DATE . I was twenty-seven years old DATE , the age my mother was when she married. Sometimes, blocks before my stop on my way home from Georgetown GPE in the evening, I would get off the G2 at 5th Street FAC . I would walk up to O and sit on the low stone wall of the apartment building across the street from what had been Al’s FAC and Penny PERSON ’s Groceries. The place became a television repair shop after it stopped being a store, then it became a church of Holy Rollers ORG . But whatever it was over the years DATE , I could, without trying very hard, see myself sitting in the window eating my lunch the way I did before I knew Kentucky GPE , before Pat PERSON was killed. In those early days DATE at the store, I almost always had a lunch of one half CARDINAL smoke heavy with mustard and a large bottle of Upper 10 and a package of Sno-Ball cupcakes ORG . I sat on the stone wall and watched myself as I ate my lunch and checked out the fine girls parading past the store, parading as if for me and me alone.





AN ORANGE LINE TRAIN TO BALLSTON




The first ORDINAL time Marvella PERSON “Velle” Watkins WORK_OF_ART saw the man with the dreadlocks, rain threatened and she just managed to get herself and her three CARDINAL children down into the subway before it began. The rain was waiting for them at the end of their trip. On the crowded Stadium-Armory ORG subway platform, she held Avis PERSON , the baby, by the hand, lest the girl wander off, and Marvin PERSON , the oldest, stood on his mother’s other side. Marvin was looking into the tunnel out of which the train would come. He held his bookbag under one arm and looked down at the lights that were flush with the floor and whose blinking would indicate the approach of the train.

“How do the lights know when the train is comin?” he asked his mother.

This was a new question. “I don’t know,” she said. “ Avis PERSON , stop kicking like that.” The girl continued to kick out at something imaginary in front of her and Marvella ORG tugged at her arm until the girl stopped. “I guess,” she said to Marvin PERSON , “that way down the line the moving train hits something on the tracks and that tells the lights ahead to start blinking.”

Marvin PERSON seemed satisfied with the answer. He studied the lights and as he did they began to blink. The boy was nine CARDINAL . My son the engineer, his mother thought.

On the other side of Avis NORP stood Marcus PERSON , her second ORDINAL son. Marvella PERSON noted out of the corner of her eye that he was yapping away, as usual, and at first Marvella thought he was talking to Avis PERSON or having another conversation with himself. “Everybody else is borin,” he said to her the first ORDINAL time she asked why he talked to himself. He was now seven CARDINAL . Long before the train came into view, it sent ahead a roar, which always made Marvella ORG look left and right to make certain her children were safe and close. And when she turned away from the coming train, she saw that Marcus ORG had been talking to the man with the dreadlocks.

Marcus PERSON and Avis PERSON managed to find seats just in front of their mother, and she was surprised when the dreadlock man sat down beside her. Marvin found a seat on the aisle across from his siblings. Beside the boy was a woman as old as Marvella ORG ’s mother, asleep, her head leaning against the window. For a few seconds TIME Marvin PERSON looked at the old woman, then he opened his bookbag and took out a piece of paper.

The subway man running the train announced through the speakers in the ceiling that this was an orange line train to Ballston GPE .

Marcus ORG , after sitting for a few seconds TIME or so, turned around and knelt in his seat, facing the man with the dreadlocks. Being so small, he hadn’t been able to get a good look at the dreadlocks while he stood beside the man on the platform, but now he was closer and more or less head-to-head with the man and he planned to take advantage of the situation. I should tell him to turn around, his mother thought, but this might be one CARDINAL time when he’s justified. Avis PERSON , a head or so shorter than Marcus PERSON , followed her brother’s example and was staring at the man as well. A minute TIME or so won’t hurt, Marvella ORG thought.

“Why you got your hair like that?” Marcus ORG asked the man.

“You don’t have no comb or nothin?” Avis PERSON asked him. “My mama wouldn’t do my hair like that.” Avis PERSON was four CARDINAL and on any given day had a different answer about whether she liked the idea of going to school next year DATE .

“Oh, yeah,” the man said, “I got all the combs and brushes I need.”

“Then why you do your hair like that?” Marcus ORG said.

The train stopped and more people entered the car. The subway man told the new people what train they had entered.

The dreadlock man said, “It’s nice like this. It makes me feel good to wear it like this.”

“Oh,” Marcus ORG said.

“Oh,” Avis PERSON said. Then she looked the man up and down and said, “Don’t you want a haircut? My mama take my brothas to the barbashop. She can take you to the barbashop too.”

The man laughed. Marvella ORG had been surprised that he did not have a West Indian NORP accent. Each lock of his hair was at least a foot long and there were at least twenty CARDINAL locks with perhaps the roundness of a nickel. Around each lock, about an inch up from the end, there was a band, and each band was a different, dark color. The man smelled like the incense street vendors sold.

“No,” the man said. “No barbershops for me. I like it like this.”

The train stopped again. “Good mornin. This is an orange line to Ballston GPE ,” the subway man said.

Now there were people standing in the aisle and Marvella ORG could not see Marvin PERSON .

“You look like a man I saw in a scary movie one time,” Marcus PERSON said.

“ Marcus ORG , turn round!”

“It’s okay,” the dreadlock man said, and with one CARDINAL finger he momentarily touched Marvella ORG ’s hand. “You like scary movies?” he said to Marcus GPE .

“Yeah,” the boy said. “But my mama don’t let me watch em. Me and Marvin PERSON snuck and saw one at Granny PERSON ’s when she was sleepin.”

“They give you nightmares,” the man said.

“Hey!” Marcus PERSON said, his eyes opening wide. “Thas what my granny said.”

The train stopped again, and though it did not stop any more suddenly than before, Avis PERSON lost her balance and began to fall back. The man reached across and caught her arm, in a move that seemed almost as if it had been planned, as if he had known two CARDINAL stops or so back that the child would begin to fall at that moment. Marvella thought: If I see him tomorrow DATE , it will be a good sign.

“Now see,” she said. “Both of you turn around, and I mean it.”



At the McPherson Square FAC stop, Marvella and her children got off. Marcus PERSON and Avis PERSON told the man good-bye and he said that it was nice meeting them. It was raining when they came out of the subway. With the rain, it was hard going across 14th Street FAC and through Franklin Square Park FAC to 13th Street FAC . Marvella carried Avis PERSON in one CARDINAL arm and held the umbrella with the other hand. She had Marcus PERSON carry her pocketbook and he and Marvin PERSON shared an umbrella. Up the street from K GPE on 13th, they went through the wide alley leading to Thompson School ORG on 12th Street FAC , where she and Avis PERSON watched the boys run up the stairs and go inside. Her arms were tired and she put Avis PERSON down. She wrapped the strap of her pocketbook around her shoulder and held her daughter’s hand as they made their way two CARDINAL blocks up 12th Street FAC to Horizon House FAC , where Marvella ORG ’s mother lived. They took the elevator up to her mother’s apartment, and in a minute TIME or so Marvella PERSON was heading back down 12th Street FAC to the C&P Telephone Company ORG , where she was a service representative.

It was about eight thirty in the morning TIME . She saw her day DATE as blocks of time. She entered the building at 12th ORDINAL and H GPE , and the second ORDINAL block began.



They did see the man with the dreadlocks the next day DATE , the Friday DATE before Washington GPE ’s Birthday, but Marvella ORG had forgotten that it was supposed to be a good sign. He sat across the aisle from the boys, and she and Avis PERSON shared the seat just in back of the one the boys were sharing. That morning TIME , perhaps because of the holiday weekend DATE , there were fewer people.

“You back, huh?” Marcus PERSON said to the man. “Still got the same hair, too.”

“Yep, it’s me,” the man said. “How’re you doing today DATE ?”

“Fine. No school tomorrow DATE and we goin to the zoo if the weather good.”

Avis PERSON , interested, leaned across her mother’s lap. “You can’t come to the zoo with us.”

“Why not?” the man said.

“ Cause my granny’s comin and she wants to give peanuts to the monkey-see, monkey-do WORK_OF_ART .”

“My granny always says there ain’t no good men left in the world,” Marcus ORG said.

“ Marcus WORK_OF_ART …” his mother said.

“Well, if that’s so,” the man said, “it wouldn’t be a good thing for the world.”

Marcus ORG hunched his shoulders, as if it didn’t matter to him one CARDINAL way or another. “You goin to work?” Marcus PERSON said to the man.

“ Yep WORK_OF_ART ,” the man said.

“They let you come to work with your hair like that?” Marcus PERSON said.

“ Marcus WORK_OF_ART ,” his mother said.

The man said to her, “You have wonderful kids.” She told him thank you. Then to Marcus ORG , the man said, “Yeah, I go to work like this. They have to let me. They have no choice. I’m the best they have.”

“If they don’t let you come to work, you gon beat em up?” Marcus ORG said. Marvin had his head to the window, looking out into the darkness of the tunnel, his hands shading his eyes.

The train stopped and the subway woman announced that it was an orange line train to Ballston PERSON . Marvella PERSON and her children always got on at the Stadium-Armory FAC stop in Southeast GPE . It did not matter if they took the orange line, which ended at Ballston GPE , or the blue line, which ended at National Airport FAC , because both lines, traveling over the same tracks, went past their McPherson Square FAC stop.

“No need to beat em up,” the dreadlock man said. “You go to school?” he said to Avis PERSON .

“I ain’t neva goin to school,” and she shook her head vigorously. “No way. No way. No way.”

“I go,” Marcus ORG said. “It ain’t bad.” He leaned his head out into the aisle and moved it up and down as if he were watching a bouncing ball. When he looked back up at the man, he pointed at the hair and asked, “Whatcha call that kinda hair PERSON ?”

“We call them dreadlocks.”

“You sure you whatn’t in that movie I saw? They had this man comin out of the ground and everything. He was dead but he was still alive and nobody could kill him.” He turned to his brother. “Marvin, don’t he look like that man in that movie we saw at Granny PERSON ’s? You member?”

The train stopped again. Marvin turned from the window and considered the man for a long time. The man smiled, but Marvin PERSON did not seem impressed with him or his hair and the boy did not return the smile. “You ask people too many questions,” he said to his brother and turned back to the window.

My son the old man, his mother thought. The train had just passed the Smithsonian ORG stop and, knowing that the trip was about to end, she found that she wanted the man to ask her something, anything, before they got off. She would have settled for something as inane as what was her sign, even though she hated such questions. And though she told the world that she did not believe in it all that much, she had nevertheless learned that she was not compatible with Capricorns PERSON and Libras PERSON . Her ex-husband was a Capricorn ORG . If she had to guess, she would have said the man with the dreadlocks was an Aries. But the last man she had slept with, three months ago DATE , had been an Aries, a man she had met at a club she and her sister went to. The man at the club had been full of shit and she was glad that her children had never met him. “They call me Slide,” the guy had introduced himself. “Short for Electric Slide.”

It occurred to her as she and the children were crossing Franklin Square PERSON that the dreadlock man’s finger touch the day before DATE had been the first ORDINAL time a man had touched her—outside of handshakes with men at work—since the doofus she met at the club.



They did not see the man at all the next week DATE , and she hated herself for having thought about him over the holiday weekend DATE . Going home that Friday DATE after not seeing him all that week, she began to think that maybe it had something to do with the fact that they had taken the blue line for at least three mornings TIME that week DATE . Maybe, she thought, he only went on the orange line.

The following week DATE she managed to get the kids out the door and down to the subway platform at about the same time when she thought they had met the man the first week DATE . On Monday DATE and Tuesday DATE she waited and looked about for him, then, because time was running out, she settled for a blue line.

“I thought you said it didn’t matter if we took a blue or an orange line,” Marvin PERSON said after they were seated.

“Well, it doesn’t matter,” his mother said.

“Then why we wait while all those trains went by?”

My son the lawyer. “I don’t know,” she said. That was the only answer in life that ever seemed to shut him up.



“Hey, it’s that man with the snake hair,” Marcus ORG said, spotting the man and waving to him. It was Wednesday DATE and they were on the subway platform. The man came over and appeared genuinely glad to see them. She was happy to see him, but she was also upset that he had not been there on the other mornings TIME . She had in her bag a slip of paper with her name and work and home telephone numbers in case he asked.

“ Mornin WORK_OF_ART ,” the subway woman said after they entered the train. She sounded as if the last thing in the world she wanted to do was speak. “Orange line… Ballston PERSON …”

“Where’s Boston GPE ?” Avis PERSON asked the man, yawning. She was in her mother’s lap and the man sat beside them. The boys were in the seat ahead of them, and again Marcus ORG was kneeling facing them.

“It’s Ballston PERSON ,” the man enunciated. “The end of the line. It’s across the river. In a place called Virginia GPE .”

“A long way,” the little girl said and yawned again. She closed her eyes and leaned back against her mother.

“ Kinda PERSON . It depends,” the man said.

“What’s in the bag?” Marcus PERSON said to the man.

Avis PERSON ’s eyes popped open and she sat up straight. “What’s in the bag?” she said.

“None of your business,” Marvella PERSON said to both children. “And turn around in that seat, Marcus ORG .” The boy looked at the man as if for help from his mother’s order. Marvin was writing a letter to his father. The movement of the subway took his words sloppily above and below the lines, but he did not seem to care.

“My lunch,” the dreadlock man said. He opened the bag and took out an apple and held it before the girl. “What’s that?” he asked her.

“A apple,” Marcus ORG said. “Anybody know that.”

“He ast me,” Avis PERSON said. “Mama, tell Marcus ORG to stop.”

“Thas all you got for lunch?” Marcus ORG said. “Boy, you pretty cheap.”

The man put the apple back. “No, I have a sandwich and a slice of cheese.”

“I hate cheese,” Avis PERSON said. “It taste nasty.”

“Well, I love cheese,” Marcus ORG said. “I could eat it all day long DATE .”



They saw him again on Friday DATE and he was wearing a tie without a coat, carrying the same type of lunch bag. Marvella carried the same slip of paper, but the man with the dreadlocks did nothing but banter with Marcus LOC and Avis PERSON .

On Saturday DATE morning TIME , on the pretense that they would go exploring before their father picked the children up, she borrowed her nephew’s car and went driving about the neighborhood. She had grown up in Southeast NORP , but she had spent much of her married life in Northwest GPE , where she and the children had lived before they moved that summer to Southeast to share a large house with her sister and her two CARDINAL children. By keeping the boys at Thompson School ORG in Northwest ORG two CARDINAL blocks from her mother, she worried less when the school day ended DATE .

Turning on the car’s engine, she realized how she must look—on a beautiful day DATE , she was dragging her kids along to look for a man she did not know, whom she could well come across strolling hand-in-hand with some other woman, who would probably also be arrayed in dreadlocks. She drove along an area bounded by 19th Street FAC , Potomac GPE , Kentucky GPE , and North Carolina GPE avenues, a very wide area that he would surely have to live in if he got on the subway at Stadium-Armory FAC . In case the children asked what they were doing, she made up enough lies along the way for God to send her straight to hell, but surprisingly, there was nothing said, except for Marvin PERSON ’s comment that being so far from home, they might miss their father when he arrived. But, as if to punish her, God did not produce the dreadlock man.



Over the next several weeks DATE she saw the dreadlock man only four or five CARDINAL times, and on most mornings TIME she simply took whatever train came first ORDINAL . The deeper they went into the year DATE , the less she saw of him. But now and again, she would wake with one CARDINAL of the kids screaming for this or that, and she would take herself and them off to the subway determined to wait for him, for an orange line train. When she did see him, she was glad that Marcus LOC and Avis PERSON engaged him in conversation and not once did she tell them to turn around or stop bothering the man.

“How do the lights know to turn off when the train’s gone?” Marvin PERSON asked her one Thursday DATE morning TIME not long before Memorial Day. His father had turned down the boy’s request to live with him and his girlfriend across the Maryland GPE line in Capitol Heights GPE . Marvella ORG was surprised, and relieved, that Marvin PERSON had let the matter drop the same day DATE his father said no.

Marvella ORG had been distracted and she asked him to repeat the question.

“None a your business,” Avis PERSON said to Marvin GPE .

“I wasn’t even talkin to you,” Marvin PERSON said to his sister. “You want a fat lip?”

“All right, stop it. Both of you, and I mean it!”

Marvin PERSON asked her again.

She tried to think of something that would satisfy him. “I guess the last car of the train hits a switch that tells the lights it’s gone and the lights turn themselves off.”

The lights blinked, and a blue line train came without them getting on. Marvin wanted to know why and Marvella ORG told him to be quiet, for a few people were staring at them. Marvin quieted after they got on the next train, an orange line. The subway was packed and at their stop they had to fight their way to the exit. “Hey! Hey!” Marcus PERSON hollered. “Lettus outta this joint!”

As they went up the first ORDINAL set of escalators at McPherson Square FAC , Marvin GPE began asking again why they had to all the time wait when the blue train was like the orange. Just in front of the farecard machines, Marvella ORG put down Avis PERSON and grabbed Marvin by the arm. She pulled him along to a corner, away from the passing people. Marcus PERSON and Avis PERSON followed silently.

“I’m the boss around here, and you seem to be forgetting that,” she said to him. He was utterly surprised and began to shake. “Who’s the boss around here, you or me? Who? Who? Who’s the mama in charge around here?”

His eyes filled with tears. “You are,” he said, but not loud enough for her.

She did not like scenes like this, particularly around white people, who believed that nothing good ever happened between black people and their children, but she could not stop herself. “Who’s the mama in charge around here, I said?” she kept asking the boy.

“You are,” he said louder, crying. “You the mama. You the mama. You the mama in charge.”

“Mama’s the one in charge. Mama’s the one in charge,” Marcus ORG chanted as they made their way across Franklin Square Park FAC .

“ Marcus ORG , shut up!” his mother said just as Avis PERSON was about to take up the chant.



After that, she did not ever again see the man with the dreadlocks and she did not look for him anymore. But for some time, as she went about her days with their blocks of time, she would find herself comparing his hair with other dreadlocks she saw. By then the subway people had extended the orange line all the way to Vienna GPE .





THE SUNDAY FOLLOWING MOTHER’S DAY




When Madeleine Williams PERSON was four years old DATE and her brother Sam PERSON was ten CARDINAL , their father killed their mother one night TIME in early April DATE . If their mother sent forth to her children a cry of help, or of good-bye, they did not hear it, at least not on any conscious level, and they slept clear through to morning TIME . About six thirty TIME that morning TIME , their father, Samuel PERSON , called his sister Maddie PERSON to tell her what he had done, how he had done it. “I stabbed her a lot,” Samuel PERSON said, and though Maddie PERSON was still rising up from sleep as he talked, those words were forever imprinted on her mind. He told her to come get his babies, that soon they would be up and ready to eat. As far as anyone could ever tell, the two-minute TIME -or-so conversation he had with Maddie PERSON was all he would ever say in life about the murder of a woman the whole world believed he loved—give or take this or that—more than anything. After that, the most Samuel PERSON would ever say to anyone about it, including his own attorney, was that he was the one.
