“Mr. Carlson PERSON , it’s obvious you cannot structure a defense for a man who does not want to be defended,” the judge assigned to the case of the District of Columbia GPE vs. Samuel Lamont Williams PERSON said at one CARDINAL point to the attorney assigned to defend Samuel PERSON . That was but one CARDINAL of the sentences in the transcript of the trial that Madeleine Williams PERSON would come to memorize.

When Maddie PERSON arrived at the apartment that morning TIME , she found her brother sitting in near-darkness on the floor near the couch, the telephone resting like a black pet on his lap. Still not quite fully awake, Maddie PERSON had traveled the three CARDINAL blocks to the M Street PRODUCT apartment only partially aware of what she was doing. Samuel PERSON was dressed only in his underwear; there was no sign of trouble about him that she could see, and for a bit this gave her comfort, and this was what she told the courtroom one sweltering day in July DATE .

But in his bedroom she found her sister-in-law, dead, head down, sitting on the floor with one CARDINAL leg under her in a giant pool of drying blood. In her left hand, the greatest friend of Maddie GPE ’s life gripped a hairbrush, and her right hand was open, also resting on the floor, palm up, as if expecting a small surprise to be dropped into it. It seemed to Maddie PERSON right then that all the innocence and joy and kindness had seeped out of Agnes Marie Williams PERSON and had become the pool of blood about her. The floor tilted, and so the blood had flowed through the night in several thin lines from the dead woman, and one CARDINAL line had been heading directly toward where Maddie PERSON was standing in the doorway. The front of Agnes LOC ’s nightgown was soaked through with blood. “He said to me on the phone, ‘I stabbed her a lot.’” These words her niece, Madeleine PERSON , would find on page twenty-eight CARDINAL of her $ 75.86 MONEY copy of the trial transcript. The day she bought it— some twenty years DATE after that morning TIME — Madeleine PERSON made it all the way home before she discovered that her copy was missing pages forty-five through fifty-two CARDINAL . It would be three weeks DATE before the court clerk could produce the missing pages, and on those pages there were no sentences that Madeleine PERSON would come to memorize.

In the next room, Maddie PERSON found the children, still asleep, and it was only then that she began to cry. She backed out of the room, went to her brother, and stood over him. “Say somethin to me,” she hissed. She waited, and then she kicked him as hard as she could in his side, and the force of the kick sent the telephone sliding off his lap. It was the last time in their lives she would ever touch him. Samuel PERSON raised his fist to her and kept it raised until she backed off.

“Say somethin, gotdamnit! Say somethin, you sonofabitch!” She was reliving a spot or two CARDINAL in the last year DATE , the times when Agnes LOC had said it would be all right and Maddie PERSON said No and Agnes LOC said Yes it would and then Maddie ORG said Yes because she wanted to believe too.

Maddie PERSON called the police. She went back to close the door of the adults’ bedroom and went to the children’s room. It took her a few minutes TIME to wake the children and help them dress. As usual, Pookie PERSON , as Sam Williams PERSON was then called, acted as if he were older than his ten years DATE and dressed without much fuss. But Madeleine PERSON was a problem. She complained that she was hungry, and her aunt told her she would get all the food she wanted at her place. Then Madeleine PERSON could not find her doll, and it took the three CARDINAL of them several minutes TIME of hunting about the room to find it. Finally, before their aunt opened the door, Pookie PERSON said he had to pee. Maddie PERSON told him to hold it and Pookie PERSON quietly told her that maybe he couldn’t, that he might pee on himself. “I told him we were in a hurry,” Maddie PERSON would tell Madeleine years later DATE , “and that if he did pee on hisself, it wouldn’t be the worse thing in the world for a boy to do.”

Madeleine PERSON , as she was used to doing, tweaked her father’s nose as Maddie PERSON was ushering the children to the front door. This was how her years of nightmares would begin, the nightmares that would keep her sleeping in Maddie GPE ’s bed until she was eleven.

Outside, Maddie GPE found two CARDINAL white policemen getting out of their patrol car. “Go up to the second ORDINAL floor,” she said with authority. “The door’s open. I’ll be back soon as I can.” One CARDINAL , the older, the larger, did not look up when she spoke and seemed preoccupied with fixing something on his hat. The other kept blinking as if he too had come directly from his bed; Maddie GPE , pestered by Madeleine years later DATE , would remember that the new day’s DATE sun flowed in on the street and bits of the sun were caught on the blinking man’s badge, his brass buttons, the plastic over the brim of his hat.

“Come,” she said to the children, and she took Madeleine PERSON ’s hand.

“ Aunt Maddie GPE , we ain’t even washed our faces,” Madeleine PERSON said, holding her doll by the back of the neck. “We ain’t even brushed our teef yet.” “It’s okay,” Pookie PERSON said, patting his sister’s head. The woman and the children headed down M Street FAC toward 5th ORDINAL , and so the sun was at their backs.

Judge John Tellingford PERSON chose to sentence Samuel Williams PERSON to twenty-five years DATE at Lorton GPE and, Madeleine PERSON found on page 164 CARDINAL of the transcript, the judge noted that for whatever demented reason the father had stabbed to death the mother of his children, he had seen fit to spare his children an equally horrendous fate. “You are lucky, Larry PERSON , your wife wasn’t white,” he said. “Or the full force of the people would have come down on that head of yours.” In A Pictorial History of the Judicial System in the District of Columbia, Madeleine PERSON would find a picture of Judge Tellingford PERSON . He had had a huge forehead many inches high and he had been a very small white man (“a towering figure on the bench,” a Washington Post ORG obituary would say), much smaller than any of the other judges in the book, and Madeleine PERSON could tell this even though Judge Tellingford PERSON had been photographed, like the others, in his judicial robe.

Of the newspapers, only the tabloid-sized Washington Daily News ORG reported what had happened. In a drafty room at the Library of Congress ORG , with the light on her microfilm-reading machine flickering the whole time, a pregnant Madeleine PERSON would find the headline, at the bottom of page thirteen CARDINAL , accompanied by about an inch QUANTITY and a half of print: NEGRO CHEF KILLS WIFE.



Madeleine PERSON and Pookie PERSON never saw the apartment again, and until she was about six CARDINAL , when Pookie PERSON told her to stop saying it or he would knock her in the mouth, she would pass the apartment building at 427 CARDINAL M Street FAC , Northwest GPE , and tell whomever she was with that up there on the second ORDINAL floor was where her daddy had stabbed her mama to death.

By default, Maddie Williams PERSON became their guardian. Maddie PERSON , who had lived with few cares, with neither child nor chick, as she told the world, had long before made peace with herself about never marrying, about never wanting a family. And so for weeks DATE and weeks DATE after the murder she beseeched Agnes LOC ’s family to take Madeleine PERSON and Pookie PERSON . The idea of being responsible for them for years DATE and years DATE terrified her. But each time she called on the telephone or knocked on their door at the fine house on New Jersey Avenue FAC , someone in Agnes LOC ’s family would remind her that they had never wanted their daughter, their sister, their Aggie ORG , to marry that man. “We knew he wasn’t any good,” they would say, and Maddie PERSON would go away knowing that what they really meant was that her brother had always been too dark for them.

She herself was a very dark-skinned woman with long hair she usually wore in a bun propped in all its abundance with hairpins on the back of her head, like a picture hanging on a wall. She loved men, men who would have killed for her, and it frightened her that she would have to give up all the colored men in the world for two CARDINAL children. Sometimes, for years DATE after she took the children into her life, as she lay on that freed hair in the arms of some man after they both had come and come again and the man was no longer drowning her with such foolishness about baby this and baby that, she would find herself beginning to fall asleep. Then, ever so slowly, her eyes would begin to open as she tried to remember if she had left the children with someone. And if she hadn’t, the man, in the dark, would reach across the bed to her as Maddie PERSON dressed.

“Oh, baby,” the man would say. “Oh, baby, I thought we’d have another go-round.”

“Next time, sweetie. I promise. The next time.”



Most of Maddie GPE ’s male friends had cars and they were all too happy to give her and the children a ride down to Lorton GPE to visit Samuel PERSON . In the beginning, despite Madeleine PERSON ’s nightmares and despite Pookie PERSON ’s questions to Maddie ORG , the children would go up to him willingly in the crowded visiting room and play the games, like tweaking his nose, that they had played once upon a time. But gradually Pookie PERSON retreated to a corner of the waiting room and would not move until it was time to go. “I won’t force him to do anything! Not a single gotdamn thing!” Maddie PERSON told Samuel PERSON once when he called from Lorton PERSON to ask her to get Pookie PERSON to be more affectionate. “You lucky they even come see you a tall. You gettin more than you deserve and don’t forget that.” And it wasn’t a matter of Pookie PERSON being moody, she told her brother. “You gotta have a lotta moods to be moody,” she said. “And he ain’t got but that one CARDINAL mood.”

Madeleine PERSON , torn between wanting to be loyal and stand beside Pookie PERSON in the visiting room and wanting to be with her father, nevertheless opted to sit in her father’s lap and they would share whatever snacks Maddie PERSON had brought. Samuel PERSON had begun to smoke, and when Madeleine PERSON left him, she and her clothes smelled powerfully of smoke. “You smell like Daddy,” Pookie PERSON would say to her during the ride back home. “Get away from me.”

Maddie PERSON would sit throughout the visit across the table from Samuel PERSON and Madeleine PERSON , talking to whatever man had brought them to Lorton PERSON . And if the man stayed in his car, she would sit reading a magazine. The only word she ever spoke to her brother during the visit was good-bye, never hello and never anything in between. “I wouldn’t have taken you if it was up to me,” Maddie PERSON would one day DATE tell her niece. “But you and him was tied to each other by blood and there was nothin I could do about that.”

At thriteen, Pookie PERSON said he would not ever go back to Lorton PERSON . “Daddy won’t like that,” Madeleine PERSON said, waving her finger in her brother’s face. “I don’t care what Daddy don’t like,” he said. And to Maddie PERSON , Pookie PERSON said that if Jesus PERSON could throw the men out the temple at twelve CARDINAL , he could go down to Lorton GPE or not go down to Lorton GPE . “Pookie actin up,” Madeleine PERSON told her father during the next visit. “What did he say to that?” Madeleine PERSON asked her aunt years later DATE as she held her sleeping son on her lap. “I don’t remember,” Maddie PERSON said.



The children in the realm made up these words and they would chant, particularly when Pookie PERSON was around:

Yo PERSON daddy killed yo mama

And soon he’ll get yo sista

Then you’ll be next, brotha PERSON , brotha PERSON .



After weeks DATE of the chanting, he went after the biggest of the boys who teased him and worked his way down to the smallest, to the ones his own size. Even if it took weeks DATE of picking a fight with one CARDINAL of them, he would persist until he had finally whipped the kid decisively, whether with just his fists, or the help of a brick, dirt in the face, the limb of a tree. And when he was all done, when it seemed that all the boys in Washington GPE , D.C. GPE , knew not to mess with Pookie Williams PERSON , he would, from time to time, go after someone he had already whipped. “Sing that song,” he would say before the first ORDINAL punch. “Sing that song you useta sing.”

When Pookie PERSON was fifteen DATE , he stayed all night TIME at a friend’s house on Ridge Street FAC . It was the first ORDINAL time he had stayed away all night TIME without Maddie PERSON knowing where he was. In the morning TIME , he dressed while all in the house were still asleep and went to the kitchen. He had not eaten since lunch the day DATE before and hunger gnawed at his insides. But he found nothing to eat. On the table, he saw a pocketbook with twenty-eight dollars MONEY and he pocketed twenty-one CARDINAL . Then, before leaving, he poured salt in the palm of his hand and licked his hand clean and convinced himself that that was enough to fortify him for the time being.

He sat on the corner at New York GPE and New Jersey GPE avenues and waited for the rest of the world to wake up, for Madeleine PERSON as she made her way to Walker-Jones ORG .

“ Aunt Maddie WORK_OF_ART called the police and had everybody lookin for you,” Madeleine PERSON said when she saw him.

“It’s all right. I done talked to her,” he lied. “It’s gonna be all right.” He gave her twenty dollars MONEY . What had worried him most about the hunger he felt before the salt was that his sister would somehow suffer the same, and he could not abide that. “I’m gonna be goin, so you do everything Aunt Maddie PERSON tell you.”

“Where you goin, Pookie PERSON ?”

“To the navy.”

“What navy?”

“The navy ORG navy.”

“Where you get this money?”

“I took it,” he said.

“ Aunt Maddie won’t let me have no stolen money WORK_OF_ART .”

“ Hide it away,” WORK_OF_ART he said. “You can do that. And don’t spend it on somethin stupid. Use it for a mergency.”

For a moment, he touched her cheek with the back of his hand, then she watched him walk away, and watching him, she was reminded of a short poem a teacher had made them memorize about a hungry man who went down to the river one day to fish for his supper. “Bye, Pookie PERSON ,” she said, but if he heard, he did not acknowledge. “Bye, Pookie PERSON ,” she said again. She noticed that already he was getting too big for the pants Maddie PERSON had purchased only the month before DATE . In her child’s mind, he was doing no more than playing hooky for the day DATE and she thought they would see him that evening TIME , but in fact he was gone fifteen years DATE and eight months DATE .



Madeleine never gave Maddie PERSON a moment’s trouble, her aunt was proud of telling her customers at Cleopatra’s Hair Emporium ORG , a small beauty shop of five CARDINAL chairs at 9th ORDINAL and P streets Northwest ORG . At the shop, at the bottom of the mirror at her station, Maddie PERSON taped her two CARDINAL favorite photographs, one CARDINAL of herself and the children taken at Sparrow’s Beach FAC one day DATE not long after they came to live with her. The man she was seeing at the time had captured the three CARDINAL with their backs to the ocean. She treasured the picture because her nephew and niece were smiling. Above that picture, she had taped a photograph of her and Agnes LOC in their late teens. They were sitting with crossed ankles on the hood of an automobile with an ornament of some being preparing to take flight. There was, on both their faces, a look of boredom, and there was, as well, a hint of don’t-fuck-with-me.

Madeleine PERSON took copies of these photographs when she went off to Columbia University ORG , which, she had decided, was far enough away to feel she was setting off on her own and still close enough to get back to Maddie GPE in less than a day DATE .

From Columbia ORG , she wrote to Maddie GPE and Sam PERSON , wherever he happened to be, at least three CARDINAL times a week. Aside from a postcard now and again, she stopped writing to Samuel PERSON after she was fifteen DATE , for no other reason than that she simply had little to say to him. Way before this, she had stopped going to Lorton PERSON to see him, but it was for the reason young people usually stop doing things—there were a thousand CARDINAL other things to do in an ever-expanding world. Her father became little more than a man in prison who, she remembered, smelled of cigarette smoke and who would beg for some sugar when she visited him. But when depression hobbled her and gave her new eyes with which to see the world, she began to imagine that she had seen what her father had done, to imagine that she, standing in the doorway, had been a witness, powerless, but somehow nevertheless culpable. “I told him to just stop writin you when you left for New York GPE ,” Maddie PERSON told her after Madeleine PERSON returned for good to Washington GPE . “I told him, ‘ New York City GPE ’s bad anough as it is.’”

In her sophomore year DATE , she began to do volunteer work at a preschool for Harlem LOC children. All of the children at the center took to her and she to them, but she was particularly fond of a precocious three-year-old DATE girl, Clarine PERSON , who, having learned where Madeleine PERSON was from, insisted on calling her Miss Washton PERSON . Somewhere in her life, the child had been told that she was adorable, and she enjoyed standing before Madeleine PERSON and the other adults and slowly turning around so that they could get a good look at her in her dress. “See, see, see,” she would say as she turned, the hem of the dress in both her outstretched hands.

In that second year DATE as well, she began seeing Curtis Wallace ORG , an energetic junior from Norfolk ORG . “They all act like they’re God’s gifts to the world, running around with their giant Afros PERSON and talking that trash about treating us like black queens, like the queens we used to be in Africa LOC ,” she once wrote Maddie PERSON . “How many damn queens could there be in one CARDINAL African NORP village anyway? At least he has some humility and feels that he is just one among billions CARDINAL on this planet…. If and when we taste the ‘forbidden fruit,’ as they say around here, I’ll let you know. So far, though, he’s been hands off.”

They would walk the girl Clarine PERSON home in the evenings because often no one came for her. The child lived in a crowded two CARDINAL -bedroom apartment with at least a dozen CARDINAL other people, including some five or six CARDINAL other children. In all the times she and Curtis NORP took the girl home, she had seen the mother only a few times, and each time the mother had stood in her bathrobe in the entrance to the kitchen smoking a cigarette and watching as Madeleine PERSON said good-bye to the girl. “ Whatcha PERSON takin up?” the mother asked each time. “What’s your major?”

In Madeleine PERSON ’s junior year, Clarine PERSON ’s father killed the mother with four CARDINAL pistol shots into the heart. Madeleine PERSON could not remember what the mother looked like, and even when she looked down at the woman in her coffin, she could not connect the dead woman with the woman standing in her bathrobe. The girl, along with the other children, had seen her father shoot her mother. She never returned to the preschool, but Madeleine PERSON would go to the girl’s apartment each day DATE after she had worked at the preschool. They would sit on the couch together, with Madeleine PERSON doing all the talking and the girl following the movement of Madeleine PERSON ’s lips as if that were the only way she could understand what was being said. At first ORDINAL , she brought the child small gifts: barrettes, slippers, coloring books. But when she returned, the things would have disappeared, so she took to bringing only snacks, whatever Clarine PERSON could eat right there in her presence.

“Why did he do it?” Madeleine PERSON asked her aunt one night TIME after she had returned from Clarine PERSON ’s apartment and found everyone and everything in the apartment gone. Some in the building said the girl’s people had come from the South LOC and taken her there, and others said the city government people had put all the children in a house for orphans on Staten Island GPE .

“I don’t know,” Maddie PERSON said. “I only wanted her back, and knowin the why of it didn’t have the power to bring her back.” She had waited all Madeleine PERSON ’s life for her to ask, had kept that nonanswer poised, and though she had been dozing beside the telephone watching the eleven o’clock TIME television news, the nonanswer sprang from her as if she had been asked her name. “I don’t know,” Maddie PERSON said again. “You alone there?”

“No. Curtis is here. I’ve been drinking, and please don’t tell me I shouldn’t have,” Madeleine PERSON said.

“I’ve had my share. Why should I tell you different?”

“Why would he shoot her in front of the kids?” Madeleine PERSON said.

Maddie PERSON said, “He didn’t shoot her. He stabbed her. If you say the word, I’ll have Bo drive us up there tonight TIME .”

“No,” Madeleine PERSON said.

“Then put Curtis NORP on the phone. And put him on now.”



She struggled on at Columbia ORG , spending much of her time in an unsuccessful effort to find Clarine PERSON . After graduation, she returned to Washington GPE , where Curtis NORP was finishing his first year DATE in law school at Georgetown GPE . He wanted to get married, or, at least, begin living together, but Madeleine PERSON said no, and she continued saying no even after she found she was pregnant.

She named the child Sam PERSON , after the brother she now knew only from pictures and telephone calls. She was not superstitious, but when she learned her son was retarded, she felt it some trick of God’s for giving the child a name that had originated with a man who had killed his wife. Against everyone’s wishes, she had the child put in the Children’s Center ORG , the D.C. GPE government’s Laurel GPE , Maryland GPE , facility for its retarded citizens.

Once or twice a month, Madeleine PERSON and Maddie PERSON and Curtis GPE and Bo Cromwell PERSON , the man Maddie PERSON had settled down with, would drive out on Sunday DATE to the center to see Sam Wallace PERSON . The government people had put him in the Martha Eliot Infirmary GPE , for Sam PERSON could not walk, and, they would find later, he could not talk. They brought him ice cream or Nilla Wafers PERSON or some other treat. Maddie PERSON would set him on her lap and coo at him, while Madeleine PERSON or Curtis NORP fed him. If he enjoyed what they gave him, there was never any indication from him. And had they brought him nothing, but simply kept him in his wheelchair and watched him the whole visit, he would have responded the same way.

Sunday DATE became the only day off from researching the Why, and after visiting their son, Madeleine PERSON and Curtis NORP would spend the rest of the day DATE at Maddie GPE ’s or go off to a play or movie and restaurant. She had found work as a cataloguer at the Library of Congress ORG , and every day DATE after work she would walk the stacks of that library or of the Martin Luther King PERSON , Jr. Memorial Library for an answer to something Maddie ORG had said did not matter because it would not have brought Agnes LOC back. Everything she found about the Why, however remotely relevant, ended up at her apartment far up Connecticut Avenue FAC . She taped thirty CARDINAL cassettes with Maddie GPE alone, and then searched out people who had lived in the M Street FAC neighborhood when the murder had occurred. Most of them did not remember her or the killing, but she taped them anyway.

By the time her son was one year old DATE , her father had begun writing to her again. Ten- and twenty CARDINAL -page letters in the most beautiful handwriting of anyone she had ever seen, about nothing more than what his days were like and who were the men he spent his days with. And he’d send newspaper and magazine articles he himself had found of interest, each article neatly cut out and pasted on a piece of ruled notebook paper. And he’d send poems—“On Missing a Daughter’s 25th Birthday WORK_OF_ART ,” “The Rage of Being Caged WORK_OF_ART ,” “ On Becoming a Grandfather WORK_OF_ART ,” “ The Light Through the Barred Window WORK_OF_ART .” She was, simply, captivated, and it was a very long time before she told anyone what he was doing. He spoke of everything in the world except the Why, and over time she lost the courage to ask. “I am thinking of you this day and all days…,” he began his letters.



A month DATE after he left the sea for good and returned to Washington GPE , Sam Williams PERSON found a wreck of a place on Martin Luther King PERSON , Jr., Avenue GPE in Anacostia GPE that had been a trophy shop, a place he thought would be perfect for a bakery. In a few months DATE of working alone, he had the place gutted, renovated, equipped, and opened for business. The children in the neighborhood began calling him the donut man. He hired a young man and woman from the neighborhood and trained them in what he called the life wonders of baking. He named the place after his mother and aunt. The House of Agnes ORG and Maddie GPE . Fine Baked Goods.

Among the regular customers were some of the parishioners from the Cleansing Waters Baptist Church ORG two CARDINAL blocks away, including the pastor’s daughter, Hazel Watts PERSON . She was one CARDINAL of the few people who never asked who Agnes LOC and Maddie GPE were. She came in one CARDINAL Saturday DATE to pick up a cake she had ordered for a birthday party for the oldest member of the Usher’s Board ORG , and, as had become his custom, Sam PERSON waited on her himself. He carried the cake—an orangeicing thing of one CARDINAL layer, two by three feet QUANTITY —to her station wagon.

“Miss Watts PERSON ,” he said, after he had set the cake in and shut the car’s back door, “we’d like to see you sometime.” He had developed the habit of often speaking about himself in the first ORDINAL person plural. “Maybe dinner, a movie. Something like that. That is, if you aren’t married or keepin company with someone.” He did not falter.

“I’m a free woman in that way, Mr. Williams PERSON ,” she said. “Dinner or whatever would be nice.”

He walked with her to the driver’s side of the car. “Miss Watts PERSON , I hope you’re not the kind of woman who likes a man to sit around and talk a lotta of sweet nothins to a woman, cause we ain’t it.”

“That’s all right, Mr. Williams PERSON ,” she said, looking for her keys in her pocketbook. “I’ve had my fill of sweet nothings.” She opened the door. “And Mr. Williams PERSON , I hope you’re not the kind of man who likes a woman to swoon every time she’s within a mile QUANTITY of him, cause I ain’t it.” She got into her car and handed him a card from the glove compartment.

Having known only prostitutes throughout his time in the world, he was surprised by candor coming from a church woman, and she liked the fact that he was surprised. She said, “I guess this means I don’t have to tip you.”



In the most luxurious hotel in the Bahamas GPE , with the smell of the ocean thick throughout their room, Sam PERSON would say that first day DATE , standing in the night dark at the window, “We’re never gonna believe in anything but right now. Not very much of tomorrow DATE . Maybe a little of the tomorrow DATE mornin but no farther than that.”

“A bride doesn’t want to hear that on her wedding night TIME ,” Hazel PERSON said, coming up to his back and putting her arms around him. She massaged a scar about his stomach, the result of a knife fight with a man in a bar in the Philippines GPE . The keloid ORG scar covered the place where his navel had been. “A bride wants to hear that there will be a million CARDINAL tomorrows. She wants to hear that there will be an always.”

“I know,” he said. “But I could be dead tomorrow DATE , and then what would you do with all them words?”

That afternoon TIME , on the beach, she had drawn a tiny football field in the sand to begin to teach him the game. He had never had any patience with games beyond a bit of poker here and there. But she had a passion for football. It was one CARDINAL of the few sins she had allowed herself, she said, “and I want you to taste it so I don’t go to hell alone.” When the lesson for that day DATE was done, she threw the stick into the ocean. “Now,” she said, “you teach me something.” The sun was at his back and she looked at him with her hand shading her eyes.

“We don’t think we have anything like all them quarterback people,” he said.

“It don’t matter. Anything will do. It don’t matter,” she said, for she had been a bride less than twenty-four hours QUANTITY . “Some trick with a string will do.”

He moved so that his body was enough shade for her and in moving he covered the football field. “We can teach you to defend yourself if two CARDINAL guys come at you at once,” and he held up his fists, ready, coiled, forgetting where he was and to whom he was talking. “I can teach you to put em down flat.”

She laughed. She liked it. She reached over and patted his stomach where the scar was. “Can you teach me how to defend against someone who wants to do that to me?” she said, thinking of the Philippines GPE fight.

“That’s a lesson for another day DATE ,” he said, thinking of something else.

That night, in their hotel room, her arms around him as he stood at the window, she said of his words about having only right now, “All right, just don’t talk about it anymore.”

“ We won’t WORK_OF_ART ,” he said. “We won’t say a word as long as you know that’s what we’re thinkin.” From the day DATE he arrived back in Washington GPE to the night TIME of the conception of his first ORDINAL son, it was ten months and three days DATE .



Not long after Sam PERSON and Hazel PERSON returned from their honeymoon, the prison people released Samuel Williams PERSON . He made his way alone from Lorton Prison PERSON to Washington GPE , a city he had not seen for twenty years DATE . He found a room at Hartnett Hall FAC on 21st Street Northwest FAC , and a few days later DATE , with the help of an ex-offenders’ group, he got a job as a short-order cook in a diner on E Street downtown.

Except for a movie now and again and a visit every two weeks DATE or so to see his sister (“I’ll give you one hour TIME on Tuesday DATE ,” she told him, “from six to seven CARDINAL . No more, and it might be less, cordin on how I feel”), the job was about all he had of life. He refused to become friends with any of the people he worked with or with the men who roomed in his building. Once or twice a month he paid for a whore, but he never brought her back to his room, choosing instead to pay for a two-hour TIME room at the Buckingham GPE , a place at L and 14th ORDINAL that catered to prostitutes and their johns. “ Sheets Changed With Regularly WORK_OF_ART ,” a hand-written sign at the desk said.

Once released, Samuel PERSON began writing to his son and received no reply for three months DATE . “ 20 years DATE of happy living isn’t long enough for a motherfucker like you,” Sam PERSON finally wrote his father. “Get back to us after you spend 10,000 years DATE in hell.”

Samuel ORG bought a fireproof box for the letters he received from Madeleine PERSON . Though he wrote her at least five CARDINAL times a week, she wrote back only once or twice a week. The most current letter from her he always kept on the top of his room’s chest of drawers, dead center, the way some people keep a vase of flowers.



Sam PERSON was furious when he learned from Maddie GPE that Madeleine PERSON had not only not told Samuel PERSON where to go, but that she was writing back to him. And for weeks DATE he refused to talk to her. A reconciliation was arranged by Hazel PERSON and Maddie PERSON on the Sunday before Mother’s Day DATE , which happened to be Maddie PERSON ’s birthday. They held a small party for her at Sam PERSON and Hazel PERSON ’s house in Anacostia GPE . Late in the day TIME , Sam PERSON stopped Madeleine PERSON in the kitchen. She was refilling the pitcher of lemonade and he took the pitcher from her.

“Why would anyone in the world write to the man who killed their own mother?” he said, sliding the pitcher far back on the counter.

“Let’s not get into all this,” she said. “I’m just here to have a good time and to give Maddie PERSON a good day DATE .”

Despite something in him that abhored backing down from any position, he had been eager to reconcile because each and every day DATE since his return he was aware of how much he and Madeleine PERSON had lost by not being together. So many years, important years, he had told his wife, they had known each other only through hurried, often dutiful, letters and through telephone calls with horrible connections and photographs that often arrived folded despite the “ Do Not Fold WORK_OF_ART ” instructions written on envelopes. Sometimes, in addition to the times they had on weekends, Sam PERSON would pick her up after work and they would eat at some restaurant near her apartment. It had taken them several months DATE before they could speak to each other without considering each and every word, before they could even comfortably hug hello and good-bye.

“I just wish you’d explain to me this need to write to that guy. I mean, this ain’t some kinda fuckin pen pal ORG .”

“I know what he is, Sam PERSON .” The others— Maddie PERSON , Hazel PERSON , Curtis GPE , Bo, and Sam PERSON ’s new baby—were in the backyard, and Sam PERSON and Madeleine PERSON could see them through the kitchen window’s curtains. The baby, newly weaned from Hazel PERSON ’s breast, had just been bottle-fed, and the adults were taking turns trying to get him to burp.

“I don’t think he has anyone else. There’s Maddie PERSON , but she could take or leave him, and she usually leaves him,” Madeleine PERSON said. With two CARDINAL fingers she wiped condensation from the pitcher. “It’s not like I don’t think about what he did. I just think I remember this father man and some good things he did. Maybe I write because blood is thicker than water.”

“So’s goddamn cookie batter. So what?” Sam PERSON said.

“You act as if it’s easy for me to write him. It’s not. Sometimes I’m afraid, but he keeps writing me, and he sends me things, becomes a father. He sends me things for my son. I want to write ‘Why?’ but all I can manage to ask is, ‘How was your day?’ He scares me sometimes, because it’s overwhelming, so it’s not as if I look forward to hearing from him. He wants to see me, but I always tell him no. Give me credit for that.”

He took her arm and squeezed it. “You give us the word,” he said. “Just give us the word and we’ll break his neck in a thousand CARDINAL places. Break his hands so he can’t ever write again.” In a few seconds TIME he had become something else.

“No,” and she pulled away, looking at him in that “Who are you?” way she did before she became comfortable with him again. “Is that what you think I want?”

“Who the hell knows what you want.”

Outside, Maddie PERSON , in a chair under the peach tree, had the baby with his head resting on her shoulder and, with two CARDINAL more pats on the back, the baby finally rewarded her with a loud burp that even Sam PERSON and Madeleine PERSON could hear. The adults in the backyard shouted “ Hooray WORK_OF_ART !” which frightened the child and he began to cry.

“You should talk to him or something,” Madeleine PERSON said. “He’s your son’s grandfather.”

Sam PERSON pulled the pitcher forward and wrapped her fingers around the handle. “You listen to me good: I been all over the damn world,” he said, “so when I came back here I knew what I wanted to put in my own world, and he’ll never be in it. He’s the only black person who can never be in it. We have our wife and child, and you and Maddie PERSON and Hazel PERSON ’s family. And there’re new friends all over Anacostia I’ve made, and people who come in the bakery, and people at that church Hazel PERSON drags me to.” He parted Hazel PERSON ’s lace curtains to get a better look at those in the backyard. “Now and again we meet a complete stranger we like a whole lot and I include that person in.” He released the curtains, then straightened them. “But no matter how big we make that world, it’ll never be big enough to include him. And he’s very lucky, cause we could have killed him a long time ago. I’ve driven over there a hundred CARDINAL times to do it—that’s how much I hate him. But I won’t. We won’t unless you and Maddie PERSON told us that’s what yall want. Every day DATE he wakes up he should feel lucky.”

He took the pitcher from her. “Your trouble’s that you live up there among all them white people. With the ghost people. They believe in that all forgivin shit, in all that stuff that cripples the soul. You should move out to Anacostia PERSON to be with real people, the people who know what day and night is like and never get the two CARDINAL confused.” Then he put his hands at the corners of her mouth and tried to fashion a smile. She hugged him, clung to him, and for those moments they were no more or less than a boy and girl without a mother and father.



Madeleine and Curtis NORP had planned to spend Mother’s Day at the Children’s Center FAC with their child, but Curtis NORP ’s father became ill during the week DATE and Curtis NORP went to Norfolk ORG . Madeleine PERSON would have waited until he returned to visit the center, but she did not want too much time to pass after Mother’s Day before she saw her son.

On the Sunday morning following Mother’s Day, she was ready to leave her apartment when the chime on her door rang. She opened the door without looking through the peephole. Samuel PERSON stood before her, holding a paper bag with one CARDINAL hand and removing his hat with the other. What she saw was not the man in the letters with the beautiful handwriting, not the man of the poems.

“I’m your father,” he said. He smiled and looked momentarily down at his shoes. At five CARDINAL , she stopped counting his missing teeth.

“How did you get in here?” she asked, looking to either side of him into the hall. “The front door is always locked.”

He stopped smiling. “Somebody was comin in and I got to the door fore it closed. I know this ain’t spected. I wanted to wish you a happy Mother’s Day.” He sounded like every black country person she had ever heard, those people who talked of fetchin this and wearin britches and someone commencin to do such and such.

“Mother’s Day was last Sunday DATE . It’s past,” she said.

“I know,” he said. “I started up here last Sunday DATE , but I left your address at home and when I tried to go by memory, I got lost. Never get lost in white folks’ neighborhood. The first ORDINAL law a the land.” He smiled again. His suit coat and pants had been stylish a generation ago DATE . They did not match, though they were both a dark blue that might appear similar at a glance. His dark gray fedora was now so old that it had the look of something abandoned, something a child pretending to be an adult might wear at Halloween DATE .

“Well, I’m on my way out. I’m afraid I’ve no time for a visit.”

“I can take you,” he said. “I can take you wherever you wanna go. I got a car and I can take you wherever you need to go.”

“I have my own car. Thanks,” she said.

“But I can save you wear and tear on yours,” he said. “Save you gas, too. Sides”—and he reached into the paper bag and pulled out a red, drug-store box of chocolates—“I brought you this. Happy Mother’s Day PERSON . You can eat em on the way to where you goin.”

She told him thanks and placed the box on the table by the door. She did not tell him that she had once, before age twelve DATE , been able to eat all the chocolate she wanted, but now all chocolate made her ill.



With her directions, Samuel PERSON drove out of Washington GPE and found the Baltimore GPE -Washington Parkway, heading to Laurel GPE and the center. He and his car smelled heavily of cigarette smoke. All that May the days DATE had been wonderful gifts, and that day DATE was no exception. After they had crossed into Maryland GPE , after there was enough fresh air blowing through the car to force out the smoky air, she relaxed somewhat and lay back in her seat.

“I been tryin to get up the nerve to come see you for a long time,” he said at one CARDINAL point, “but I guess it took spring to give me the nerve I needed.” He drove with his hat cocked back on his head. It was a sight she remembered from somewhere, but she did not know if it was a memory of him from before they had stopped being a family or from some movie she had seen with Curtis NORP . “It ain’t like goin to the store and buyin a loaf of bread, I know that.”

Before long, she directed him onto the center’s grounds and he parked in front of the infirmary. The infirmary was a one CARDINAL -story brick building of offices and wards where the city people kept the most severely retarded residents, those children and adults who could not talk or walk or feed themselves or communicate. There, too, were the patients from other buildings who had been beaten by the staff or other residents or who had been injured accidentally or neglected to the point where they could no longer care for themselves.

On the lawn there was a family fussing over a fellow who could have been five CARDINAL or in his teens or a man of thirty or so CARDINAL , and who was sitting in the lap of a woman who may have been his mother. Two CARDINAL cars down from where Samuel PERSON parked, a man was working deep under the hood of an ancient car. The woman raised her arm and gave an uncomfortably loud hello to Madeleine PERSON and Samuel PERSON .

Inside the building, they saw no one until they had walked far down the hall to D Ward GPE . All the way down they could hear the crying and cackling and laughing and shouting of those in other wards. Madeleine PERSON realized that she had come without some treat—pieces of fruit or a small box of cookies, something that Curtis NORP usually remembered to bring. At D Ward WORK_OF_ART , after the attendant had wheeled the child Sam PERSON out of his ward and left without having spoken one word, Samuel PERSON bent down and kissed the boy on the cheek, which embarrassed Madeleine PERSON . Sam PERSON blinked once and then after a few seconds TIME he blinked again. In the ward, those patients not in their beds were in wheelchairs, gathered around a very loud television set propped up on a dull blue bureau that had no drawers. The only person in the room who seemed interested in the television was an attendant painting her fingernails.

Samuel PERSON took the handles of the wheelchair and they went outside. Madeleine PERSON had never come there without Curtis NORP or Maddie GPE and she would have preferred going into one CARDINAL of the unoccupied offices in the front and shutting the door.

The woman on the lawn waved them over. “ Yall PERSON set a spell with us,” she said, then began to introduce those in her family. “And this here is Clement WORK_OF_ART ,” she said of the retarded boy in her lap. “The baby a the family. Six years old DATE .”

“That’s the biggest baby I ever saw,” said the woman’s daughter, who stood beside an older brother, just behind their mother. The brother whispered something in the girl’s ear and the two CARDINAL laughed.

“All right now,” their mother said, “Thas anough a that.” The woman, Arnisa Isaacs PERSON , gave Samuel PERSON a blanket and indicated that he should spread it on the grass for him and Madeleine PERSON and Sam PERSON to sit down on.

“We’ll just move around a bit,” Madeleine PERSON said. She resented Curtis NORP for not being with her, for not protecting her from all this.

“Oh, there’s time for that,” Arnisa PERSON said. “ The day DATE is long. Sit a spell.” She pointed to the blanket in Samuel PERSON ’s hand and he and Arnisa PERSON ’s son opened it and spread it in front of the woman and her retarded boy.

Sam PERSON , freed from the makeshift straps of cloth that had bound him to the wheelchair and placed beside Madeleine PERSON on the blanket, began to look about for the first ORDINAL time. Noticing an empty carton of ice cream, Samuel PERSON asked if there was a store nearby. “Like to get my grandson somethin,” he said.

“No,” Arnisa PERSON said. “There used to be a canteen, but all that’s gone. This place is goin to hell. The closest place is that place out on the road you came in on.”

“Oh, he doesn’t need anything,” Madeleine PERSON said, tying one CARDINAL of the laces on Sam PERSON ’s tennis shoes. “He’s probably just eaten lunch. It’s not necessary to get him anything.”

Samuel PERSON did not remember the place on the road and asked Arnisa PERSON for directions. She called to her oldest boy, who was helping the man working under the hood of the car. “He’ll show you where it is,” and before Madeleine PERSON could think of something to say, Samuel PERSON and the boy were in his car and heading back up the lane. The girl and her brother began helping the retarded brother into his wheelchair and they maneuvered the wobbly chair through the grass onto a paved, stone-littered area that had once been a playground.

“Yall be careful now,” Arnisa PERSON said. She reached across and took Sam PERSON ’s chin in her hand. “And how old’s this precious thing?” she said. “Oh, oh, ain’t he just the most precious thing in the whole world!” She took Sam PERSON onto her lap. “Come here, sugar.”

Sam PERSON began to drool almost immediately. Madeleine PERSON recoiled, and Arnisa PERSON leaned around to see what Sam PERSON had done. “Oh, honey,” Arnisa PERSON said, wiping Sam PERSON ’s mouth with a paper towel, “it’s only spit. It ain’t lye.” Then she began telling Madeleine PERSON about her life, sparing nothing, it seemed to Madeleine PERSON , as if the two CARDINAL women had known each other from day one DATE . The man working on the car was not the children’s father, wasn’t even her legal husband. “I lucked out when I found him,” Arnisa PERSON said, looking lovingly at the man still deep in the car. “A good man is hard to find, they say, and that’s the eternal truth. And then you throw in a kid— three CARDINAL kids!—not countin the one CARDINAL out here, and you talkin bout a hello and good-bye all in the same day DATE .”

Madeleine felt she knew this woman, knew her children, who were destined for nowhere, knew her common-law husband with his unreliable trash-heap of a car, knew this woman and her wig of “real human hair!” as the television ads proclaimed. Knew their tabloid lives. It occurred to her that they were a part of the same tribe as the nearly toothless man who had come to her door that morning TIME , saying he was her father. The more Arnisa PERSON talked, the more she was aware of how much time was going by and kept looking up the lane for the car that would take her back to Washington GPE . Sam PERSON leaned his back against the woman’s breasts and fell asleep.



Nearly an hour later TIME , Samuel PERSON and the boy returned, but they were walking, with the boy trying to balance on the narrow strip of yellow-painted concrete dividing the grass from the lane.

“Where have you been?” Madeleine PERSON shouted to Samuel PERSON when he was still yards away. “What have you been doing to leave me like this?”

Samuel PERSON was surprised at the outburst, but the boy began to explain that the car had died just before they left the center. Samuel PERSON had insisted on going on to the store, and he was now holding a bag of something as his daughter raised her finger and berated him. Arnisa PERSON stood with Sam PERSON in her arms.

“Help me get Sam PERSON into the wheelchair so we can get him back,” Madeleine PERSON said to Samuel PERSON . “How in the world are we going to get back home?”

“Oh, honey, Bill PERSON can probably fix that car,” Arnisa PERSON said. “He can fix anything.”

They put Sam PERSON in his wheelchair, and as Samuel PERSON wheeled the boy up the ramp, Madeleine PERSON looked her father up and down. “Don’t you even know how to dress? Can’t you see that that tie doesn’t go with that suit—if you can call it a suit—with those shoes. Don’t you even know how to match colors?” Samuel PERSON said nothing. After they had returned Sam PERSON to the ward, Madeleine PERSON waited in the infirmary lobby while Arnisa PERSON ’s husband drove Samuel PERSON to where his car was. In very little time, they returned with Samuel PERSON driving his own car.

Madeleine PERSON said nothing more to Arnisa PERSON , and she and Samuel PERSON drove silently back to Washington GPE . At her apartment, she got out without a word and did not hear Samuel PERSON say he was sorry. She opened the building’s front door and made sure it locked behind her. When she was back in her apartment, she looked out the window and found that the car had died on him once again. The car was parked in a space near the entrance to the parking lot with its hood up and Samuel PERSON was leaning into the car, a man being swallowed up. She lived on the second ORDINAL floor, facing the parking lot, and she could hear him and what he was doing. White people passed and paid no attention to him.

He worked late into the afternoon TIME , now and again stopping to try to start the car or to step back and stare at it as if some solution might rise up from the roof and announce itself. The day DATE was completely ruined for Madeleine PERSON , and throughout the afternoon TIME as her father worked she sat angry in the chair with its back to the window. That morning TIME she had looked forward to going to the deli down the street where she and Curtis NORP sometimes bought sandwiches and pastries. But she knew she could not go out with Samuel PERSON blocking the path to the deli and the deli would soon be closed. There were few cars or people passing, and most of the world was quiet. The loudest sounds were those of her father’s muttering and of his tools against the car’s metal, all of it reminding her, first ORDINAL before anything else, that the day DATE was forever wearing itself away.





LOST IN THE CITY




When the telephone rang about three o’clock that morning TIME , she sat bolt upright in her bed, as if a giant hand had reached through the ceiling and snatched her up. The man sleeping beside her did not stir until the seventh ORDINAL ring, and then only to ask “What? What?” of nothing in particular before returning to sleep. She first ORDINAL sat on the side of the bed and began to hope: a wrong number, or Gail PERSON , drunk, in from an evening TIME of bar-hopping, calling to talk about a man. She then sat in the dark on the floor in front of the nightstand. If it was true what her mother had once told her, then nothing rang the telephone like death in the middle of the night DATE .

On the fifteenth ORDINAL ring, she picked up the telephone and said nothing.

“Ms. Walsh PERSON ? Ms. Lydia Walsh PERSON ?” a woman said.

“Yes.”

“We are very sorry to call at such a time, but your mother died twenty minutes ago TIME .” The woman was waiting. “Ms. Walsh PERSON ?”

“Yes. I’ll be there soon as I can,” Lydia GPE said.

“Very well. We, the entire staff here at George Washington PERSON , are very sorry. Your mother was an exemplary patient,” the woman said. “We will expect you very soon.”

“ Listen WORK_OF_ART ,” Lydia GPE said. “Don’t…don’t put that sheet over her face until I get there, okay? I don’t want to walk in and see that sheet over her.”

“Very well,” the woman said. “We will expect you soon. And again, we at George Washington PERSON are very sorry.”

Lydia GPE hung up the telephone. She continued sitting on the floor and watched the clock that could tell her the time in the dark. The minute numbers on the clock moved ahead one CARDINAL , two CARDINAL , and then three more minutes TIME . Twenty minutes ago TIME , what had she been dreaming? Try to remember, she told herself, for all of it must go in the diary: On the night of June 29th TIME , I was dreaming such-and-such and such-and-such when my mother passed away. Try to remember where you were.

She tapped the base of the brass lamp once and the bulb’s lowest setting came on. The man in the bed was naked, as was she. There was a foreign smell about herself and she realized that it was his cologne, a popular and very expensive concoction that many of the men she knew wore because someone in their world had decided that the smell conveyed power and success. She thought she had been dreaming of Antibes ORG and the naked Texan NORP on the beach when her mother died, but the more she thought the more it seemed that Antibes PERSON had actually been on her mind when she came the first time hours ago TIME .

What is his name? she asked herself of the sleeping man. From a nightstand drawer she took one CARDINAL of the three CARDINAL appointment books she kept in the town house. On the June 29 DATE page there were the initials JL ORG scrawled across all the hours TIME after eight in the evening TIME . She remembered they had met at Trader Vic’s FAC for dinner after she had come from the hospital, and then they had come to her place. But what had she called him all those hours? She flipped back through the pages: “ Gyn-nw dia WORK_OF_ART ” on the 22nd morning; “B Kaufman— WORK_OF_ART Sen Fin PERSON ” lunch on the 20th DATE ; “ Taylor—Amer WORK_OF_ART . Con Life Bst WORK_OF_ART ” at two on the 19th afternoon TIME . Finally, on the evening of the 15th TIME , she found “Dinner and?????? with Jack Lawrence PERSON , Amer ORG . Bankers….”

“He’s pretty light-skinned, ain’t he?” her mother had said of the first ORDINAL boy she had ever slept with, though all her mother knew at that time was that the boy had taken her to a movie and Mile Long PERSON for a steak sandwich. “Does he come from a sickly family?” her mother had asked. She told her diary about the evening the boy busted her cherry: “The movie was Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf PERSON ? He told me that I was the most beautiful girl at Dunbar GPE , but when he walked me back home after the ‘dirty deed’ was done, he acted like he didn’t know me anymore.”

She shook Jack Lawrence PERSON from Amer GPE . Bankers, who was not light-skinned but the color of dark honey. He grabbed her hand and squeezed it so hard she thought she heard her bones cracking—in his sleep he had perceived some threat to himself. She screamed and he woke up, his hand still holding hers and his head turning about to find out where in the world he was. He released her and she rubbed her hand. “What the hell’s wrong with you?” she said.

“ Sorry…sorry WORK_OF_ART ,” he said. “I must have been dreaming.” The way he said “dreaming” prompted more details about him: Something he called fate had plucked him from the streets of Harlem LOC and sent him to Horace Mann PERSON prep, then sent him to Dartmouth ORG , then sent him to Harvard ORG Law. At their first ORDINAL dinner, he had said of the place where she had gone, “I would have gone to Yale Law PERSON , but there was something I didn’t like about the white guy that interviewed me.” “You okay?” he said now. He was still lying down.

“I’ll be all right. I have to go,” Lydia GPE said. “My mother has died and I have to go to her.”

“Oh, Cynthia PERSON , I’m very sorry.”

My name is Cynthia PERSON and I come from Washington GPE , she chanted in her head. What was that from? Jumping rope or playing hopscotch? He does not even know my name on the very night TIME my mother has died, she thought, wanting him out of her bed and out of her house. “You can get some sleep,” she said. “Make sure the door is locked when you leave.”

He yawned. “Yeah, I’m beat,” he said. The way he said “beat” brought more details about him. He turned over and pulled the sheet up to his shoulders. Even now, she thought that they were nice shoulders.

“I can’t believe I’m walkin the same paths that my Lord walked,” her mother had said that second ORDINAL day in Israel GPE , standing at the Church of Gethsemane ORG . Lydia GPE had presented the trip to her mother on her sixty-fifth CARDINAL birthday and had even paid the way for Georgia Evans ORG , her mother’s best friend. Lydia GPE had not wanted to go, but her mother had insisted. “Oh, Lydia GPE ,” her mother had said, “what would the Holy Land mean to me without you bein there with me?”

Georgia GPE , lazy, far less religious that her mother, had complained about all the hills. “How did Jesus PERSON get any preachin done goin up and down these hills?” she said the second day DATE . Georgia GPE would drink all the water she carried, then want more from Lydia GPE and her mother. “I never done so much walkin in all my life. Never drunk so much water either.” On the third day DATE , after the Via Dolorosa, Georgia GPE was unable to go on and spent the next days DATE moping about the hotel. “I never thought all I’d get to see of the Holy Land ORG was a big old hotel. Must be a sin in that somewhere.”

My mother lies moldering…

She tapped the base of the lamp three CARDINAL times and the bulb went through the rest of the settings, then the room went dark. In the living room, she knew she needed some coke. One CARDINAL line, she said to herself, one CARDINAL line and no more. This fur and no further. With the gold razor blade, she spread out the cocaine on the black marble tray, then inhaled a line of two inches QUANTITY or so through the crystal straw Gail Saunders PERSON had brought back from Bonn GPE . “I hereby make this oath, this pledge, this whatever,” Gail PERSON said the night TIME of her return. “I’ll sleep with no more white men. They make you feel like you should be grateful.”

In the shower, Lydia GPE held her face as close as she could to the nozzle. After she had finished, she soaped herself again. “Best get his smell off me,” she said to the water. “Or else when I walk in there, they’ll know I’ve been fucking. The nurses and doctors will look at me and they’ll say, ‘Why, Ms. Walsh PERSON , your mother lies moldering and you’ve been fucking.’”

“Forgive me, Father, for I have been fucking,” she said to the mirror as she toweled off. The exhaust fan made a low humming sound, barely audible even in the quiet of the night TIME . But though the repair people had been there four CARDINAL times, it was still too loud for her. “No sound,” she had said to the second ORDINAL repairman. “Absolutely no sound whatsoever. Can you manage that?” She did not want to go back to her bedroom, to her closet, so she dressed in the clothes she had returned home in the evening TIME before. They, the clothes, were scattered about the living room, where Amer ORG . Bankers ORG had taken her the first ORDINAL time and where Antibes PERSON had entered her head. That first ORDINAL Sunday DATE in Antibes GPE , she had done as the natives did and gone naked on the beach, and a stranger, the naked Texan NORP reading Ayn Rand PERSON , had said in the most exquisite French NORP that her breasts were perfect. Je m’appelle Lydia PERSON et j’babite a Washington GPE .

She called a Capitol FAC cab, because that was the company her mother had always used. “Trust Capitol to get you there and back in one CARDINAL piece,” her mother had said. “Don’t trust D.C. National ORG or Empire GPE .” Lydia GPE opened the front door and listened to the night sounds. She felt the coke was wearing off. Way off to the left, through the thick leaves of June DATE , she thought she saw the sun inching up, but she knew how deceptive the light in Washington GPE could be. Once, as a girl, she had traveled with her mother’s church through most of the night TIME to an edge-of-the-world mountain town in Virginia GPE , where the church members had held Easter PRODUCT sunrise services as the sun came up over the mountains. “We proclaim,” the preacher had said, “that Jesus PERSON has risen.” “We proclaim it so,” the congregation had said, huddled in blankets and covered with dew. “We proclaim it so.”

She did another line of cocaine. Her town house was in an enclosed area in Southwest LOC protected by a guard in his tiny house at the entrance. Generally, the guard would call to tell her that a cab was coming to her door, but she felt she might want to go out to the entrance and meet the cab. But then, as the coke flowed through her, she relaxed and thought it best for him to come and get her. “ Ten dollar MONEY tip,” she said to the marble tray and raised her eyebrows up and down several times. Before closing the crystal canister that contained the drug, she put some in a plastic packet with the small gold spoon she kept in the canister. “Who knows what evil lurks in a hospital,” she said, laughing.

On that sixth morning TIME in Israel GPE , Georgia GPE had gone back to her bed after breakfast and seemed unable to move, but she had insisted that Lydia GPE and her mother go on without her. When mother and daughter returned from floating on the Dead Sea LOC , they found Georgia GPE in a lounge chair at the swimming pool, descending into drunkenness, not quite certain who they were or where she was. When Lydia GPE ’s mother told her that she was in the Holy Land FAC , the land of Jesus PERSON , Georgia GPE said, “Yes. Yes. I been to that place.” Then, after Lydia GPE ’s mother slapped her, Georgia GPE asked her friend for forgiveness.

Back in the room the two CARDINAL older women shared, Lydia GPE had tried to reassure a sobbing Georgia GPE . Her mother refused to say anything more to Georgia GPE . “It’s all right,” Lydia GPE said to Georgia GPE as she put her to bed. The old woman kept saying that she was going to die in the Holy Land ORG and Lydia GPE kept telling her that she wouldn’t. They left her and had dinner in the hotel dining room, but her mother only picked at her food.

Georgia GPE was contrite throughout the last six days DATE , and though it was clear to Lydia GPE that the woman’s legs and feet could not manage it, Georgia GPE , uncomplaining, went out each day DATE for the rest of the tour. Each place along the way, in Jericho GPE , in Bethany GPE , in Nazareth LOC , she stayed close to Lydia GPE ’s mother, but Cornelia PERSON paid her no mind, and it showed on Georgia GPE ’s face.

On the living-room wall in Lydia GPE ’s town house, among the photographs of places she had visited around the world, between the pictures of her standing before the Kremlin ORG on a winter day DATE and of her in a cavernous room in a Danish NORP castle the guide said was haunted, there was the picture of Lydia GPE and Cornelia GPE and Georgia GPE standing where the tourist bureau said Joseph PERSON ’s carpentry shop had been, Georgia GPE in her hideous wig standing on one CARDINAL side and her mother in the middle. It was the tenth day DATE of the trip.

She did two CARDINAL more lines of cocaine. “ Just a shorty shorty this time TIME , girl,” she said as she spread out the drug. All of this and more I offer to you if you would but bow down and worship me….

She did not know how long the cab driver had been standing in the doorway when he said, “Lady, you call for a cab?” He was an old man who had probably done nothing but work all his life. Father, may I?…What would that old man have said to see her perfect breasts adorning the beach at Antibes GPE ? Have you seen the Egyptian NORP pyramids? the naked Texan NORP asked, fingering the pages of Ayn Rand PERSON .

“Yes,” she said to the old man, sounding as if there had been a death in the family. “It’s for me. My mother has died.” Immediately, he took off his hat and made the sign of the cross. She stood and put her things, including the packet of cocaine, into the Fendi PERSON bag.

“My heart goes out to you, lady,” the cab driver said. “It really does. I know what it’s like to lose a mother. And a father too.” Through the screen door, he looked about the room as if there might be others to whom he should express condolences.

At the door, she could see that he was not just an old man, but an extremely old man. Her father, had he lived, would have been such a man. She closed the door and locked it. The sounds of birds were louder, and she knew the sun was not far off. The old man helped her down the three CARDINAL brick stairs and held the cab door for her. She had wanted to buy a second ORDINAL town house in the area as another investment and have her mother and Georgia GPE live there, but her mother told her that she did not know if she could live among so many white people. “I’m not used to their ways and such like you are, Lydia GPE ,” and Lydia GPE had been offended.

The old man drove out of the compound and turned right on G Street FAC . He was looking at her in the rearview mirror. She smelled dead fish from the wharf. At 7th ORDINAL the man turned right again. “I knew folks who lived in Southwest LOC before they threw the colored out and made it for the wealthy,” her mother had said when Lydia GPE told her she had bought a town house there.

“Ma’am, maybe you should tell me where you goin?” the cab driver said.

“Just get me lost in the city,” she said.

“What, ma’am?”

“Just keep on driving and get us lost in the city. I’ll pay you. I have the money.”

“No, ma’am, it ain’t a matter of money. I just thought…. You know, your mother…. And besides, ma’am, I’m a Capitol FAC cabdriver and I ain’t allowed to get lost.”

“Try,” she said. “Try ever so hard.” She took two CARDINAL twenty-dollar MONEY bills from her bag, leaned forward and placed them on the seat beside him. “And the more lost you get us, the more you get paid. Or is it, the more loster, or the most lost? There are, you know, Mr. Cab Driver PERSON , so many grammatical rules that the grammar people say we must not break.”

“Yes, ma’am, I know. I’ve heard it said.”

He did not know what else to do, so he continued driving. He passed the federal buildings along 7th ORDINAL , then the mall and its museums. In one CARDINAL of the museums white men had allowed her father to make a living pushing a broom, and now she was paid in one year DATE more than her parents had earned in both their lifetimes. Soon, she would pass a point in her life where she would have earned more than all her ancestors put together, all of them, all the way back to Eve PERSON .

At New York Avenue FAC , he turned right, then left on 5th Street FAC . He thought that maybe she had been born elsewhere, that she did not know Washington GPE , would not know the streets beyond what the white people called the federal enclave. But in fact, the farther north he went, the more she knew about where they were going. My name is Lydia GPE …. Say it loud….

“You gettin us lost?”

“Yes, ma’am, I’m tryin.”

“All right. Try very hard.” She placed another twenty CARDINAL beside the other two CARDINAL .

They passed where the K Street market once had been. Two pounds QUANTITY of chicken wings for twenty cents MONEY . Had she remembered to finally write down her mother’s recipe for that wondrous beef stew somewhere in one of the appointment books? They continued on up 5th Street FAC . Her father had died at 1122 5th Street TIME in a back room on the top floor where they had lived when she was four CARDINAL . It occurred to Lydia GPE that in the world there was now no one from whom she could get that full medical history she had always planned to get. Who now could tell her if there was a history of breast cancer among the women in her family?

“I’m sorry for all this,” her father had said on his death bed to her mother. “I’m very sorry for all this, Cornelia GPE .” They had not known that she was standing in the doorway watching them.

“For what?” her mother said to her father. “What’s there to be sorry about? You do know that I love you. You do know that, don’t you? If you go away with nothin else, go away with that.”

At 5th ORDINAL and Ridge GPE streets, she asked the cab driver, “Hi you doin up there, buddy? You doin okay?”

“Yes, ma’am, just fine, thank you.”

While living at 457 CARDINAL Ridge Street FAC , in the downstairs apartment, they had come to know Georgia GPE , who lived in the upstairs apartment. Georgia GPE would never have children of her own and, except for Lydia GPE , was uncomfortable around other people’s children. Until Lydia GPE , was fourteen DATE , she gave her a doll every Christmas DATE . “Now see, if you pull the string Chatty Cathy PERSON will talk to you, honey. Tell Chatty Cathy PERSON your name, honey.” “My name is Lydia Walsh PERSON and I live in Washington GPE .”

The sun was even higher when he turned right at O Street. In one CARDINAL of the houses on that street her mother lived until Lydia GPE ’s last year DATE of law school. She had once brought down from New Haven GPE a professor of linguistics who thought the sun rose and set on her. He had had a kind heart, the professor had, but his love for her had shown through all too clearly, and that was his downfall. For thirty days DATE during the month DATE of her birthday he had sent her the reddest roses she had seen up to then: one CARDINAL on the first day DATE , two CARDINAL on the second day DATE , three CARDINAL on the third ORDINAL , and so on. “How much do professors of linguistics make?” she asked a friend on the twentieth day DATE , looking down at his name on the card that came with the roses. “Does he come from a sickly family?” her mother had asked while the man was in the bathroom.

She wanted more coke and she began to cry. “And first ORDINAL prize, for her particularly beautiful enunciation, goes to….” John Brown PERSON lies molderin where my mother lies molderin…. The cab driver thought that her crying meant that maybe it had finally hit her that her mother had died and that soon his passenger would be coming to herself.

At New Jersey Avenue FAC , the cab driver turned left, then right at Rhode Island GPE down past Frazier PERSON ’s Funeral Home. At a large apartment building on Rhode Island GPE where the Safeway FAC now stood, they had lived on the same floor as a woman who was terrified that her husband would leave her. “So all the time bein scared of him leavin,” her mother told Lydia GPE years later DATE when she thought her daughter was old enough to understand, “she just became his slave. He was a night foreman at a bakery way out in Northeast LOC . I guess some thought he was a handsome man, but I never cared for him. Had what they call that good hair. Night and day DATE she worried that he’d leave her. She begged me and all the other women not to take him from her. She wouldn’t believe that I whatn’t studyin bout him. She worried herself sick and they came and took her away to St. Lizabeths GPE one day DATE . In those days DATE , they gave you twenty-five dollars MONEY if you turned in a crazy person. Twenty-five dollars MONEY and a pat on the back. Somebody turned her in, but it whatn’t me.”





HIS MOTHER’S HOUSE ORG




When his mother moved into that 10th Street FAC house Santiago Moses FAC bought for her, one CARDINAL of the few things she brought from the place she left behind was the coffee table made of see-through glass and false wood. And once in the house he bought, in the renovated house, one CARDINAL of her pleasures in the first weeks DATE was watching the neighbors watch as the trucks came to deliver furniture, some of it still in sealed boxes and crates, brand new furniture and appliances that no other woman in the world had lived with. In the midst of all the new that her son bought for her—the living room couch itself cost as much as all the furniture in the place she left behind—she put the coffee table that had been owned by God knows how many people before she herself bought it in that second ORDINAL -hand store on H Street FAC in Northeast LOC and had her man rope it to the roof of his eleven-year-old DATE Chevy ORG .

Her whole life, in dozens CARDINAL of pictures, could be seen through the glass top of that old coffee table, and that was what she told her son.

“Oh, don’t give me that stuff, Mama,” Santiago GPE told her two months DATE or so after she had moved in, “go back to Levitt ORG ’s. Go back to Woodie ORG ’s. You can find somethin somewhere that’ll be better than this piece of shit.” He was sitting on the leather couch beside Rickey Madison PERSON and her son leaned forward and knocked twice on the top of the table. It was along about midnight TIME .

“Stop,” Joyce Moses PERSON said, “you’ll break the glass.” But her words lacked the scolding force of the old days DATE , and she giggled and put both hands to her mouth and shook herself: She was still exhilarated by the new world her son had bought for her, and, in any case, one CARDINAL more crack in the top wouldn’t have been the end. Her two CARDINAL younger children were upstairs, asleep in oaken beds, safer than they had ever been in their lives. Santiago Moses ORG watched his mother, then he gave the table another playful tap. He was twenty years old DATE .

“Nope nope nope,” Joyce PERSON said. “Don’t want another table.” She had been drinking, but “only a teensy-weensy bit a wine,” as she told Rickey PERSON after he arrived with Santiago GPE . The carpet was down, having been installed throughout the house before she and Rickey PERSON and her two CARDINAL younger children moved in, but much of the new furniture had yet to be arranged in the rooms just as she wanted. There was no hurry. She sat on the floor, leaning back on her arms, her toes disappearing into the carpet. “With all this other stuff, don’t you think if I’da wanted another coffee table, I woulda gone out and ordered it?”

“It’s a gotdamn shame to buy the best and then have this shit sittin in the middle of all the good stuff,” Santiago ORG said. He laughed. “We can give this old one to the poor,” and he laughed again. His feet were propped on the edge of the coffee table, and as he laughed he stretched his legs out over the table and shook them up and down.

“He’s right, honey,” Rickey PERSON said. He had been her common-law husband for six years DATE . “Better find somethin new. We can look next week DATE .”

Santiago ORG stopped laughing and turned to Rickey ORG . “My mother’s old anough to know what she want. She ain’t nobody’s child, Rickey PERSON . She don’t need nobody tellin her what to do.”

“I didn’t mean anything by it, Sandy PERSON . Why you gettin all upset again? Sides, I think I should be able to tell my own woman somethin.”

“ Rickey WORK_OF_ART , you can’t tell nobody shit! Just do what I tell you and keep your mouth shut.”

“All right now, you two CARDINAL ,” Joyce PERSON said. “I don’t want yall startin nothin.” She stood up quickly, for this was how the last fight started. “All right. All right. This conversation’s closed far as I’m concerned, cause I’m keepin this table and thas all there is to it. Why yall wanna go and spoil a good time?”

“We gotta be goin anyway,” Santiago ORG said.

She walked them to the door, and Santiago GPE kissed her cheek, the same kind of peck he had been giving her since he was months DATE old. He turned up his jacket collar and went out the wooden and iron-bar doors and down the steps to his Range Rover. Rickey PERSON kissed her mouth. “See you later, baby,” he said. He whispered that she should get a new table and she gave him a playful push.

“ C’mon WORK_OF_ART ,” Santiago ORG said, “You know what she taste like by now. I ain’t got all night TIME .”

The layered curtains were now up, and she parted them and watched her son and husband ride away down 10th Street FAC . She continued to stand by at the window. She loved this time most, the hours TIME when her house and all that was in it seemed to conspire with the quiet and envelop her. She had, while still in the old place, passed this house a million times, when it had contained a horrible family of loud people. Back then, she would have bet the souls of her children if someone had told her that one day the house would be made over and then hold her and her family.

She turned out the lamp beside her, and by and by she saw a form across the street peel away from a huge shadow, take the shape of a man, and walk toward the house. Before the man was midway across the street, she could see, in the walk without purpose, in the thinness, that it was Humphrey PERSON , her godson. For a minute TIME or so, he stood in the middle of the empty street and looked up and down, his hand shading his eyes as if it were the middle of a very sunny day.

“Mama Joyce PERSON , it’s so good to see you,” Humphrey PERSON said, holding on to the banister with both hands as he made his way up the stairs. She opened the wooden door wider. “ Sandy PERSON here?” He smiled through the iron-bar door, then he began to laugh, and she saw that he was out of his head again.

“ Sandy PERSON just left,” she said and opened the iron-bar door. “He might be back fore long. Come on in, sweetie.” She did not bother to ask why he was across the street, as if he had been waiting, because she knew she would not have received an answer that meant anything.

“Mama Joyce PERSON , I can’t stay.” He laughed. “Could I just leave some money here for you to give him?” He stepped into her house.

“Now, honey, you know I don’t handle any money for Sandy PERSON . You gotta take that up with him.”

He blinked uncontrollably, then turned his head and looked at something invisible beside him. He laughed again, then he turned back to Joyce PERSON . “It’s all right, Mama Joyce PERSON . I told him…I said, I said, ‘I’m gonna leave it with her just this one time.’”

“You sure bout that?”

“Please, Mama Joyce PERSON . Please please. Pretty please with sugar on top.” He giggled.

“All right, you crazy thing. Just this once.” She shut the iron-bar door, listening for the click that told her it was secured, and then locked the wooden door. The world was not a safe place, Rickey PERSON kept telling her. Humphrey PERSON handed her a folded lump of bills. “Wow,” she said, “nough to choke a horse.”

He looked intently at the money. “It’s never enough,” he said, and for a second ORDINAL or so he straightened himself up. “But you tell him, Mama Joyce PERSON , you tell him I’ll get the rest to him as soon as I can. Sooner than soon.”

“You hungry?” She took off his baseball cap and ran her hand through his hair, something Santiago GPE would no longer let her do. “You need a haircut. You want somethin to eat?”

He shook his head and then stared at her as if he were trying to remember something. “I ain’t hungry, Mama Joyce PERSON . Thanks all the same.” He continued to stare. “Gettin in shape. Gettin in shipshape.” He began to box with the invisible something beside him. “We gettin in shape, ain’t we?” he said to the thing. “Ain’t we gettin in shape?”

Finally, he sat on the couch. Joyce PERSON put the money on the coffee table and the wad began to unfold. In little or no time, Humphrey PERSON had tumbled over and was asleep. A few tiny, clear packets fell out of his jacket pocket onto the floor. She picked up the packets and placed them on the coffee table. She could have counted on one hand the times she had seen the stuff, but each time she did, the cream-colored nuggets always reminded her of small chunks of white Argo starch she had eaten when she was pregnant.
