From the hall closet, she took new sheets from their wrappings and covered him, then put a couch pillow under his head. In his sleep, he was laughing again. “He uses more of the stuff than he sells,” she had once overheard Santiago tell Rickey ORG .

She unlaced Humphrey ORG ’s tennis shoes and discovered that they were the same pump kind Santiago GPE had bought for her other son. She pushed the air-release button and thought she could hear the hissing of the escaping air. She set the shoes under the couch.

“ Two-hundred-dollar CARDINAL shoes,” she said, “and holes in his socks.” She and Humphrey PERSON ’s mother, Pearl Malone PERSON , had been like sisters since they were ten years old DATE . They had, at seventeen DATE , given birth to their oldest sons, Santiago GPE and Humphrey ORG , within three weeks DATE of each other.

Joyce PERSON sat across from Humphrey PERSON in what the store salesman had called a Queen Anne PERSON chair. One CARDINAL of her legs was resting across a chair arm, an old habit she was trying to break in the new house. She watched the sleeping boy and listened to the grandfather clock in the hall. Before Santiago GPE and Humphrey PERSON were born, Joyce PERSON and Pearl PERSON had decided to share an apartment to save on the money they would get from public assistance. They discovered, a week or so DATE after Humphrey PERSON was born, that Pearl PERSON ’s milk had mysteriously dried up, and Pearl PERSON became convinced that without her milk, her son would grow up without immunity.

“Oh, girl, you worry too much” Joyce PERSON told her one morning TIME in a splendid June DATE . “They makin formula and stuff thas just as good as breast milk.”

“ Joyce PERSON , I don’t wanna feed my baby outa no box.” They were in their kitchen and Pearl PERSON , standing at the stove, was reading aloud every word on the box of formula. Then she held it to her ear and shook it, as if just the sound of the contents was evidence of a lack of something vital. “He’ll get all those diseases. I read about it.” The babies were in plastic carriers, setting on the table. Santiago GPE was asleep and Humphrey PERSON was watching Joyce PERSON , who sat playing with his hair.

In the end, Joyce PERSON offered to feed Humphrey PERSON from her own breasts. And for the six months or so DATE Pearl PERSON felt it took to give Humphrey PERSON protection against the world’s diseases, Joyce PERSON would take him up and put him to her breast. “I’m gonna teach him to call you Mama Joyce PERSON ,” Pearl PERSON said, wiping sweat from her brow one day DATE in the crushing humidity of August DATE .



In the very center of Joyce PERSON ’s coffee table, under the see-through glass, were pictures of her children and Pearl PERSON ’s as babies. Chubby-cheeked beings looking off to the side uninterestedly, or looking dead at the camera eye as if to challenge. Surrounding those pictures were photographs of the children in later years DATE , and surrounding those were pictures of Joyce PERSON ’s parents and aunts and uncles and the children of her friends. There were pictures of her and Rickey PERSON together, arms around each other, and there were pictures of her alone, at the beach, at parties, sitting with crossed legs on the hoods of boyfriends’ cars. In the top left-hand corner of the glass, there were cracks of one or two inches QUANTITY , radiating out, like the sun’s rays in a child’s drawing. Santiago GPE , not long after they bought the table, had promised that if the cracks got any longer he would use his summer job money to replace the entire glass.



About two that morning TIME Santiago GPE called. The telephone sounded with the most unobtrusive chime she had been able to find. She was on the second ORDINAL floor, in the room she had furnished with such care and set aside for her mother, who would not ever step foot in her daughter’s house. When she told Santiago GPE that Humphrey PERSON was there, he told her not to let Humphrey PERSON leave. “I been lookin for his bony ass for two whole days DATE ,” he said.

“He downstairs sleepin,” Joyce PERSON said, “and I don’t think he goin anywhere.” She wanted to know where Rickey PERSON was, why he wasn’t home yet, and Santiago PERSON told her that he would send Rickey PERSON home soon and that he himself would be staying at his Capitol Heights ORG apartment if she needed him.

She had little use for sleep anymore, and after the call, she roamed the house with all the lights turned out, something she often did, even when Rickey PERSON was home. She and Pearl PERSON had shared poor-women dreams of living in a place like this, with furniture no one else in the whole world had ever used. As she walked about the dark house, she liked to remember what she and Pearl PERSON had said once upon a time, remember how painful it could be just to dream. Then, her mind would leap to now and she would touch something, the grandfather clock, the shelves of food in the pantry, the drawer of brassieres still with their price tags, the silver racing bicycle her youngest son was too small to ride.

About three CARDINAL that morning TIME , while Joyce PERSON stood looking out the third ORDINAL -floor hall window, Humphrey PERSON got up and stumbled out. She got downstairs and found the iron-bar and wooden doors open to the world. She discovered later that he had taken the money. Toward three thirty TIME , Rickey PERSON , nearly dead on his feet, finally came home. She fixed him a sandwich with thick slices of ham and then sat across the kitchen table from him, sipping a beer. “What a way to pay the rent,” he kept saying between bites. She helped him upstairs and into bed. Then she roamed the house some more until about four CARDINAL thirty, when she came to bed and curled up close to him. But she could not sleep because she kept thinking she had not locked all the windows and doors.



The pictures of her mother started in the center of the coffee table display. Her mother rarely smiled in the photographs and she often looked into the camera as if the eye had caught her doing something God would not approve of. “I just don’t take the good pictures,” her mother had said when she saw the display at the apartment Joyce PERSON had left behind.

The pictures of Rickey ORG began under the see-through glass more or less where the photographs of Santiago GPE at ten CARDINAL began. Rickey PERSON did not like having his picture taken, and so most of the photos were of him in unguarded moments. One was taken at somebody’s house during Christmas DATE . The camera had caught him with his mouth parted in a small O and the camera had given him red eyes. Rickey ORG ’s pictures had replaced those of the two CARDINAL men who had fathered her three CARDINAL children. He was the first ORDINAL man in her life who had never beaten her. And for a long time she thought that because he did not beat her, he did not care for her as much and that one morning TIME she would wake up and, like the others, he would be gone.



Before Rickey Madison PERSON became a driver and bodyguard for Santiago Moses ORG , he worked construction. The work was steady enough so that at least once a week he could take Joyce PERSON and her children to the Flagship on the wharf. One evening TIME two years or so DATE before, they came out of the restaurant and found that Rickey ORG ’s Chevy ORG wouldn’t start. Rickey PERSON , after spending more than half CARDINAL an hour under the hood, stepped away from the car with resignation and spat into the gutter. Joyce PERSON watched him. He was the kind of man who had nightmares about not getting to work on time. Santiago GPE , laughing, made the sign of the cross over the car.

“What the hell you laughin at, boy?” Rickey PERSON said. Clovis, Joyce PERSON ’s little girl, came up to him and put her hand in his.

“You,” Santiago ORG said. “You look like you don’t know whether to shoot that thing or beg it for another chance.” He put his arm around Rickey PERSON ’s shoulder, for by then Santiago GPE was a head taller than the man.

“You think this so damn funny, huh?” Rickey PERSON said. “If I can’t get to work in the mornin, you may not eat next week DATE .” Joyce PERSON worked as a home care aide, but it was Rickey ORG ’s money that kept the family going.

“Oh, I’ll eat all right,” Santiago ORG said. He took several new bills from his pocket. “ Next week DATE , and the week DATE after that, and the one after that, and all the ones after that too.” He stuck some of the money in Rickey PERSON ’s pocket. “Take a cab to work tomorrow DATE .”

“It probably some play money,” Clovis PERSON said.

“Play money my ass,” Santiago ORG said. He had not come to the restaurant that evening TIME with the rest of the family. And when he did arrive, he was accompanied by a woman who must have been at least ten years DATE older than he. The woman had brought along her son, about three or four years old CARDINAL . “Play money my ass,” the woman said.

Rickey ORG counted the money, then he counted it twice more, spread it fanlike and turned to show it to Joyce PERSON . “Look,” he said to her. “Look at this.” He said to Santiago GPE , “You hit the number or somethin, boy?”

“God provides,” Santiago GPE said. “God is good.” He said to the woman, “ Ain’t WORK_OF_ART that right, baby?” She sidled up to Santiago GPE and began to giggle. The woman wore a low-cut blue dress and a gold crucifix on a gold chain around her neck, and all through dinner Joyce PERSON had looked at the cross resting between the woman’s breasts. “God is everything,” Santiago ORG said. “God is good.”

The moment Joyce PERSON had seen the woman walk into the restaurant, she knew she would not like her, knew the woman had been doing things with her son. Santiago continued on about God and goodness, and the woman leaned herself and her breasts against him. “Now why don’t you go find a cab so you can take the family home,” Santiago PERSON told Rickey ORG . Rickey PERSON , without words, went off to look for a cab. “Me and Tamara gon take her car.” The woman’s little boy, looking at Rickey ORG walk away, sat down on the sidewalk with a very loud sigh, as if he thought there would be much more talking and he may as well wait until it was all over.

In the cab, Joyce PERSON , seeing how happy Rickey PERSON was, told the cab driver to take the long way back to their apartment.

The next time Joyce PERSON saw the boy and his mother, it was the day DATE after they had delivered the pool table for the basement in the new house. The woman had reached through the iron-bar door and knocked at the wooden door, and she was about to knock again when Joyce PERSON opened the door.

“You tell Sandy PERSON he can have him,” the woman said to Joyce PERSON . She took one CARDINAL of the boy’s hands and wrapped his fingers around one CARDINAL of the bars. “This is my settlement for all the money I owe him.” In his other hand, the boy was holding a little car, and leaning against his leg was a small suitcase held together with rope. “You tell him he can stop buggin me now bout what I owe him. Mark me down paid in full. And tell him to send me a receipt care of General Delivery.” She went clackety-clack down the stairs in her high heels, wobbling the way Joyce PERSON had seen Humphrey PERSON wobble, and the boy began to cry. “Shut up, gotdamnit! Shut up, I said!” She was down the street before Joyce PERSON could collect herself to say anything.

“Hey! Hey! Wait a minute! Whas goin on here!” Joyce PERSON opened the iron-bar door, nearly knocking the boy down the steps. “Come back here!” The woman was nearing O Street. “ Sweet Jesus PERSON ,” Joyce PERSON said to herself. Had she not been in her bathrobe she would have run after the woman. “What are you doin?”

The boy was still crying. “Well, I don’t love you neither!” he yelled to his mother as she turned the corner, and then he threw the car in her direction. “And I never even did.”

When Santiago PERSON called that afternoon TIME , he told his mother it would be all right, that the boy would be gone by the evening TIME . “The dopey bitch just made a mistake, thas all,” he said. But the boy, Adam PERSON , stayed three weeks DATE , and no one ever again saw his mother. He was a silent presence in the house and never caused Joyce PERSON a moment’s problem. Whatever Joyce PERSON told him to do, he did without question or sass. He had retrieved the car the first day DATE , and for all those three weeks DATE , he mostly sat out of the way in a corner of the living room, rolling the car back and forth. The carpet was too thick for the car to move very far on its own, and the boy usually pushed it all the way. Unlike other boys she had known, he did not make car sounds as he moved it. By the time the city government woman had come to get him, Joyce PERSON had given him a piece of her heart. The city government woman, who quickly produced a large red sucker as if she expected trouble from Adam PERSON , spoke college-people English LANGUAGE and double-parked in front of the house. The city government woman took him by the hand, and the boy did not say good-bye and he did not cry. Quite often after that, after Santiago GPE had released Rickey for the night and Joyce WORK_OF_ART had curled up beside him in their bed, she would see Adam PERSON in her dreams. But in the dreams he was always a grown man and he would somehow come through the iron bars of one CARDINAL of the basement windows in the dead of night TIME , and when, in the dark, they came upon each other, in the kitchen, on the stairs, in one of the children’s rooms, she did not understand why she was not afraid of him.



“I guess he must get that kinda PERSON need from you, cause he done gone and bought a house in Fort Washington GPE ,” Rickey PERSON said to Joyce PERSON one evening TIME , nearly a year DATE after they had moved into the house. They were in their second ORDINAL -floor bedroom, in their pajamas on the bed, the way Joyce PERSON liked to relax with Rickey PERSON after her two CARDINAL youngest children were asleep in their beds on the third ORDINAL floor. For a change, Santiago GPE had let him go early. Rickey PERSON was leaning back against the headboard and Joyce PERSON was lying across the foot of the bed, and in front of her were a beer and her cigarettes and an ashtray on a bamboo tray that could not be tipped over. “I guess he’ll be invitin you and the kids out to see it soon.” This was how she received most of the news about Santiago GPE , in bits and chunks from Rickey EVENT when the day DATE was all but over.

“You look so tired, baby,” she said. “Why don’t you lay down and let me give you one of my special back rubs?”

“I don’t want nobody’s gotdamn back rub!”

“Well, you sure look like you could use one.” When he moved his head, she could see that it was making a greasy spot on the white headboard. She considered what it would take to remove the spot. The day before DATE , he had accidentally dropped a lighted cigarette on the carpet in the hall and she had cursed him for being careless.

“You know what I saw last week DATE ?” he said. He took a swig from his own beer on the nightstand.

“No, baby, what did you see last week DATE ?”

He did not like the way she said that, and at first ORDINAL he thought he would just shut her out and turn over and go to sleep. But soon he said, “I saw the most money I ever seen in my whole life.” He suppressed a belch. He squinted, gazed at the bedspread as if the memory of the money were now a scene unfolding in the spread’s pattern of palm trees and sand and birds in flight. “And it was in a room with a few kids that couldn’t a been no more than thirteen CARDINAL , fourteen years old DATE . They was playin this big radio that was sittin in the windowsill and they all knew the songs that was playin on the radio, and every time a song came on they would sing along, like they was at camp or somethin. They were at this big round table, countin that money and laughin and havin all the fun in the world like they were just countin so many leaves and it wouldn’t be anything if it all blew away.” He yawned. “So much money that it musta been some kinda GPE sin just to have it at one time in a place that wasn’t a bank. Some house in Northeast LOC , maybe it was Southwest LOC . One CARDINAL place is gettin to be like another now. ‘Drive me here, Rickey PERSON .’ ‘Drive me there, Rickey PERSON .’”

Joyce PERSON took a sip of beer and lit another cigarette.

“I thought you was gonna quit them things,” Rickey PERSON said. She could tell one CARDINAL of his drunk spells was coming on.

“You member: I told you the first of the month. Don’t you remember? I promise.” She could tell he didn’t believe her.

Rickey PERSON said: “All the men there ever was in my family, that’ll ever be in my family, each one could work day and night for a thousand years DATE , and all the money they would make would never come close to what I saw in that room. I can still hear some a those songs that was on the radio, and I can tell you some a the words.” He sang one CARDINAL of the songs.

“You ready for that back rub now, sugar?”

He yawned again, then inspected his fingernails and slid farther down in the bed. “I forgot to tell you that day fore yesterday I finally got a look at this Smokey Peebles FAC . Himself. The William ‘Smokey’ Peebles everybody talks about. After all this time, I guess Sandy PERSON trust me enough.” Despite Joyce PERSON ’s pleadings, he refused to wear the silk pajamas she bought for him. The cotton and synthetic ones, he told her, didn’t let him slide off the bed as the silk ones did. “Gimme a sip.” He reached for Joyce PERSON ’s beer.

“You got your own.” She lit another cigarette. “ Rickey PERSON , why you gotta always bring that stuff home? Those people don’t interest me in the least. I thought we was gonna have a nice evenin, just me and you, baby.” She was afraid he might start pouting, as he now did more and more when he was drunk, and to head him off, she pushed the tray out of the way and crawled up the bed and put her arms around him. “All right,” she said. “I’m sorry. So this was the one himself, huh?”

He was silent for a long time and she reached into his underwear and stroked him.

“Not right now,” he said, taking her hand out. “Besides it don’t seem to be doin the job anyway.”

“You gotta be patient,” Joyce PERSON said. “Thas the thing bout makin babies. It helps if thas the last thing on your mind. Makin em. Then they come one two CARDINAL just like that.”

Rickey PERSON said, “ Sandy PERSON had me drive him to this place off Florida Avenue FAC , to some kinda FAC old-fashioned drug store. But they didn’t have a pharmacy or nothin like that. It was mostly just a soda fountain and some booths. A few tables and chairs, just like in those old black-and-white movies.” She put her hand inside the shirt of his pajamas and stroked his chest; sometimes there was nothing to do but ride the whole thing out.

“I could tell that Sandy’d been there before, just from the way he gave me directions,” Rickey PERSON said. “When they let us in, Sandy PERSON goes to the counter and sits down beside this little boy, who was drinkin a milkshake all slurpy-loud and everything. I stood near the big front window, just like he told me to. There was two CARDINAL men I’d seen someplace else before standin near the front door, and there was a large man in one CARDINAL of the booths sittin across from this very pretty woman who was drinkin a big milkshake just like the little boy. This big fella had on the best-lookin suit I’d ever seen, the kinda ORG suit I want you to bury me in when I pop off. Sandy PERSON was steady-talkin to this little boy and I just kept lookin at Smokey GPE , at that big back a his. It made me nervous at first ORDINAL to be near somebody they say had killed three CARDINAL men. The woman he was talkin to had on a lot of makeup and she was more interested in the milkshake than whatever it was Smokey LOC was sayin to her.”

Joyce PERSON continued to stroke his chest and threw her leg over his thighs. “ Shoulda PERSON went up and introduced yourself,” she said. “‘I heard so much about you, Mr. Peebles PERSON . Can I call you Smokey PERSON ?’”

Rickey PERSON smiled. He said, “There was an old white man in a nice clean apron behind the fountain and he had one a those old-timey soda jerk hats on. He held up one CARDINAL a those metal glasses they useta make milkshakes in and he shook it at me, wantin PERSON to know if I wanted one. I shook my head. There wasn’t nobody else in the place but these people, and no aisles with soap and toothpaste and aspirin GPE and whatnot, and I gradually got the feelin PRODUCT that this white man’s one job in life was to make milkshakes and banana splits and everything for whoever big Smokey GPE told him to.”

The grandfather clock in the hall downstairs struck ten CARDINAL , and Joyce PERSON lifted her head momentarily from Rickey ORG ’s chest to listen for Clovis PERSON getting up and going to the bathroom.

“At the last, this little boy Sandy PERSON had been talkin to turned in his seat and hopped away from the stool. He twisted his body around without movin his feet to see how far he’d hopped away from the seat. Then he wiped his mouth with the back of his hand. He came toward the door and everybody jumped up, includin Sandy PERSON . One CARDINAL a those guys opened the door. The boy stuck out his hand to me, and I could see that he wasn’t a boy atall. ‘You Rickey ORG , huh?’ he said. ‘I’m Smokey. Smokey Peebles PERSON . You keep watchin out for my boy there. There’s some bad shit in the world, y’know, and I don’t want my boy hurt.’ He pointed over his shoulder to Sandy PERSON . ‘He my righthand man.’ I just shook his hand, cause I didn’t know what to say. ‘How you like my tennis shoes,’ he said. ‘They Chuck Taylors. Converse. Thas all I wear is Chuck Taylors PERSON .’ He just went on like me and him was old walk partners and like the only important thing in the world to him was what kinda tennis PERSON shoes he wore. The fella who’d opened the door closed it, seein that Smokey LOC wasn’t headin out. I could see some children gatherin at the door. ‘When I was a little boy,’ Smokey GPE was sayin, ‘ Chuck Taylor PERSON was the thing. Every boy had to have Chuck Taylors PERSON . They were like ten dollars MONEY or somethin back then, but that was a whole lotta money. My mama—I’ll never forget this—my mama got me these cheap-ass three-dollar MONEY tennis shoes from Becker ORG ’s on 7th Street FAC . You know how mamas can be. If you saw those tennis shoes like from a mile QUANTITY away you’d think they were Chuck Taylors PERSON , but up close, even a blind man could tell you they was just imitation. And people, my own friends now, got on my shit about it too, stomped all over my feelins. Every time I wore them they’d like come up to me, bend down, and point real close at these imitation Chuck Taylors PERSON .’”

Rickey ORG reached over and drank the last of his beer in one CARDINAL swig. “I think he musta been twenty-five CARDINAL or somethin like that, and all he was talkin about was those damn tennis shoes. This woman at the booth came out and zipped up his jacket. Then I saw that she wasn’t really a woman but a girl, maybe eight, nine years old DATE , and I thought I was gonna be sick. She had on high heels and big earrings and a short dress and a painted face that made you wanna cry. She moved like every move she had learned by practicin, like maybe she’d studied how to move like a real woman while standin in front a some big mirror. She put her arm through Smokey GPE ’s, just like they was man and wife or somethin. Smokey GPE was steady talkin. ‘Now all I wear is Chuck Taylor PERSON tennis shoes. High-tops, low-tops, red, yellow, gold, green, purple. All colors. Even the regular white or the black ones. Guys all over the world wearing hundred-dollar MONEY , two-hundred-dollar CARDINAL , three-hundred-dollar CARDINAL tennis shoes and me—I’m happy with some of the cheapest on the market. No pump, no flyin; just me and Chuck PERSON .’

“The guy opened the door again, and everybody followed him on out. The big man who’d been in the booth started to open the back door of this Mercedes ORG for him, but Smokey ORG said, ‘Oh, no. I feel like tryin out my drivin muscles.’ And he raised his arms and flexed his muscles. One CARDINAL man took this thick pad of foam and put it in the driver’s seat. All these kids was crowdin round Smokey LOC , and one CARDINAL of the fellas with Smokey GPE started throwin change in the air and the shit came down on some a their heads, but the kids didn’t care cause it was money. ‘Yall stay off dope, you hear me?’ Smokey PERSON told em. ‘Yall stay off dope. Stay away from that mess. And stay in school. Stay in school.’ All the kids knew his name and they started singin what he’d just said. Made up a little song right there on the spot. The white man in that apron came to the window and started wavin to nobody in particular. Then I heard him lock the door and I could see the shades comin down.”

When the telephone chimed, Joyce PERSON was dozing. Rickey PERSON picked up the entire telephone and handed it to her. She sat up and blinked herself wide awake. “ Pearl PERSON ? Pearl PERSON , what is it?” she said after a bit. “Stop cryin now, honey, and tell me whas wrong.”

Rickey PERSON went downstairs to get more beer because the tiny refrigerator in their bedroom had conked out the day before DATE . When he returned, Joyce PERSON was wetting her finger and rubbing it on the greasy spot on the headboard.

“What Pearl PERSON squawkin about?”

“ Somethin about Humphrey WORK_OF_ART owin Sandy money,” Joyce PERSON said. “She want me to talk to Sandy PERSON , have him let up on Humphrey ORG .”

“He ain’t gonna do it,” Rickey PERSON said, sitting on the side of the bed and kicking off his slippers. “He done give the Hump ORG too many breaks already. Pearl PERSON sound like all this stuff is somethin logical, like some Riggs Bank ORG loan. She should bring her ass out of Potomac GPE once and a while and see what it’s like in the real world. What can she know bout what Humphrey PERSON ’s up to if all they do is talk on the phone?”

Three years before DATE , Pearl PERSON had married what she told Joyce PERSON was her “dream man,” a much older man who owned four CARDINAL restaurants scattered throughout Northeast LOC and Anacostia GPE . They moved to Potomac GPE , but while her new husband had accepted her second ORDINAL child, he told Pearl PERSON that he would have nothing to do with Humphrey PERSON until the boy “straightened himself out.” The result, essentially, was that home for Humphrey PERSON became just about anywhere he happened to be. He had declined to come and live with Joyce PERSON .

“I’ll talk to Sandy PERSON ,” Joyce PERSON sighed.

“ Talk to the Hump WORK_OF_ART while you at it.”

The telephone chimed again. Joyce PERSON answered, said, “Yes, mama, tomorrow DATE ,” a few times and then hung up. “She sounded very calm,” she said to Rickey ORG . “But the calmer she sounds, the madder she is about somethin. Problems, problems. Ain’t I got problems.” She took Rickey PERSON ’s beer from him and placed it on the nightstand. “If Daddy want a baby, Daddy gotta work for it.”



The next day DATE was Friday DATE , and she put off going to see her mother because it was too nice an April day DATE not to begin preparations for her backyard garden. Santiago GPE called twice during the day DATE and he assured her that his Mama Pearl was exaggerating about what Humphrey ORG owed him.

“Then what’s this she talkin about?” Joyce PERSON said to him Sunday DATE morning TIME . Sundays DATE were the only days DATE he would agree to come over early so she could have everyone together for breakfast.

“I don’t know,” Santiago GPE said. He was sitting across the table from his brother, Taylor PERSON . “Think fast!” he told the boy before tossing a biscuit at him. “You know how Mama Pearl PERSON can be.” Taylor PERSON ran around the table and grabbed Santiago GPE ’s ear. He feigned pain and then pretended to choke Taylor PERSON .

“Then you won’t mind talkin to Humphrey PERSON when he get here. I made him promise to come over.”

Santiago GPE stopped playing with Taylor PERSON . He shrugged. “I don’t mind. I told you it was cool.”

Taylor PERSON continued to play with Santiago GPE . “All right,” Joyce PERSON said. “Thas anough of that. Get upstairs and clean your damn room! You know I’m still hot about that bike, so you better stay outa my sight today DATE .” She said to Santiago GPE , “After I told him again not to take the bike, he took it out last night TIME and busted the front wheel.”

“What’s the use of havin some toy if you can’t play with it,” Taylor PERSON said. Joyce PERSON had promised that he could begin riding it on his next birthday, when she thought he would be tall enough to reach the pedals.

“When the toy cost three hundred dollars MONEY , it ain’t no toy no more,” she said. “And listen here: I’m gettin tired of all this mouth you been givin me lately. Les not forget who runs things around here. You keep it up and you’ll be missin some teeth.”

“Oh, it’s all right, Mama,” Santiago ORG said. “I’ll just have Rickey PERSON take it next week DATE to get fixed.” Rickey PERSON , sitting next to Santiago GPE , said nothing. He was reading the newspaper and he turned the page.



Joyce PERSON came in from her garden when Humphrey PERSON arrived and had him and Santiago GPE go into the living room. “I don’t want yall to come out till this whole thing is straightened out,” she said and reminded them of the way she and Pearl PERSON used to do it when they quarreled as boys. Then she returned to her garden. A half hour or so later TIME , Rickey PERSON came out and stood on the steps watching her. “I’m gonna put some corn over there,” she said when she noticed him. “I’m gonna put the tomatoes right there. Might even try some peppers. You know how you like peppers. How’s it goin in there?” She had a transistor radio playing on the last step and he had not heard most of what she said.

Rickey PERSON turned off the radio. “I wasn’t in there, but when I went by I heard em talking like the old days DATE .”

“Well, thank the Lord Jesus PERSON ,” she said, taking off her gloves. “ Whew PERSON . No wonder my mama and daddy left the farm for the city.”

“You takin the pill or somethin?”

“What?”

“It’s takin you longer to get pregnant than it took em to make Frankenstein PERSON ,” Rickey PERSON said.

“Well, I hope we aimin for somethin far better than that,” she said. She was standing before him now and she reached around him and began kneading his behind. “It’s discouragin,” he said. She said, “I know, baby. Just hang in there.”

Inside, she pinched the cheeks of Santiago GPE and Humphrey ORG and told them she was proud of them. She offered to make a celebratory dinner that evening TIME . But the dinner did not come off as planned. Humphrey PERSON did not show up, and Rickey PERSON called about eight CARDINAL to say he and Santiago GPE would be out late.



A year or so DATE after she moved into the house, she began searching for another coffee table similar to the old one. The old table was running out of room for new photographs, and whenever she added new pictures, she was forced to overlap everything. In some cases, a face was hidden by the picture above it or next to it; in others, these were missing limbs, and in still others, entire bodies were gone, except for a sleeve or shoe here and there. There was always an empty space she saved for some especially wonderful picture that might come along. That space shifted about, according to how she arranged things. On the day DATE Rickey PERSON asked her about the pill, the space happened to be next to a picture of her in a white-and-green cotton print dress, and she was standing beside the man who was Clovis PERSON ’s father. The photograph had been taken a year or so before she met Rickey PERSON , and a month DATE after her tubes were tied. “I hope he tied the knot tight enough,” Joyce PERSON said to one CARDINAL of the hospital nurses who had befriended her.” “A pretty bow,” the nurse said. “It’s one CARDINAL of the few things they get right in this joint.”



Three weeks DATE after she had promised to come by the next day DATE , Joyce PERSON finally got up the courage to visit her mother. She waited until one o’clock TIME , hoping the washer and dryer repairman would show up before she left. Her mother had not called back to remind her of the promise, which was her mother’s way. As always, Joyce PERSON tried to anticipate all that her mother would throw at her and spent the walk down to her mother’s thinking of ways to counter it. She would not have noticed the woman and the three CARDINAL children walking down the other side of 5th Street FAC had the little girl with the woman not cried out to one CARDINAL of the boys, “Stop, you hurtin my sore!” When Joyce PERSON looked over, she saw the woman scolding the youngest of the boys, shaking her finger in his face. Joyce PERSON saw immediately that the other boy, standing off to the side of the others, was Adam PERSON . She uttered an oh loud enough for the man passing by her to ask if she might be ill.

She crossed the street and touched Adam GPE ’s shoulder, saying, “I know you remember who I am, your Aunt Joycie GPE .” The boy looked up at her and blinked twice, then looked at the woman he was with as if she might have the proper response.

“Thas my child, lady, leave him be,” the woman said.

“It’s all right,” Joyce PERSON said. “Me and Adam PERSON know each other from way back, don’t we, Adam PERSON ?” The boy shook his head. “Sure you do,” Joyce PERSON said. “Come on now, think. Remember how I useta to fix you all them banana splits piled up this high?” There seemed to be no memory at all in the boy’s face, and for several seconds TIME he looked out into the street as if Joyce PERSON were a bother. “Remember all them baths with the soap bubbles? Bubble time?”

“Listen, you can see he don’t even know you,” the woman said.

“It was a long time ago,” Joyce PERSON said. She took money from her purse and gave Adam five dollars MONEY . Then, seeing the other two CARDINAL children look hungrily at the bill, she gave them five dollars MONEY as well.

“I don’t let my children take money from strangers off the street,” the woman said.

“She useta to be my mama,” Adam PERSON said, inspecting the back of the bill.

“You can’t have him back,” the woman said, grabbing each bill and throwing them at Joyce PERSON . “I got him fair and square. I got the papers on him to show it. You can’t have him.” She gathered the children by the hands and hurried them against the light across H Street FAC . She continued to watch the woman and the children go down 5th Street FAC , and when they were nearing F Street FAC , Adam PERSON turned to look back, as if to confirm the feeling she had that the initial denial was part of some game.

Her mother lived in the Judiciary House FAC , an H Street FAC apartment building for senior citizens and the disabled. Joyce PERSON let herself into the apartment with her own key and found her mother in the living room. The small black-and-white television Joyce PERSON ’s father had bought on credit twelve years ago DATE was on, but her mother was reading a paperback book and paid no attention to the television. Her mother, who did not look up when her daughter entered, was wearing, as usual when she was inside, one CARDINAL of her dead husband’s shirts and a pair of his checkered socks. And as Joyce PERSON bent down to give her mother the kind of kiss on the cheek that Santiago GPE would give Joyce PERSON , she smelled her father’s cheap musky aftershave.

“I want you to give Sandy PERSON a message,” her mother said, taking off the eyeglasses she kept on a string around her neck. “And if you want I’ll tell it to you slow so you can get every word down.”

“I’m fine, Mama,” Joyce PERSON said. “Thank you very much. And how you doin?” Her resolve to do battle had dissipated in the street with the woman and Adam PERSON . In that second ORDINAL -floor bedroom in her 10th Street FAC house she had set aside for her mother, there was a telephone with giant numbers so her mother would not have trouble dialing her friends. And there was a picture over the poster bed of Jesus Christ PERSON , blonde hair down to his shoulders, praying in the garden at Gethsemane PERSON .

“ Santiago GPE been comin by some nights and sleepin sida my bed like he did when he was young,” her mother said.

“That sounds like good news to me, Mama. I’m glad you two CARDINAL friends again. You coulda told me this on the phone.” She sat across from her mother in a cheap metal chair that was part of the dinette set. “I would think you’d be glad to see your grandkids, since you don’t want to come to my house.”

“It ain’t the comin and stayin and what not. He stayed here the other night TIME . Got up early when that beep-beep thing went off and let hisself out. And when I got in here I found a hundred-dollar MONEY bill on the table layin under the sugar dish. One hundred dollars MONEY . It’s on the table there and you take it outa my house when you go. I ain’t some sportin woman in the street. I told him never to bring a thing in this house but hisself and the clothes on his back. Well, maybe he’ll listen if the words come from his own mother.” She had been reading a romance novel and now she inserted a funeral-home bookmark in her place and closed the book.

Joyce PERSON said, “He just wants to make you happy, Mama. You know how he likes to be generous with his family.”

“I just this moment changed my mind,” her mother said. She never once looked at her daughter, only watched the people on the television. “Since all this givin is in his blood that way, then tell him not to come to my house again. And if he comes I’ll have him locked up.”

“That’ll break his heart, Mama.”

“Tell him not to worry: God don’t put no more on us than we can bear.” Her mother put on her glasses and opened the book.

Joyce PERSON stood and went to the door, and her mother told her not to forget the money.



She took the long way back home, lest she bring bad feelings back to her house. She walked downtown along F Street FAC and looked in the store windows. At a shop at 12th Street FAC , she bought a doughnut and several large cookies with the hundred-dollar MONEY bill and ate them unselfconsciously as she walked along, the way a child would. At a shoe store near 13th Street FAC , she abandoned once and for all any hope she ever had that her mother would come to live with her and spend the rest of her life in the room on the second ORDINAL floor. And at Garfinkel PERSON ’s she wondered if that doctor could go back inside her and pull one CARDINAL end of that pretty bow so that it would come untied and she might make Rickey PERSON , with all his whininess, happy.



There had been, along the false-wood part of the coffee table, a few cigarette burns when she bought the table. Rickey PERSON had somehow managed to make the burns disappear and the table looked almost new. The burns had been near some pictures taken at various Christmases PRODUCT . In one CARDINAL , taken months after his mother married, Humphrey PERSON was sleeping in a chair by a window. In his lap was a knit cap Clovis PERSON had given him. When they woke him for dinner, he was angry, as if he had been arguing in his dreams and did not know he was now awake. “I got my pride, you know,” he shouted. “I still got a whole lotta pride people don’t even know about.”

In another picture, taken during a Christmas when he was still courting her, Rickey PERSON had allowed Joyce PERSON to set Clovis PERSON in his lap, arrange the boys on either side of him, and photograph the four CARDINAL of them in front of the Christmas tree DATE . “I’m a family man without a family,” he’d told her not long after they had met at a cabaret in Southeast GPE . And those words were in her mind when she knelt on the linoleum floor and took their picture. Three CARDINAL times. “I can give you all you want,” she had said before he moved in with them. “I can give you all the kids you can afford.” “I can afford a hundred CARDINAL ,” he said. “Then that’s how many I can give you.”



The garden came up beautifully, despite a week or so of bad weather. It had rained hard three days DATE straight, and on the second ORDINAL morning they had awakened to find the basement floor covered with three inches QUANTITY of water. All the rain in the basement was gone now, but it had left some seed, some indestructible life form, that threatened to turn the basement into something prehistoric. Despite a virtual army of men hired by Santiago GPE to disinfect the basement periodically, Joyce PERSON would come down some mornings and find green, furlike mold growing along the paneled walls, sprouting in corners, sharing space with the mousetraps.

But the garden thrived, and a summer came on, Joyce PERSON spent more and more of her days there. She was there, bent down in a row DATE of tomatoes, when Clovis PERSON ran out to her and told her that Sandy PERSON was picking on Humphrey ORG again down at the corner. Calmly, and with an exasperated sigh, she took off her hat and gloves and told Clovis PERSON to stay in the house.

She would not ever remember if she heard the two CARDINAL pops before she got to the corner at O Street FAC . When she turned the corner, she saw a crowd, but between her and Humphrey PERSON there was no one. He was backing toward her, and he would have reached her, but Santiago GPE shot him again and he fell. She thought that he had only stumbled, and when she saw Rickey PERSON out of the corner of her eye standing in the street watching them, she was somehow nearly reassured that Humphrey PERSON had only misstepped.

She shouted to Santiago GPE . “Stop it fore you hit somebody!” When she got to Humphrey PERSON , he was sitting, and when he began to lie back, she reached down to help him, took him by the front of the dark jacket with one hand and the back of his head with the other. When he was down all the way, he shook his head as if to say, “Clumsy me.” There was wetness on the hand that had taken the jacket, but she was concentrating on Santiago GPE too much to take note of it. She continued on toward him and he lowered the gun and did not move.

“You stay outta this, Mama. This ain’t got nothin to do with you.”

“What you been doin?” she asked him.

She slapped him twice, and when she saw the blood on his cheek and then on her hand, her heart sank because she thought she had injured him.

“All right now, Mama, I’m warnin you.” He pointed the gun between her eyes, then he backed away. “This ain’t none a your business.” He pushed back against the people behind him, and they made room for him, then he ran to the Range Rover that was double parked. In seconds TIME he was gone.

She called to Rickey PERSON , who was now standing on the sidewalk across O Street, and then she began to scream his name. He ran away. She went back to Humphrey PERSON , whose front was now completely bloodied. She asked someone to call for help. Joyce PERSON sat down and cradled Humphrey PERSON ’s head in her lap. She thought that he was already dead, but he opened his eyes and said, “Please don’t tell my mama.” He said it again and would have gone on saying it, but she covered his mouth with her hand.



It was well after dark when the police left her house, and when they had all gone, she called Pearl PERSON . She stayed on the telephone for several hours TIME , until Pearl PERSON ’s husband got home from work. Pearl PERSON said that she forgave Santiago GPE , but Joyce PERSON knew that that would never be true in this life. After she hung up the telephone, she sat on the floor in the living room until the grandfather clock told her it was ten DATE . In a small cabinet near the couch was a fifth ORDINAL of vodka, which she drank in less than an hour TIME . Then, beginning in the basement, she went about the house undoing the locks on all the doors and windows, for Santiago GPE had no key to her house. And outside that house there was a very cruel world and she did not like to think that her child was out there without a place to come to.





A BUTTERFLY ORG ON F STREET




The man Mildred Harper PERSON was legally married to for twenty-seven years DATE had been dead and buried five months DATE when, standing on an F Street FAC traffic median, she came upon the woman her husband had lived with for the last two years DATE of his life. Mildred PERSON had crossed to the island from Morton ORG ’s, going to Woolworth ORG ’s, her eyes fixed upon a golden-yellow butterfly that fluttered about the median. A child swatted half CARDINAL -heartedly at the butterfly, which rose as high as seven or so CARDINAL feet at moments, zigzagging back and forth over people’s heads and around an advertising kiosk PERSON and around the small, lifeless trees. Then the butterfly set off into the traffic heading toward 13th Street FAC . It astonished her to see such a thing, wild, utterly fragile, in the midst of the buildings, the noise, the cars and buses, and she figured the thing must have lost its way. Before long, the butterfly was consumed in the colors of 13th Street FAC .

When Mildred PERSON turned back toward Woolworth ORG ’s, she came face to face with the woman her husband had left her for, whose leaving had picked Mildred PERSON up by the hair and dropped her down at the doorstep of insanity. She had seen the woman four CARDINAL or five CARDINAL times before, always from the back seat of her son’s car. But to see her now so close was like finding that a being from a recurring dream had stepped out into her life.

“ Mildred WORK_OF_ART ,” the woman said, “I’m real sorry for your loss.”

Two months before DATE , the woman had turned over to Mildred PERSON ’s son all the belongings of Mansfield Harper PERSON , including dozens CARDINAL of pictures of his family. “She didn’t say nothing much, Mama,” her son kept telling Mildred PERSON . Then he said, “She just said, ‘I’m real sorry for your loss.’”

The woman stood but a few feet QUANTITY from her on the median. Perhaps if she had said something else, Mildred PERSON might have walked away. But she was surprised by the note of sincerity in the woman’s words. “Thank you,” Mildred PERSON said.

He had not, this man she was married to for twenty-seven years DATE , told her he was leaving. One CARDINAL day his things were in their 12th Street FAC home (“ God Bless This House WORK_OF_ART ”), and the next day DATE when she came home from work, many of those things were gone. The imported Swiss NORP razor. Mildred PERSON had put his note in her Bible WORK_OF_ART . (“Place your hopes among the Psalms ORG ; the Psalms ORG is good luck.”)

“The doctors,” the woman was now saying, “had given him all this medicine, so he didn’t suffer any. Cancer, you know, can kill you twice. Once with all that sufferin GPE , then with the final dyin itself. But he passed on peacefully into the next world.” She was a rather plain woman, Mildred PERSON decided, but only because she did not fix herself up. Her hair was combed back with the ends captured in a red barette at the nape of her neck. She wore no makeup and her thick eyebrows grew together, meeting in a neat line over the bridge of her nose that would have been becoming on a woman who fixed herself up.

They had lived, this woman and the father of Mildred PERSON ’s four CARDINAL children, in a small house on Maple View in Anacostia ORG , where Mildred PERSON had forced her son to take her. “I live in Northeast LOC , Mama LOC . I don’t know one thing about Anacostia PERSON .” “Buy a map. Get a map. I want to see where they live, where him and her live together.” “You just actin crazy.” “Do what I say.”

“I haven’t been downtown in so long,” the woman was saying. “They sure have built it up.” Mildred PERSON ’s oldest son had forgiven his father almost from the first day DATE , but their only daughter, Gladys ORG , Mansfield GPE ’s favorite, could not forgive. And on those days DATE when Mildred PERSON managed to get far enough away from insanity’s doorstep to see hope, she would come upon her daughter tearing up still one CARDINAL more treasure Mansfield GPE had given her. This little piggy had roast beef…. This little piggy stayed home….

“I hadn’t been down here in a long time either,” Mildred PERSON said.

“I really miss the way we used to be able to cross right in the middle of the street when all the lights changed,” the woman said. “You know, the lights would change and the people on the four CARDINAL corners could just walk right out in the middle of the street to the other side. I miss that.”

“I remember,” Mildred PERSON said. She wanted to go now. The pain was coming back, day by hour TIME by minute TIME by second ORDINAL . She wanted to go on across the street to the things of Woolworth ORG ’s. (“If it ain’t at Woolworth ORG ’s,” Mansfield GPE had said once, “they ain’t makin it.”) The woman’s plainness continued on down her body, with a gray sweater and a blue blouse, both of which had had all the life washed out of them. Her skirt, a darker blue, was pleated, but it had been ironed by someone who had not quite lined up the pleats correctly, so in some places there was the definite line of the original pleat only a fraction of an inch from the less pronounced line made by the iron.

“ Mildred WORK_OF_ART , I hope you didn’t mind that I didn’t make it to the funeral,” the woman said. She expected the woman to say that it would not have been proper for her to be there, but instead she said, “I was not well and couldn’t make it.”

Mildred PERSON began to feel she was back in that chair in front of her television, talking back to the people on the television. She thought what an easy thing it would have been to strike the woman. But she looked away, up 13th Street FAC , at the sign at Kitt PERSON ’s music store, at people looking in the store window. Then she looked down. The woman’s shoes were loafers, black and shiny. They appeared new and there was a dime in each one. It was something her husband had always done, and something her daughter did as well, following her father. (“No pennies in penny loafers for me. Put in a dime, and if a quarter would fit in there, I’d put in a damn quarter DATE .”)

The dimes were very shiny, too, and it slowly came to Mildred PRODUCT that perhaps all the woman had was now in Harmony Cemetery GPE , six feet QUANTITY under, returning to ashes and dust. It came to her, too, that the woman must have been in a kind of mourning, and she began to feel like something of an intruder, as if she had come into that woman’s house and disturbed the woman, kneeling in prayer.

“It’s all right,” Mildred PERSON said about the funeral. “His own brother didn’t make it in from California GPE .”

“He ain’t gonna die, Mama,” her son had said the first ORDINAL time they waited in his car for Mildred PERSON to get a look at them. They were across the street from the house in the twilight of the day, and Mildred PERSON sat in the back. “I see him a lot, and I should know. He ain’t gonna die no more than you or me.” It was about then that her husband and the woman had come up the street, his strong arm around her, lovers, whispering into the woman’s ear every sweet word that had ever been invented. She had expected it, but it still surprised her. (“Say you want me. Say you can’t do without me. Say you can’t live without me. Say you want me day DATE and night TIME , and all the time in between. Say it. Say it now.”)

“Don’t start anything out here, Mama. You just stay put, y’hear DATE ? Don’t get out a this car.” But they were not walking that way at all: The woman was actually holding Mansfield GPE ’s elbow. And when they got to the house, she opened the gate and led him up the few steps, and they stood on the porch as moths circled the overhead bulb that offered next to no light. Mansfield GPE waited patiently while she unlocked the front door, then she guided him into a dark room.

“Well, I’d best get along,” the woman said now. “I been huntin a winter DATE coat, but I ain’t seen nothin I like. And the prices so high, it make you wanna cry. I’m gonna try Morton PERSON ’s, then go home.”

“I just come from there,” Mildred PERSON said.

She had, toward the end, sent her daughter down there to Anacostia ORG under the pretense of taking some of his things to him. She had hoped that Gladys ORG , after seeing her father, would come back home with some love restored. But Gladys ORG had come back cursing him, and she had cursed him all that night, and all the next day DATE , and well into the next, a Sunday DATE .

The woman extended her hand. “My name’s Elizabeth Ann Coleman PERSON , but all my friends call me Lady,” the woman said, shaking Mildred PERSON ’s hand. “God is with you.” But Mildred PERSON knew that that had not been true for a long time, and that it would never be true again. The woman walked across F Street FAC against the light and entered Morton PERSON ’s. Mildred PERSON did not turn to look at her. She went to the corner of the traffic median and waited for the light to turn green. People on either side of her crossed against the light. But she stood waiting as if she had the whole day and a good part of the next.





GOSPEL




As the House of the Solitary Savior Baptist Church burned to the ground one December Sunday DATE morning TIME , Vivian L. Slater PERSON was in her bath, arranging a program of gospel songs her group was to sing at the church. A Sunday DATE morning TIME bath was just about the only constant in her life, and every Sunday God sent she stretched out in a fragrant mixture of baby oil and water and the most expensive bubble bath she could find. On a stool beside the tub, she always placed a huge glass of soda, grape or some kind of cola. She chilled the drink with several small plastic balls containing water that had been frozen. And beside the glass was a large transistor radio tuned to WYCB or to some station broadcasting church services that offered more spirituals and gospel songs than preaching.

If someone telephoned for her while she was in the tub, her husband, Ralph PERSON , would answer and tell the caller that Mrs. Slater PERSON was indisposed for the time being. From time to time, without her even calling to him, Ralph PERSON would get up from reading the Sunday DATE newspaper and come in without knocking and refilled her glass and replace the colored balls of ice. He was seven years DATE older than she and a man of extreme handsomeness, with no sign of sickness, and when she accompanied him to D.C. General ORG every week DATE for his treatments, men and women of all ages would stare at him, pitying a man who was saddled with a cancer woman perhaps not long for this world. It bothered her that the world did not know which of them was sick. As Ralph PERSON refilled her glass and dropped in fresh balls of ice, he never once would look at her nakedness.

As the House of the Solitary Savior ORG burned down, she was also arranging a program for the Holy Tabernacle AME Zion ORG , a magnificent church of three thousand CARDINAL members where her group, the Gospelteers PRODUCT , was to sing later in the day TIME . She knew it was the sin of pride, but Vivian NORP no longer got any pleasure from singing at the House ORG , as the members called it; it was something she did only because she knew that for singing there, God would make some small, positive notation beside her name in that book of His.

The House of the Solitary Savior ORG had had but one CARDINAL pastor in its thirty years DATE —a tall, gaunt man who made his living as a plumber’s helper. His wife, an elementary school teacher, was as tall and gaunt as her husband, so that anyone seeing the couple would have mistaken them for brother and sister. In all the time that Vivian NORP had known the Reverend Wesley Saunders PERSON , the church had never had more than fifty CARDINAL members, despite the reverend’s boast that he preached more of God’s truth than any pastor in Washington GPE .

About eleven o’clock TIME she was dressed and ready to go. Ralph PERSON was in the easy chair in the living room, and that was undoubtedly where she would find him, drunk, combative, that night when she came home.

He said, “Paper say maybe some snow tonight TIME , sugar.” He was a man who loved profoundly and he had not stopped looking at her since she came into the room. He watched her now as she put on her coat and considered herself in the mirror on the back of the hall closet door. She said, “If it does snow, them new snow tires’ll get a workout.” She turned to the side and considered herself in the mirror that way. He said, “You look real good today DATE , sugar.” From the closet she took the slippers and gown she wore when singing. She turned her other side to the mirror. Finally, she leaned over him, put her finger an inch from her lightly rouged lips and touched it to his cheek. She said, “I’ll see you when I get back.” He said, “Okay, sugar. Be careful.”

To get to Diane McCollough PERSON , her best friend and the first ORDINAL member she had recruited for the Gospelteers ORG , she came down Martin Luther King PERSON , Jr., Avenue GPE and crossed the bridge over the Anacostia River LOC . Generally, she did not like driving, particularly not over the bridge, for having so many cars around her made her feel as if she were a part of some uncontrollable tide and could only be helplessly swept along. But on a Sunday DATE morning TIME the traffic was tolerable, and after she had crossed the river, she relaxed and reviewed the day’s programs in her head. Now and again, she looked at herself in the rearview mirror.

Diane PERSON lived in a house half CARDINAL the size of Vivian NORP ’s on 9th Street Southeast LOC , not far from Lincoln Park FAC . Vivian NORP let herself into the house with her own key. Diane PERSON lived with her second ORDINAL husband, Harry PERSON , and her youngest daughter from her first ORDINAL marriage, along with her daughter’s only child, an overweight boy of four CARDINAL who had been spoiled beyond redemption. Two CARDINAL of Diane PERSON ’s sons were in Lorton GPE for selling cocaine. “She ain’t had a happy life, I can tell you that,” Vivian NORP would say in defending her friend to people who thought she had raised her children wrong. “Have a little sympathy.”

Diane PERSON , dressed and made up, was at the kitchen sink, drinking the last of her coffee. Everyone said good morning except for the little boy, who sat beside his mother at the table, playing with a truck that was as big as his head. Vivian NORP sat down across from the boy, as far away from him as she could get. The boy would have thought nothing of touching her with his greasy hands. The odor of coffee and bacon had settled about the room, and Vivian NORP counted off the weeks DATE she had been on her diet.

“ Vi PERSON , don’t get comfortable, cause I’m all ready,” Diane PERSON said.

“We got plenty of time,” Vivian NORP said. “ A minute TIME or two CARDINAL won’t hurt.”

“Who yall got today DATE ?” Cherry PERSON , Diane PERSON ’s daughter, asked. She was, like her mother, a very plain and charming woman who could immediately put the world at ease. She had waited until she was thirty-one CARDINAL to marry, but it was to a man she now fought with night TIME and day DATE . And usually after the worst fights, she ran away to stay with Diane PERSON , until her husband came and knocked contritely at his mother-in-law’s door. “And think of that poor ugly daughter of hers,” Vivian NORP would say to people as she defended her friend.

“ The House WORK_OF_ART first ORDINAL , ain’t it, Vi PERSON ?” Diane PERSON said, coming up behind her grandson. “The Hoouuse PERSON …” She dragged the word out as if the sound of it could frighten the boy, and then she tickled his sides. “The House ORG gonna get you.” The boy, moving the truck along the edge of the table, ignored her.

“ The House in the early afternoon WORK_OF_ART ,” Vivian NORP said, “then Holy Tabernacle ORG in the evening.”

Diane PERSON ’s husband said, “That House ORG got that Reverend Saunders PERSON , ain’t it? God’s gift to the world, ain’t he?”

“So he think,” Vivian NORP said. In the world of Washington GPE gospel, Vivian NORP ’s Gospelteers, a group of four CARDINAL women and a piano player, had a respectable reputation that she felt had outgrown a storefront like the House ORG . But twenty-five years before DATE , just after the group’s birth, Reverend Saunders PERSON was the first ORDINAL to say, “Come and sing before my people.” She felt she owed him. It was an obligation he could remind her of on the phone with no more than a “God bless you and a good evenin to you, Sister Slater PERSON .” Reverend Saunders PERSON , even with a flock that could fit into one CARDINAL Metrobus GPE , was a proud man, and though Vivian NORP always told him the church owed them nothing, he would have the Gospelteers PRODUCT wait at the end of the program while he and his wife went about the church collecting what the members could contribute to the group. At the large churches built to last until kingdom come, payment came in a check with the church’s name in bold, unflinching letters at the top center.

“ Yall WORK_OF_ART gonna sing, ‘I’m a Pilgrim PERSON ’?” Diane PERSON ’s husband said. “I do like that song. Reminds me of what they used to sing back home. I could listen to it all day long.”

Vivian NORP said, “We’ll do it at the House ORG , but not at Holy Tabernacle ORG . Reminds you of bein back in your mama’s arms, huh?” She reached across to pinch his cheek. He was a large light-skinned man and he blushed.

She began to sing to him, and for the first ORDINAL and only time the boy raised his head and looked at her.

I have trouble on ev’ry hand

But I’ve started for the city…

I’m goin down to the river Jordan PERSON

I’m gonna bathe my weary soul.



“Oh, get outta here,” he said, and she sang on because she liked seeing that she had pleased. When she had finished, he asked, “You think your no-count piano player’ll show up this time?”

“He’d better,” Diane PERSON said.

“You got that right,” Vivian NORP said. “Just thinkin about last Sunday DATE sets my teeth on edge.”

Despite being a young man who spent most of his Sundays DATE in churches hitting the ivory keys for God, the piano player, Counsel Smith PERSON , lived a fast life, much of it packed into Friday DATE and Saturday DATE nights TIME . So it was often difficult for him to collect himself on Sunday DATE morning TIME , to pull himself away from a willing woman and clear his head of alcohol, and to go off to be with four CARDINAL other women, one CARDINAL of whom was old enough to be his grandmother, two CARDINAL of whom were old enough to be his mother, and one CARDINAL of whom had a ring through her nose about another man.

“We already told him if he miss one CARDINAL more time or be late one CARDINAL more time, he’s finished,” Diane PERSON said. She set her cup in the sink, then looked sternly at her daughter and pointed into the sink full of dirty dishes. “There ain’t nothin worse in the world than gettin up at some church and havin to make up excuses about why you didn’t bring your piano player.”

“ Yall PERSON should be able to sing without a piano player by now,” her husband said.

“ Ain’t WORK_OF_ART that much singin in the world,” Vivian NORP said. The adults laughed, and then the boy, as if afraid he was being left out, laughed as well.

“You ready?” Vivian NORP said to Diane PERSON .

“As ready as I’ll ever be.” She gave her husband a passionate kiss on the lips, a kiss that Vivian NORP thought was too much for a Sunday DATE morning TIME at the kitchen table. Diane PERSON then pinched the boy’s cheeks. “Ooh, ooh,” she said. “ Ooh PERSON , my little butterball.” The boy wiggled away.

In the car, going to pick up the other two CARDINAL women, Diane PERSON inspected her face in a palm-sized mirror she took from her pocketbook. Vivian NORP drove down to Massachusetts Avenue FAC .

“How long Cherry gonna be with you this time?” Vivian NORP said.

“ Can’t tell WORK_OF_ART ,” Diane PERSON said. “Can’t ever tell. Just have to wait till they both come to their senses, and lately it’s takin em longer and longer. Soon they won’t have any sense at all. I’m just thankful for a understandin husband.”

Vivian NORP watched her friend out of the corner of her eye. She noted that Diane PERSON was putting on more weight. The two CARDINAL women were both fifty-seven years old DATE , though Vivian NORP would have been quick to tell anyone that she was younger by seven months DATE .

Diane PERSON sighed and grew quiet. She put the mirror back in her pocketbook and studied the road before them. Her singing voice was no longer what it had been once upon a time and she knew this, but she and Vivian NORP went back a long way. Then, too, in most of the churches of Washington GPE , the people who heard the Gospelteers ORG were generally more concerned about the message than the messenger PERSON ’s delivery.

Vivian NORP laughed, shaking her friends’s arm. “Oh, come on now,” she said. “Snap out of it. Pull up them droopy lips.”

“Lord, yes,” Diane PERSON said. “It’s gonna be a wonderful day DATE . And”—she drummed her fingers on the pocketbook—“there FAC is a bright spot there out on the horizon.” She shook her head with delight.

“Oh,” Vivian NORP said, “what is this bright spot?”

“Later, I’ll tell you later, when there’s time,” Diane PERSON said, and she shook herself some more.

The woman who was old enough to be Counsel Smith PERSON ’s grandmother was Maude Townsend PERSON , a blind woman who lived at Claridge Towers ORG on M Street Northwest FAC , an apartment house for old people and the disabled. On the day DATE the House of the Solitary Savior ORG burned to the ground, Maude PERSON was waiting outside Claridge Towers ORG with Anita Hughes PERSON , the newest and youngest member of the group.

After Maude PERSON and Anita PERSON were in the car, Vivian NORP said, “ Standin PERSON out there like that yall looked like two CARDINAL sportin ladies on the corner waitin for some gentlemen. I had to look twice to make sure I was at the right address.” The four CARDINAL laughed.

“I ain’t lookin for no man,” Maude PERSON said after they were on 11th Street FAC . “Thas all finished. All I want is some more Jesus PERSON .” Maude PERSON , too, was one of the original members of the Gospelteers LOC . She was seventy-eight CARDINAL , and of the dozens CARDINAL and dozens CARDINAL of her people who had been alive when the group sang that very first ORDINAL Sunday DATE at the House ORG , not one was now alive.

“But you sho right about that sportin stuff,” Maude PERSON said. “You wouldn’t believe what that place done turned into. Claridge was such a nice place when I first ORDINAL moved in.” She leaned back in her seat and crossed her ankles.

“I keep telling her that she should move out, find someplace else,” Anita PERSON said. As she often did the night before the group sang, she stayed with Maude PERSON . “ John PERSON and I will help her find a place.” John PERSON was the man with whom she lived, a gentle country man who was in his last year of medical residency at Howard University Hospital ORG . Anita PERSON was twenty-five CARDINAL , in the second year DATE of studying for a biology doctorate. She sang gospel because she felt that was the only way she could speak to God.

“Every senior citizen buildin in this city done turned bad,” Maude PERSON said. “The only thing to do is to just pick up and move back down South LOC . I got two CARDINAL friends that done that and they say they shoulda done it long ago.”

“Oh, Maude PERSON ,” Diane PERSON said, “I been back South LOC and you ain’t gonna find it no different.”

“She right,” Vivian NORP said.

Maude PERSON said nothing. Her head was turned to the window. In one hand she carried her tambourine. On the wrist of the other arm she wore a watch, but it was the type for sighted people, and aside from being a pretty thing on her wrist, it was not any good to her unless someone with eyes looked at it and told her what time it was.

Vivian NORP found a parking space on S Street FAC , between 10th and 11th DATE . Maude PERSON walked with her arm through Vivian NORP ’s, and Diane PERSON and Anita PERSON walked behind them. Not until they had reached the corner of 10th Street FAC did the three CARDINAL sighted women notice that a policeman was not allowing traffic to continue on down 10th ORDINAL . Once on 10th Street FAC , they could see a crowd of people on both sides of the street and the fire trucks about midway up the block. And when they got closer, they could see Reverend Saunders PERSON and his wife, their heads high above all the others, even the firemen who hurried about them. Counsel ORG , for once, had been early and he stood beside the couple.

Counsel ORG told them what had happened, and the three CARDINAL women could see that not one CARDINAL part of the small building had been saved. As he spoke, a mood of utter sadness swept over the four CARDINAL women. They did not think very much of Reverend Saunders PERSON ’s work, but they did not believe that anything bad should ever happen to any of God’s houses.

“Well,” Counsel ORG said in a voice only Vivian NORP could hear, “that’s one excuse for a piano I have won’t have to coax some life into again.”

Vivian NORP watched the reverend’s wife clinging to her husband, her face buried in the shoulder of his coat. There was a general stench of burnt wood, and above the murmurs of the crowds on both sides of the street, Vivian NORP could hear the water falling through the charred skeleton of what was left of the church. She watched the water rain down and flow with black debris over the sidewalk into the gutter and the street. People stepped back from it. She could see clear through the church now into what had passed for a backyard. Now and then, a small burst of dark smoke would escape from the structure and dissipate a few feet QUANTITY above it. The busy firemen spoke to each other as if they had all been raised together from birth.

Reverend Saunders PERSON turned around and took note of the four CARDINAL women. He shook their hands and he thanked them for coming. And then the members of his church came up to the women and they, too, thanked them for coming. Most of the members were women who were nearly as old as Maude PERSON . Vivian NORP could see that most of the women had been crying and it tore into her heart. From program to program, she never remembered any of them except in some vague way, and whenever she happened to meet one CARDINAL of them in any other place on any other day she was never able to recall from where she knew them.

The firemen were now packing up to leave, rolling up the fire hoses and taking off their suits. The fireman who seemed to be in charge came to Reverend Saunders PERSON and said a few final words to him, then he went back to helping his men. The sun was at the top of the sky. In a voice loud and undeniable, Reverend Saunders PERSON asked his people to pray and everyone on both sides of the street fell silent. Some of the firemen would occasionally stop what they were doing for a second ORDINAL or two CARDINAL , but for the most part, they continued on.

When the prayers were done, Reverend Saunders PERSON asked the Gospelteers to sing one CARDINAL song.

“ Vi WORK_OF_ART , I feel ‘Amazin Grace’ in my heart right now,” Maude PERSON said. The four CARDINAL women locked their arms and began to sing, and again the people fell silent. And though he did not usually sing, Counsel ORG joined the four CARDINAL women.

“We gonna build us another one, Sister Slater PERSON ,” Reverend Saunders PERSON said when the hymn was over. “And I hope yall will come to sing at the dedication.” His words still had a touch of that boastful quality. He turned back and took a few steps toward what was left of the church, and his wife, her arm still in his, followed. “Everything is a sign from the Master WORK_OF_ART ,” he said to no one in particular. Vivian NORP could see, for the first ORDINAL time ever, that he was no longer a young man. “And maybe tomorrow DATE or the next day DATE , I’ll figure out what it is.” His wife had not said a word the whole time.

The group now had a few hours TIME before the program at Holy Tabernacle ORG . Counsel ORG had parked near Vivian GPE ’s Cadillac ORG and he walked the four CARDINAL women to the car. Though none of them was very hungry, they decided to go to the Florida Avenue Grill ORG , because Anita PERSON ’s aunt was a waitress there. Counsel ORG told the women he would meet them at the church. Vivian NORP warned him not to be late and Maude PERSON , teasing, told him not to bring one of his women along.



The second ORDINAL assistant pastor and a deacon at Holy Tabernacle ORG greeted the Gospelteers ORG just outside one of the dressing rooms in the basement just off 14th Street FAC . The hall was crowded with groups going in and out of other dressing rooms and offices being used as dressing rooms. Vivian NORP could see Counsel ORG at the end of the hall, where he was conversing with a young woman in the corner.

That Sunday DATE was the last day of a month DATE of festivities inaugurating the new head pastor, Reverend Melvin Ritter PERSON , the son of the last pastor, Reverend Louis Ritter PERSON . The older man had turned over most of his duties to his son a year before DATE , and he began spending most of his time at a home he and his wife had bought in North Carolina GPE , where he had been born and raised and where God had called him. Six months DATE before he had gone for a walk in the dark and drowned in the river that bordered their property.

Upstairs, the old man’s son was speaking to those assembled in the church, and he was telling them about his father and the river. There were speakers installed in just about every ceiling corner of the building and the son’s words rained down on the people in the basement hall and in the rooms.

As the Gospelteers got ready in their dressing room (they were to be the third ORDINAL group to sing, after the Watchers ORG , and Jesse Mae Carson PERSON and the Heavenly Choir GPE ), they remembered the day a year before DATE when the old man had been preaching and had seemed to lose his way. The women and Counsel ORG and members of a few other groups had been waiting in one of the back halls that led to the church when they heard the old man grow silent. At first ORDINAL they thought the speakers had malfunctioned, but they heard him breathing loudly. Then he said, “Mother,” which was what he called his wife.

Vivian PERSON had gone to the hall door leading into the church and had seen the old man absently flipping the pages of his Bible WORK_OF_ART . He said “Mother” once more, took up the Bible WORK_OF_ART , walked to the edge of the pulpit, and extended his hand, as if for help, to his wife. Only those near him could hear him say “Mother” yet again. She got up from her place in the Amen Corner, came to him, and led him back to a seat behind the lectern and just in front of the church’s choir. Eventually, the second ORDINAL assistant pastor, a deacon, and his wife helped the old man out of the church. The old man’s son had come to help his father as well, but his mother shook her head and pointed to the pulpit. The old man and his wife and one of the pastors and the deacon passed by Vivian NORP . The old man’s eyes gave her nothing, and though they were leading him, she could see that his legs were still strong. His son, who was then the first ORDINAL assistant pastor, went to the pulpit.

“Did you see what Jesse Mae PERSON was wearing?” Diane PERSON said now. The room was not very big but it was large enough to accommodate two CARDINAL dressing tables, a lounge chair, and a settee. “I tell you: If Jesus PERSON gave out seats in heaven accordin to how good a dresser you are, she’d go straight to hell.” She sat at one CARDINAL of the tables and Anita PERSON was at the other. Vivian NORP was helping Maude PERSON button her gown.

“What did she have on?” Maude PERSON asked. “Somebody tell me what that little hussy had on.”

The words of the old man’s son came out of the speaker. He said that the river where his father had died was the same one he had swum in as a boy, and it was the same one where he had been baptized.

“ Fur WORK_OF_ART ,” Diane PERSON said.

“ Fur WORK_OF_ART ?” said Maude PERSON . “You mean a fur coat?”

“No, fur trim, Maude PERSON . Fur for her collar. Fur round the sleeves. Fur round the hem a that gown a hers.”

“Everybody in the group wearin gowns like that?” Maude PERSON asked.

“You kiddin PERSON ?” Vivian NORP said. “She wouldn’t be the Queen of Sheba GPE if she let everybody wear what she has on.”

Jesse Mae Carson PERSON and her Heavenly Choir GPE had the greatest reputation of any gospel group in Washington GPE . They were wealthy enough to have paid to cut three CARDINAL record albums with a D.C. GPE company. To sell the records Jesse Mae ORG ’s great-grandson would set up a table in the lobbies of the churches where they were singing and offer as a bonus a photograph of the group that had been autographed by Jesse Mae ORG herself. Jesse Mae ORG was eighty-eight years old DATE and stood four feet QUANTITY and some inches QUANTITY high. A person had to stand very close and look real hard to find even one CARDINAL line on her face. She hadn’t sung with the group for more than fifteen years DATE , but would stand before the group and, like a conductor, guide the Heavenly Choir through their numbers. She had had eight CARDINAL husbands. “All of them legitimate,” she had told a radio interviewer once. “God,” she said, “don’t mind you havin a vice. He just don’t want you to abuse it.”

“What color is the gowns they wearin PERSON ?” Maude PERSON wanted to know of the Heavenly Choir GPE .

“Blue, I think. Some kinda blue,” Vivian NORP said. When they wanted to tease her, Vivian NORP ’s friends would call her Little Jesse Mae ORG or Jesse Mae PERSON , Jr. PERSON , because she had had five CARDINAL husbands, three CARDINAL “legitimate” and two CARDINAL common-law.

Upstairs, Reverend Ritter PERSON had finished his remarks and was introducing the Watchers ORG , a group of five CARDINAL men, all over sixty, who had been his father’s favorite. The Watchers set into “Oh, What a Friend We Have in Jesus PERSON .” As the group went into “ Deep River WORK_OF_ART ,” Anita PERSON suggested that she and Maude PERSON go on out and catch up on the gossip as they made their way upstairs. “If we see that hussy,” Maude PERSON said to Anita PERSON , “just turn me loose. Don’t try to hold me back, child.”

Deep River LOC , my home is over Jordan PERSON —



“Ain’t nobody in the world can sing that like them,” Diane PERSON said of the Watchers ORG . “I musta heard a hundred CARDINAL people sing that spiritual over the years DATE . And they the only ones to give me the goose bumps.”

“Know what you mean,” Vivian NORP said. She rarely had anything to say about any other group, but the Watchers ORG , being older and male, were not in competition with the Gospelteers WORK_OF_ART . “Me and you might as well make our way too.
