You got the key?” Diane PERSON nodded and locked the door after them. In the hall, Jesse Mae PERSON was talking to Anita PERSON .

The Watchers sang:

Oh, chillun, oh don’t you want to go to that gospel feast

That promised land, that land where all is peace?



“I know, I know,” Anita PERSON was saying. “It does sound nice, but I keep telling you I’m happy where I am.”

Vivian NORP came up and put her arm around Anita PERSON ’s shoulder. “Still trying to steal you away, huh?” she said to Anita PERSON .

“Not steal, Vi PERSON ,” Jesse Mae ORG said. “Just…how do I say it? Just…entice. Ain’t that right, baby?” and she winked at Anita. It was said that Anita PERSON had a voice beautiful enough to lure the angels down from heaven. Gospel groups up and down the East Coast LOC envied Vivian NORP for having her in the Gospelteers NORP , and for more than a year DATE Jessie Mae ORG had been trying to get Anita PERSON to come over to the Heavenly Choir GPE . She had sent her copies of her group’s record albums, lists of the churches along the East Coast LOC where they had sung in recent years DATE , and pictures of the group posed before landmarks in other cities and standing with well-known politicians and soul singers and athletes. And with all she sent, there was always a note that ended, “I look forward to seeing you the next time. Forever Yours in the Lord WORK_OF_ART ….”

But Anita PERSON had never once wavered in her desire to stay with the Gospelteers PERSON , and Vivian NORP took heart from this. Some days DATE , as she sat in her office at the Agriculture Department ORG , she would think of Anita PERSON arrayed in the pasture-green gown the Gospelteers wore on the fourth Sunday DATE . She would be solo, standing just in front of the other women acting as chorus, and Anita PERSON ’s voice would take hold of the church and all the people in the church would be telling her to bring it on home, bring it on home, child.

“Oh, Jessie Mae PERSON , why don’t you just give it up,” Diane PERSON said. “You just gonna have to face the fact that Vivian NORP got you beat on this one.” It sometimes irritated Vivian NORP that Diane PERSON , of all people, came to her defense.

Jessie Mae PERSON offered each of the four CARDINAL women a practiced smile, a patient smile a tired adult gives a small child who has said one CARDINAL too many absurd things.

“And how is Ralph PERSON ?” Jessie Mae ORG asked Vivian NORP . “Still handsome as ever? My my my.”

“Yes,” Vivian NORP said. “Still the most handsome in the world. Still the best in the world.” She had told no one that Ralph PERSON was dying.

Jessie Mae ORG wished them well with their program and went to be with her group. Vivian NORP and Diane PERSON spent the remaining time in the dining hall, sipping tea. The portraits of all the church’s pastors were on the walls, and near the door to the kitchen there was the place where Reverend Louis Ritter PERSON ’s picture would be one day DATE .



The congregation applauded generously when the Gospelteers PERSON came on. Vivian NORP stepped forward and told the congregation that the group would be singing some of the favorites of Mahalia Jackson PERSON , and the congregation broke into applause again. Anita PERSON would be singing the first ORDINAL songs solo, and the young woman took Vivian NORP ’s place in front of the group. She looked briefly at Counsel ORG and he nodded once and began to play. Anita PERSON closed her eyes for a few seconds TIME and began to sing as she always did—for God and for her father. Once, as she was singing at the Virgin Mother Baptist Church ORG on Kentucky Avenue FAC , Jesus PERSON had come down the aisle and sat down in a pew near the front. He told her that her voice pleased him. He had said no more than that, but she had taken his words to mean that he forgave her for living with John PERSON without marriage. And each time she saw her father, who would not forgive her, she wanted to tell him what Jesus PERSON had done and said. But she could not create the words. Perhaps the words were in the music, but it did no good, because her father did not come anymore to hear her sing.

The Gospelteers opened with “Consideration”:

Tide PRODUCT rolling high billows…

Lord, when you smile on all creations, consider me,

Mad winds may blow; mad breakers roar

They beat on every side



By the time they had reached the refrain of “ Walk Over God’s Heaven WORK_OF_ART ,” Vivian NORP knew the group had reached that sometimes elusive part of the program when the church belonged to them. Those moments were at the center of her life, those moments when the audience, if given a choice of all the things to do on the earth LOC , would have chosen to go on listening to them forever. If I could pick my time to die…she had once thought. When the group reached the end of the program with “ What Could I Do if It Wasn’t for the Lord WORK_OF_ART ,” the congregation and Reverend Ritter PERSON refused to let them go. And so they sang “Move on up a Little Higher” and “ Jesus Met the Woman at the Well WORK_OF_ART ,” and then they went into “ Amazing Grace WORK_OF_ART ” all over again.

When it was all over, they had a bite to eat at the church, mingling with those who could not get enough of hearing and talking about the old man. Diane PERSON said she had a most important call to make and went off while the others were eating, and when she returned the group made its good-byes. Outside, they hugged Counsel ORG good night, and the four CARDINAL women set off in Vivian NORP ’s car. It had been snowing, and each of the four CARDINAL was full of the satisfying warmth at knowing the evening had gone so well. Five CARDINAL blocks or so from the church, Diane PERSON asked if they could stop a minute TIME at the corner of 14th ORDINAL and Fairmont GPE . There, she stepped out into the night TIME and the snow.

“I be right back,” Diane PERSON said before closing the door. She did not look before crossing the street and in a few steps she was at the passenger side of a car that was waiting with its motor on. When she opened the door, the light came on, and in that instant, Vivian NORP could see a bit of the driver, a man who took off his hat. It took her breath away to see him do that. And in that instant before the light went out, she saw Diane PERSON and the man lean toward each other. The kiss came in the dark, the two CARDINAL figures silhouetted against the dull light in the area behind the car. The kiss lasted but a second ORDINAL , but for Vivian NORP it was a most unkind second ORDINAL .

The three CARDINAL women waited in silence for many minutes TIME , until Maude PERSON asked where was Diane PERSON and what was taking her so long. Anita PERSON told her what she was seeing.

“Could you tell if it’s Harry PERSON ?” Maude PERSON said.

“I don’t think it is,” Anita PERSON said. “It sure is n’t Harry’s car PERSON .”

At the word car Maude PERSON seemed to fall to pieces. “Oh, Lord. Oh, Lord,” she said. “She sure is playin with fire doin that. What’s wrong with her? What in the world is wrong with her?”

Before long, Diane PERSON got out of the car, but midway across the empty street, she hesitated and looked back at the man, then she went to him again, and the man rolled down his window. She nodded to him. To Vivian NORP , it was the nod of a woman who had lost her heart, a woman she did not know, had never met in her life. There was an inch or so of snow everywhere, and in the street there were Diane PERSON ’s footprints, coming and going, two CARDINAL intersecting dotted lines on an otherwise unblemished canvas. Vivian NORP looked away when she saw the small clouds their words made.

“I ain’t your gotdamn chauffeur!” Vivian NORP said when Diane PERSON had returned and shut the door. “I don’t get paid for sittin PERSON here and waitin PERSON for you!”

“ Vi PERSON , I’m sorry. It took longer than I expected. I’m really sorry.”

Vivian NORP started up the car. “If you think all I got to do with my time is sit here with all your foolishness, you got another thought comin.”

“ Vi PERSON , I told you I’m sorry. What more do you want? Jesus PERSON !”

“ Vi PERSON ,” Maude PERSON said, seeking peace, “it’s all right. Take it easy. Let’s just get out of here.”

“ Maude PERSON , this my car and I’ll say what I want in it.”

Except for occasional mumblings from Vivian NORP that she was not a chauffeur, they drove the distance to Maude PERSON ’s apartment building without words. Diane PERSON was crying quietly. At the building, Vivian NORP double-parked as Maude PERSON and Anita PERSON , who had decided to stay the night with the old woman, prepared to get out.

“I want you two CARDINAL to make up, y’hear DATE ?” Maude PERSON said before leaving. “ Yall PERSON come too far to let somethin come between you.”

But Diane PERSON got out of the car. “I’ll call for a ride from your place, Maude PERSON , if it’s all right.”

“I thought you wanted a ride home.” Vivian PERSON said.

“I’ll call Harry or Cherry PERSON to come pick me up,” Diane PERSON said.

“Now you both goin in the same direction,” Maude PERSON said. “Why don’t you let Vi PERSON take you home?” She stood on the sidewalk, her arm through Anita PERSON ’s.

“Suit yourself,” Vivian NORP said. She reached across the seat to close the door and drove away.

The streets were empty of life, though the snow was still falling lightly. Vivian NORP circled the block and went down M Street FAC until, at Thomas Circle FAC , she realized that that was not the way home. She could still see him…. And when she had turned the car around, it took a while to understand that she was only going in the general direction of home. She turned her windshield wipers up to their fullest speed and made her way through Northwest GPE , Northeast ORG , and then to Southeast NORP , where she pulled into the parking lot of a High’s store a few blocks from the Navy Yard ORG and the river Anacostia PERSON . She thought it would take only a moment TIME or two CARDINAL to collect herself.

She could still see him, and it came to her as she watched people go in and out of the High’s that she had not seen a man take off his hat in that old-fashioned way in a long, long time. It was a respectful gesture out of a country time when a little girl would watch dark young men tall as trees stand respectfully close to young women and say things that made the women put their hands to their mouths to stifle a giggle. The young women’s cotton print dresses billowed slightly with the summer DATE breezes, and even the billowing itself seemed to a little girl a part of all the secrets and romance that she could not yet take part in. And the young women always leaned back against the shadiest of trees with such utter self-assurance, holding a glass of lemonade that the men had brought out from the kitchen. And when the young women’s parents thought that there was too much in the giggles, they would tell the women to come up to the porch and bring so-and-so and get some more lemonade.

It was a time of perfect lemonade chilled with hunks of ice cut from larger blocks that were covered with straw and kept in root cellars. It was a time of pound cake baked to such a wondrous golden that it must have been a small sin to even cut into it. But perhaps God forgave, as he went on forgiving a little girl who watched the young men courting the young women, who watched them for so long that the flies set up house on her cake and all the ice in her glass melted and made her drink unpalatable.

Where had all such men gone when she herself came of age? Had the same things been said to the other women that were later said to her as she leaned back against her own tree?

In a cheap metal box in her closet in the house where Ralph Slater PERSON waited, she kept the licenses from her three CARDINAL marriages, along with the divorce documents. And from the first ORDINAL common-law marriage, she kept a letter, in childlike block letters and misspelled words, that the man had written to her from two thousand miles QUANTITY away, promising that they would be one CARDINAL forever.

She could still see him…. How much more grandness, beyond the gesture with the hat, was there to him? Her heart ached to know, and with both hands she held tight to the steering wheel, as if she were in danger of being swept away on some swelling tide. She did not want to think, though the words took shape and went in and sat down beside the man in his car—she did not want to think that God did not make such men anymore. And that if he still did, he should waste them all upon women like Diane McCollough PERSON .

She could see him, and slowly the image of him as she knew she would find him took hold. She could see him—asleep in the same chair she had left him in that morning TIME : Perhaps the Sunday DATE newspaper would be scattered at his feet, and maybe the wobbly TV-dinner table would be empty, for he would not want to bring down her wrath by keeping the remains of his dinner in the living room. Perhaps, too, he might have peed on himself again. And the television would be on, as it had been all day DATE , but aside from a football score here and there, he would not be able to remember what he had seen throughout the day DATE . But the wobbly table would not be empty—a few empty beer cans and one that would be half CARDINAL empty, along with his bottles of medicine and a tablespoon with which to take the liquid one.

A few people came and went about her, but the snow now covered the windows of her car and all she could make out were shadows moving about. She could hear voices, but she could not understand any of what people said, as if all sound were being filtered by the snow and turned into garble. She could not anymore read her watch, but she continued to tell herself that in the next minute TIME she would start up the car and go home to Ralph PERSON . In the end, it grew cold in the car, and colder still, and at first ORDINAL she did not notice, and then when she did, she thought it was the general condition of the whole world, owing to the snow, and that there was not very much she could do about it.





A NEW MAN




One day in late October, Woodrow L. Cunningham PERSON came home early with his bad heart and found his daughter with the two CARDINAL boys. He was then fifty-two years old DATE , a conscientious deacon at Rising Star AME Zion FAC , a paid-up lifetime member of the NAACP ORG and the Urban League ORG , a twenty-five year DATE member of the Elks GPE . For ten years DATE he had been the chief engineer at the Sheraton Park Hotel ORG , where practically every employee knew his name. For longer than he could recall, his friends and lodge members had been telling him that he was capable of being more than just the number-one maintenance man. But he always told them that he was contented in the job, that it was all he needed, and this was true for the most part. He would be in that same position some thirteen years later DATE , when death happened upon him as he bent down over a hotel bathroom sink, about to do a job a younger engineer claimed he could not handle.

The afternoon TIME he came home early and discovered his daughter with the boys, he found a letter in the mailbox from his father in Georgia GPE . He read the letter while standing in the hall of the apartment building. He expected nothing of importance, as usual, and that was what he found. “ Alice PERSON took me to Buddy Wilson ORG funeral just last week DATE ,” Woodrow PERSON read. “I loaned him the shirt they buried him in. And that tie he had on was one that I give him too. I thought I would miss him but I do not miss him very much. Checkers was never Buddy Wilsons ORG game.” As he read, he massaged the area around his heart, an old habit, something he did even when his heart was not giving him trouble. “I hope you and the family can come down before the winter months DATE set in. Company is never the same after winter DATE get here.”

He put the letter back in the envelope, and as he absently looked at the upside-down stamp taped in the vicinity of the corner, the pain in his heart eased. He could picture his father sitting at the kitchen table, writing the letter, occasionally touching the pencil point to his tongue. A new mongrel’s head would be resting across his lap, across thin legs that could still carry the old man five miles QUANTITY down the road and back. Woodrow, feeling better, considered returning to work, but he knew his heart was deceitful. He folded the envelope and stuck it in his back pocket, and out of the pocket it would fall late that night TIME as he prepared for bed after returning from the police station.



Several feet QUANTITY before he reached his apartment door he could hear the boys’ laughter and bits and pieces of their man-child conquer-the-world talk. He could not hear his daughter at first ORDINAL . He stopped at his door and listened for nearly five minutes TIME , and in that time he became so fascinated by what the boys were saying that he would not have cared if someone walking in the hall found him listening. It was only when he heard his daughter’s laughter, familiar, known, that he put his key in the door. She stood just inside the door when he entered, her eyes accusing but her mouth set in a small O of surprise. Beyond her he could see the boys with their legs draped over the arms of the couch and gray smoke above their heads wafting toward the open window.

He asked his daughter, “Why ain’t you in school?”

“They let us out early today TIME ,” she said. “The teachers had some kinda meetin PERSON .”

He did not listen to her, because he had found that she lived to lie. Woodrow PERSON watched the boys as they took their time straightening themselves up, and he knew that their deliberateness was the result of something his daughter had said about him. Without taking his eyes from the boys, he asked his daughter again why she wasn’t in school. When he finally looked at her, he saw that she was holding the stump of a thin cigarette. The smoke he smelled was unfamiliar, and at first ORDINAL he thought that they were smoking very stale cigarettes, or cigarettes that had gotten wet and been dried. He slapped her. “I told you not to smoke in my house,” he said.

She was fifteen DATE , and up until six months or so before DATE , she would have collapsed into the chair, collapsed into a fit of crying. But now she picked up the fallen cigarette from the floor and stamped it out in the ashtray on the tiny table beside the easy chair. Her hand shook, the only reminder of the old days DATE . “We just talkin. We ain’t doin nothin wrong,” she said quietly.

He shouted to the boys, “Get outta my house!” They stood up quickly, and Woodrow PERSON could tell that whatever she had told them about him, such anger was not part of it. They looked once at the girl.

“They my guests, Daddy,” she said, sitting in the easy chair and crossing her legs. “I invited em over here.”

Woodrow PERSON took two CARDINAL steps to the boy nearest him—the tall light-skinned one he would spot from a bus window a year or so later DATE —and grabbed him with one hand by the jacket collar, shook him until the boy raised his hands as if to protect his face from a blow. The boy’s eyes widened and Woodrow WORK_OF_ART shook him some more. He had been living a black man’s civilized life in Washington GPE and had not felt so coiled and bristled since the days DATE when he worked with wild men in the turpentine camps in Florida GPE . “I ain’t done nothin,” the boy said. The words sounded familiar, similar to those of a wild man ready to slink away into his cabin with his tail between his legs. Woodrow relaxed. “I swear. I don’t want no trouble, Mr. Cunningham PERSON .” The boy had no other smell but that peculiar cigarette smoke, and it was a shock to Woodrow PERSON that a body with that smell should know something that seemed as personal as his name. The other, smaller boy had tiptoed around Woodrow PERSON and was having trouble opening the door. After the small boy had gone out, Woodrow PERSON flung the light-skinned boy out behind him. Woodrow PERSON locked the door, and the boys stood for several minutes TIME , pounding on the door, mouthing off.

“Why you treat my guests like that?” Elaine Cunningham PERSON had not moved from the chair.

“Clean up this mess,” he told her, “and I don’t wanna see one CARDINAL ash when you done.”

She said nothing more, but busied herself tidying the couch cushions. Then Woodrow PERSON , after flicking the cushions a few times with his handkerchief, sat in the middle of the couch, and the couch sagged with the familiarity of this weight.

When Elaine PERSON had returned the room to what it was, her father said, “I want to know what you was doin in here with them boys.”

“ Nothin PERSON . We wasn’t doin nothin. Just talkin, thas all, Daddy.” She sat in the easy chair, leaned toward him with her elbows on her knees.

“You can do your talkin down on the stoop,” he said.

“Why don’t you just say you tryin to cuse me a somethin? Why don’t you just come out and say it?”

“If you didn’t do things, you wouldn’t get accused,” he said. He talked without thought, because those words and words like them had been spoken so much to her that he was able to parrot himself. “If you start actin like a young lady should, start studyin and what not, and tryin to make somethin of yourself…” Woodrow L. Cunningham PERSON bein Woodrow L. Cunningham PERSON , he thought.

She stood up quickly, and he was sickened to see her breasts bounce. “I could study them stupid books half CARDINAL the damn day DATE and sit in church the other half CARDINAL , and I’d still get the same stuff thrown in my face bout how I ain’t doin right.”

“Okay, thas anough a that.” He felt a familiar rumbling in his heart. “I done heard anough.”

“I wanna go out,” she stood with her arms folded. “I wanna go out.”

“Go on back to your room. Thas the only goin out you gonna be doin. I don’t wanna hear another word outta your mouth till your mother get home.” He closed his eyes to wait her out, for he knew she was now capable of standing there till doomsday to sulk. When he heard her going down the hall, he waited for the door to slam. But there was no sound and he gradually opened his eyes. He put a cushion at one CARDINAL end of the couch and took off his shoes and lay down, his hands resting on the large mound that was his stomach. All his friends told him that if he lost thirty or TIME forty pounds QUANTITY he would be a new man, but he did not think that was true. He considered asking Elaine PERSON to bring his pills from his bedroom, for he had left the vial he traveled with at work. But he suffered the pain rather than suffer her stirring about. He watched his wife’s curtains flap gently with the breeze and the movement soothed him.

“I would not say anything bad about mariage,” his father had written to Woodrow PERSON after Woodrow PERSON called to say he was considering marrying Rita Hadley PERSON . “It is easier to pick up and walk away from a wife and a family if you don’t like it then you can walk away from your own bad cooking.” Woodrow PERSON had never been inclined to marry anyone, was able, as he would tell his lodge brothers, to get all the trim he wanted without buying some woman a ring and walking down the aisle with her. “ Doin PERSON it to a woman for a few months DATE was all right,” he would say, sounding like his father, “cause that only put the idea of marryin in their heads. Doin it to them any more than that and the idea take root.”

It had never crossed his mind to sleep with any of the women at Rising Star AME ORG , for he had discovered in Georgia GPE that the wrath of church women was greater than that of all others, even old whores. He only went out with Rita PERSON because the preacher took him aside one Sunday DATE and told him it was unnatural to go about unmarried and that he should give some thought to promenading with Sister Rita PERSON sometime. And, too, he was thirty-six DATE and it was beginning to occur to him that women might not go on forever laying down and opening their legs for him. The second ORDINAL time they went out, he put his arm around Rita PERSON and pulled her to him there in the Booker-T Theater. She smacked his hand and that made his johnson PERSON hard. “I ain’t like that, Mr. Cunningham PERSON .” He had heard those words before. But when he pulled her to him again, she twisted his finger until it hurt. And that was something he had not experienced before.

His father suffered a mild stroke a week DATE before the wedding. “Do not take this sickness to mean that I do not send my blessing to your mariage to Miss Rita Hadley PERSON ,” his father said in a letter he had dictated to Alice PERSON , his oldest daughter. “God took pity on you when he send her your way.” Even in the unfamiliarity of Alice PERSON ’s handwriting, the familiarity of his father was there in all the lines, right down to the misspelled words. Until some of his father’s children learned in their teens, his father had been the only one in the family who could read and write. “This,” he said of his reading and writing, “makes me as good as a white man.” And before some of his children learned, discovered there was no magic to it, he enjoyed reading aloud at the supper table to his family, his voice stringing out a long monotone of words that often meant nothing to him and even less to his family because the man read so quickly.

His father read anything he could get his hands on—the words on feed bags, on medicine bottles, on years-old DATE magazine pages they used for wallpaper, just about everything except the Bible WORK_OF_ART . He had a fondness for weeks-old DATE newspapers he would find in the streets when he went to town. No one—not even the squirming small kids—was allowed to move from the supper table until he had finished reading, hooking one word to another until it all became babble. Indeed, it was such a babble that some of his sons would joke behind his back that he was lying about knowing how to read. “Few white men can do what I’m doin right now,” he would say. “You go bring ten CARDINAL white men in here and I bet nine CARDINAL couldn’t read this. Couldn’t read it if God commanded em to.” Sometimes, to torment his wife, he would hold a scrap of newspaper close to her face and tell her to read the headlines. “I cain’t,” she would say. “You know I cain’t.” No matter how many times he did this, his father would laugh with the pleasure of the very first ORDINAL time. Then he would pass the newspaper among his children and tell them to read him the headlines, and each one would hold it uncomfortably and repeat what their mother had said.



When Woodrow PERSON woke, it was nearly five o’clock TIME and his wife was sitting on the side of the couch, asking where Elaine PERSON was. “She ain’t in her room,” his wife said and kissed his forehead. A school cafeteria worker, Rita PERSON was a very thin woman who, before she met Woodrow PERSON , had lived only for her job and her church activities. She was five years DATE older than he was and had resigned herself to the fact that she was not the type of woman men wanted to marry. “I’ve put it all in God’s hands,” she once said to a friend before Woodrow PERSON came along, “and left it there.”

Rita PERSON waited until seven o’clock TIME before she began calling her daughter’s friends. “Stop worryin,” Woodrow PERSON told her after the tenth ORDINAL call, “you know how that girl is.” At eight-thirty TIME , they put on light coats and went in search, visiting the same houses and apartments that Rita PERSON had called. They returned home about ten CARDINAL and waited until eleven, when they put on their coats again and went to the police station at 16th ORDINAL and V Northwest. They did not call the station because somewhere Woodrow PERSON had heard that the law wouldn’t begin to hear a complaint unless you stood before it in person.

At the station, the man at the front desk did not look up until they had been standing there for some two minutes TIME . Woodrow PERSON wanted to tell him that the police chief and the mayor were now black men and that they couldn’t be ignored, but when the man behind the desk looked up, Woodrow PERSON could see in his eyes that none of that would have mattered to him.

“Our daughter is missing,” Rita PERSON said.

“How long?” said the man, a sergeant with an unpronounceable name on his name tag. He pulled a form from a pile to his left and then he took up a pen, loudly clicking out the point to write.

“We haven’t seen her since this afternoon TIME ,” Woodrow PERSON says.

The sergeant clicked the pen again and set it on the desk, then put the form back on top with the others. “Not long enough,” he said. “Has to be gone forty-eight hours TIME . Till then she’s missing, but she’s not a missing person.”

“She only a baby.”

“How old?”

“ Fifteen WORK_OF_ART ,” Woodrow PERSON said.

“She’s just a runaway,” the sergeant said.

“She never run away before,” Woodrow PERSON said. “This ain’t like her, sergeant.” Woodrow PERSON felt that like all white men, the man enjoyed having attention paid to his rank.

“Don’t matter. She’s probably waiting for you at home right now, wondering where you two CARDINAL buggied off to. Go home. If she isn’t home, then come back when she’s a missing person.”

Woodrow PERSON took Rita PERSON ’s arm as they went back, because he sensed that she was near collapsing. “What happened?” she asked as they turned the corner of U ORG and 10th ORDINAL streets. “Did you say somethin bad to her?”

He told her everything that he could remember, even what Elaine PERSON was wearing when he last saw her. Answering was not difficult because no blame had yet been assigned. Despite the time nearing midnight TIME , they became confident with each step that Elaine PERSON was just at a friend’s they did not know about, that the friend’s mother, like any good mother, would soon send their daughter home. Rita PERSON , in the last blocks before their apartment, leaned into her husband and his warmth helped to put her at ease.

They waited up until about four CARDINAL in the morning, and then they undressed without words in the dark. Rita PERSON began to cry the moment her head hit the pillow, for she was afraid to see the sun come up and find that a new day had arrived without Elaine PERSON being home. She asked him again what happened, and he told her again, even things that he had forgotten—the logo of the football team on the light-skinned boy’s jacket, the fact that the other boy was bald except for a half-dollar MONEY -sized spot of hair carved on the back of his head. He was still talking when she dozed off with him holding her.

Before they had coffee later that morning TIME , about seven thirty TIME , they called their jobs to say they would not be in. Work had always occupied a place at the center of their lives, and there was initially something eerie about being home when it was not a holiday or the weekend DATE . They spent the rest of the morning TIME searching the streets together, and in the afternoon TIME , they separated to cover more ground. They did the same thing after dinner, each spreading out farther and farther from their apartment on R Street FAC . That evening TIME , they called neighbors and friends, church and lodge members, to tell them that their child was missing and that they needed their help and their prayers. Their friends and neighbors began searching that evening TIME , and a few went with Woodrow PERSON and Rita PERSON the next day DATE to the police station to file a missing person’s report. A different sergeant was at the desk, and though he was a white man, Woodrow PERSON felt that he understood their trouble.

For nearly three months DATE , Woodrow PERSON and Rita PERSON searched after they came from work, and each evening after they and their friends had been out, the pastor of Rising Star ORG spoke to a small group that gathered in the Cunninghams ORG ’ living room. “The world is cold and not hospitable,” he would conclude, holding his hat in both hands, “but we know our God to be a kind God and that he has provided our little sister with a place of comfort and warmth until she returns to her parents and to all of us who love and treasure her.”

In the kitchen beside the refrigerator, Rita PERSON tacked up a giant map of Washington GPE , on which she noted where she and others had searched. “I didn’t know the city was this big,” she said the day DATE she put it up, her fingertips touching the neighborhoods that she had never heard of or had heard of only in passing—foreign lands she thought she would never set eyes on. Petworth PERSON . Anacostia. Lincoln Park ORG . And in the beginning, the very size of the city lifted her spirits, for in a place so big, there was certainly a spot that held something as small as her child, and if they just kept looking long enough, they would come upon that place.

“What happened?” Rita PERSON would ask as they prepared for bed. What he told her and her listening replaced everything they had ever done in that bed—discussing what future they wanted for Elaine PERSON , lovemaking, sharing what the world had done to them that workday. “What happened?” It was just about the only thing she ever asked Woodrow PERSON as the months DATE grew colder. “What happened? Whatcha say to her?” By late February DATE , when fewer and fewer people were going out to search, he had told the whole story, but then he began to tell her things that had not happened. There were three CARDINAL boys, he said at one CARDINAL point, for example. Or, he could see a gun sticking out of the jacket pocket of the light-skinned one CARDINAL , and he could see the outline of a knife in the back pants pocket of the third ORDINAL . Or he would say that the record player was playing so loudly he could hear it from the street. They were small embellishments at first ORDINAL , and if his wife noticed that the story of what happened was changing, she said nothing. In time, with winter DATE disappearing, he was adding more and more so that it was no longer a falseness here and there that was embedded in the whole of the truth, but the truth itself, an ever-diminishing kernel, that was contained in the whole of falseness. And, like some kind of bedtime story, she listened and drifted with his words into a sleep where the things he was telling her were sometimes happening.

By March DATE , Woodrow PERSON had written countless letters to his father telling the old man it was not necessary to come to Washington GPE to help look for the girl. “I got a sign from God,” the old man kept writing, “that I could help find her.” Then, with spring, he began writing that he had received signs that he was not long for the world, that finding the girl was the last thing God wanted him to do. In the longest letters the old man had ever written to the one CARDINAL child of his who responded, he would go on and on about the signs he saw signaling his own death: The mongrel would no longer take food from his hand; the dead visited him at night TIME , sitting down on the side of his bed and telling him things about himself; the rising sun now touched his house last in the morning TIME , though there were houses to the left and right of his.

“You keep telling me that I’ll be hurt or lost,” the old man wrote Woodrow PERSON . “But I know the way that Washington GPE , D.C. GPE is set up. I came there once maybe twice. How could I get lost. Take a chance on me, and we’ll have that child home before you can blink one CARDINAL eye. I can bring Sparky NORP he got some bloodhound in him.”

In late April DATE , Rita PERSON took down the map in the kitchen. The tacks fell to the floor and she left them there. She put the map in the bottom drawer of her daughter’s dresser, among the blouses and blue jeans and a diary she would not find the strength to read for another three months DATE . Her days of searching during the week DATE dwindled down to two CARDINAL , then to one. She returned the car a church member had lent her to drive around the city in. Each evening TIME when she got home, Woodrow PERSON would be out and she left his dinner in the oven to stay warm. Every now and again, when the hour TIME was late, she went out to look for him, often for no other reason than that there was nothing worth watching on the television. As she put on more and more weight, it became difficult for her to stand and dish out food to the students at lunchtime. Her supervisor and fellow workers sympathized, and, after a week DATE of perfunctory training, she was allowed to sit and work at the cash register.



As he continued going about the city, sometimes on foot, Woodrow PERSON told himself and everyone else that he was hunting for his daughter, but this was only a piece of the truth. “I’m lookin for my daughter, who’s run away,” he said to those opening the doors where he knocked. “She’s been gone a long time, and her mama and me are about to lose our minds.” He sometimes presented a picture of his daughter, smiling radiantly, that was taken only months DATE before she disappeared. But just as often, he would pull out a photograph of the girl when she was five CARDINAL , standing one CARDINAL Easter PRODUCT between her parents in front of Rising Star WORK_OF_ART . All who looked at the photograph, even the drunks half CARDINAL -blind with alcohol, were touched by the picture of the little girl in her Easter FAC dress who had now gone away from her parents, parents who were now worried sick. Many people invited Woodrow PERSON into their homes.

The Easter PRODUCT picture became a passport, and the more places he visited the more places he wanted to see. On U Street FAC , a woman of twenty-five CARDINAL or so with three CARDINAL children put down the child she was holding to get a better look at the picture of the five-year-old DATE girl. Woodrow PERSON , in the doorway, noted just over her shoulder that on her wall there was a calendar with a snow-covered mountain, hung with the prominence others would have given a landscape painting. An old woman on Harvard Street FAC , tsk-tsking as she looked at the picture, invited him in for coffee and cake. “My prayers go out to you.” Nearly everything in her apartment was covered in plastic, even the pictures on the walls. The old woman sat him on her plastic-covered couch and placed the food on a coffee table covered with a plastic cloth. “And such a sweet-lookin child, too, son.” When he asked to use the bathroom (more out of curiosity than for relief), she pointed to a plastic path leading away down the hall. “Stay on the mat, son.”

A tottering man in a place on 21st Street FAC just off Benning Road FAC began to cry when Woodrow PERSON told him his story. “ Dora PERSON , Dora PERSON ,” the man called to a woman. “Come see this little angel.” The woman, who was also tottering, pulled Woodrow PERSON into their house with one hand, while the other hand pressed the picture to her bosom. The man and Woodrow PERSON sat on the couch. The woman stood in front of them, swaying trancelike, her eyes closed, the picture still pressed to her. The man put his arm around Woodrow PERSON and breathed a sour wine smell into his face. “Let’s me and you pray about this situation,” he said.



One CARDINAL April evening, a little more than a year and a half DATE after their daughter disappeared, Rita PERSON was standing in front of their building, waiting for him. “We have fish tonight TIME . It’s in the stove waitin,” she said, in the same way she would have said, “I know what you been doin. And who you been doin it with.” “We have fish to eat,” she said again. She turned around and went back inside. “We have fish, and we have to move from this place,” she said.



Woodrow WORK_OF_ART ’s father died nearly seven years DATE after Elaine Cunningham PERSON disappeared. Of the eight CARDINAL children he had had with Woodrow PERSON ’s mother and the five CARDINAL he had had with other women, only Woodrow PERSON , Alice PERSON , and a half-brother who lived down the road from the old man came to the funeral. It was a frozen day in January DATE , and the gravediggers broke two CARDINAL picks before they had even gone down one foot QUANTITY . They labored seven hours TIME to make a hole for the old man. “Even the ground don’t want him,” said one CARDINAL of the old man’s friends standing at the gravesite.

There was not much in the old man’s place to divide among his heirs. In a wooden trunk in one CARDINAL of the back rooms, Woodrow GPE found several pictures of his mother. He had been kneeling down, going through the trunk, and when he saw the pictures, he cried out as if he had been struck. He had not seen his mother’s face in more than forty years DATE , had thought his father had destroyed all the pictures of her. “You always looked like her,” Alice PERSON said, coming up behind him. “Even when you sat at the right hand of the father, you looked like her.”

Though he was younger than three CARDINAL other brothers, Woodrow PERSON had worked hardest of his father’s children. At first ORDINAL , his father had sat his children about the supper table according to their ages, but then he began to seat them according to who did the most work. His best workers sat closest to him, and by the time he was seven CARDINAL , Woodrow PERSON had worked his way to the right hand of his father. Woodrow PERSON ’s mother sat at the far end of the table, between two CARDINAL of her daughters. Most of his brothers and sisters, unable to pick the amount of cotton Woodrow PERSON could, never forgave him for living only to be close to their father. But he learned to pay them no mind and even learned to enjoy their hostility. He never moved from that right-hand place until the day DATE he went off down the road to work in the turpentine camps.

He also found in the trunk some letters he wrote his father from the camps and from railroad yards and from the places he worked as he made his way up to Washington GPE . They were all of one CARDINAL page or less, and they were all about work, work from sunup to sundown. There were no friends mentioned, there were no descriptions of places where he lived, there were no names of women courted, loved. “I got a two-week DATE job tanning hides,” he wrote from a nameless place in South Carolina GPE . “I got work cureing tobacco. I may stay on after the season,” he wrote from somewhere near Raleigh ORG . “I have been working in the stables outside Charlotesvile ORG . The pay is good. I got used to the smell. and the work goes easy.”

Woodrow PERSON and Rita PERSON took the train back to Washington GPE , bringing back a few of the pictures and none of the letters, which he burned in a barrel outside his father’s house. Everything along the way back to D.C. GPE was as frozen as Georgia GPE . It was as if the cold had separated the world into three CARDINAL unrelated and distinct parts—the earth LOC , what was on the earth LOC , and the sky above. Nothing moved. Flying birds seemed to freeze in midair GPE , and then the cold would nail them there.

Rita PERSON and Woodrow PERSON were back in the apartment on Independence Avenue FAC in Southeast by ten o’clock that night TIME . Rita PERSON took her usual place at an easy chair near the window. On a table beside the chair was all she needed—the television guide, snacks, the telephone. The chair was very large and had had to be specially ordered, because she could not fit into the regular ones in the store.

Woodrow PERSON , even though the hour TIME was late and the weather people were predicting even colder temperatures, quietly put on his heaviest coat and left the apartment. He said nothing to Rita PERSON , and she did not look up when the door locked behind him. At the corner of Independence and 15th, Woodrow PERSON looked into the grocery store window at the owner he had become friends with since moving to Southeast LOC . No customers went into the store, and the owner was dozing behind the counter, his head back, his mouth open. Woodrow PERSON watched him for a very long time. By now he knew everything about the man and his store and the sons who helped the man, and there was no urgency to be inside with him. Having lost so much weight, Woodrow PERSON felt that even more of the world had opened up to him. And so he wondered if he should go on down 15th Street FAC , try to find a house he had not visited before, and bring out the picture of the child in her Easter PRODUCT dress.





A DARK NIGHT WORK_OF_ART About four CARDINAL that afternoon TIME the thunder and lightning began again. The four CARDINAL women seated about Carmena Boone ORG ’s efficiency apartment grew still and spoke in whispers, when they spoke at all: They were each of them no longer young, and they had all been raised to believe that such weather was—aside from answered prayers—the closest thing to the voice of God. And so each in her way listened.

They heard an apartment door down the long hall to the right open and close with utter violence, obviously pushed shut by the wind of the storm. Within seconds TIME , they saw Ida Garrett PERSON move almost soundlessly past Carmena Boone PERSON ’s open door, a rubber-tipped brown cane in her good hand. She went the few yards to the end of the hall on the left and knocked again and again and again at what everyone in the room knew was the door of Beatrice Atwell’s PERSON apartment. Beatrice PERSON was sitting in the middle of Carmena GPE ’s couch, snug between the large Frazier sisters from the fifth ORDINAL floor. Then, just as soundlessly, Mrs. Garrett PERSON was standing small and silent in Boone LOC ’s doorway. She could not have looked any more forlorn if she had been out in the storm: breathing as if each breath would be her last, her wig perched haphazardly on her head as if it had been dropped from the ceiling by accident, her pocketbook hanging from the arm that a stroke had permanently folded against her body, her eyeglasses resting near the end of her nose, beyond where they could possibly do her any good.

“I was passin,” she said with effort to Carmena GPE , “and I saw your door was open.” Leaning against the doorjamb, she blinked in an effort to adjust to a room that was lit by only a forty-watt QUANTITY bulb, another concession to the voice of God. Several times, she shifted the scarred cane from the good hand to the bad, and just when the bad hand seemed about to drop it, she would take it back. “I was passin and saw your door was open, Boone….”

She continued to repeat herself until Carmena GPE stood and went to her, reassured Mrs. Garrett PERSON with a light touch of the hand. “You know you always welcome here, Miss Garrett PERSON .” She took the woman’s elbow and led her to a chair at the dining table. “I was thinkin bout you, me and the Fraziers, but somebody said you’d been under the weather, so I thought I shouldn’t bother you.”

It began to rain, no more than a soft tapping at the window.

“I’m fine, by the help of the Lord,” Mrs. Garrett PERSON said, sitting. She settled herself, patting her wig and making sure her dress was well down over her knees. Her movements seemed practiced, like those of someone who did everything according to the way it was set out in some book. She placed her cane across her lap and leisurely began to pick pieces of lint off her dress, a silklike, polka-dotted thing that shimmered with what seemed huge green eyes. Then, with a flash of lightning and burst of thunder, she jerked her head up, as if the whole thing had been directed at her personally, the thunder an inch from her ear and the lightning just in front of her eyes. She waited, and when there was quiet for several minutes TIME , she sighed, then began to take note of the four CARDINAL other women. They had been watching her intently, but when she looked at them, they nodded and lowered their eyes or deftly turned their heads away. Only when they were addressed by name did the women look at her, smile, ask how she was keeping. Beatrice PERSON , knitting on the couch between the Frazier ORG sisters, did not look up.

“I’m surprised to see you here,” Mrs. Garrett PERSON said to her. “I thought you might be home.” There was a bit of hurt to the last words.

“No,” Beatrice PERSON said happily. “I’m here. I’m right here.” It seemed to give her so much pleasure to say these words that she repeated them again and again until she raised a thread to her mouth and bit it in two CARDINAL . “I’ve come for the prayer meetin.”

“So thas what all yall hens here for?” Mrs. Garrett PERSON said and turned to Carmena GPE at the other end of the table. Carmena PERSON nodded with a smile. “Oh, but I hope yall ain’t gonna have that Reverend Sawyer PERSON again. He ain’t nothin but jackleg, Boone LOC . I could tell the first ORDINAL time I laid eyes on him. ‘ Jackleg PERSON ,’ I said to myself. ‘As jackleg as they come.’”

Carmena PERSON , seeking support, glanced at the others. “It’s him. But he got a church of his own now, Miss Garrett PERSON . Out in Northwest ORG , just off Rhode Island Avenue FAC .”

“Havin a church, Boone ORG , don’t mount to a hill of beans,” Mrs. Garrett PERSON said with exasperation. “It don’t make a man a preacher, called by God. Even I”—she put her good hand over her heart—“could say I’m a man a God, but that don’t make it so. All havin a church means is you got a little money to rent a hole in the wall and a few fools to come to the hole and give you their pennies.”

“Well, I ain’t a member of his church,” Carmena PERSON said defensively, “and don’t plan to be a member. And I ain’t never give him money to come here to pray with us.” Mrs. Garrett PERSON smiled knowingly. “I do have some food for us all when he get here. But thas a everyday normal courtesy. Some sandwiches…some cake and punch…just things I picked up round the corner…whatn’t no trouble….”

Mrs. Garrett PERSON looked askance at the food displayed on the table. “He’ll fill hisself up off that, belch once, and look for more,” she said. She leaned down and placed her cane on the floor beside her. “And what time is this man a God spected on the premises?”

“He said three CARDINAL thirty,” Carmena PERSON said.

“ Three thirty TIME , huh? And all the clocks in the world now sayin it’s way past four CARDINAL .”

Carmena PERSON shut the window just as the rain began to come in. With only the forty-watt QUANTITY burning in the lamp on the table, the room was on the verge of darkness. But each flash of lightning would give a ghastly brightness to the place and for those moments everything in the room could be clearly seen.

“And what you doin over there, Atwell GPE , workin away like a tiny little mouse?” Mrs. Garrett PERSON said.

“ Sewin WORK_OF_ART ,” Beatrice ORG said. “Makin somethin for my new grandchild.”

“Oh, Lani PERSON dropped another one, huh? You didn’t even tell me.”

“A girl. A little over a month ago DATE .” The two CARDINAL Frazier ORG sisters on either side of Beatrice ORG were tall women, each weighing about 200 pounds QUANTITY , and they seemed to spread out much more than when they were standing. Beatrice PERSON weighed little more than 110 pounds, and if there had been no words from her, she might well have gone unnoticed.

“And you never told me,” Mrs. Garrett PERSON said. “ Tsk tsk tsk PERSON . I always thought well of Lani PERSON .” She turned slowly to Carmena GPE , and as she turned, her smiled widened. “But that husband of Lani PERSON ’s keeps her havin babies. Who can keep up with how many they have? She’s the babiest-havin woman I ever knowed of. One after the other after the other….”

Silent ORG and still except for the motions of her hands, Beatrice PERSON never looked up.



Carmena PERSON prayed for the Reverend Sawyer PERSON to turn up. If nothing stopped her, Mrs. Garrett PERSON would sit in that chair and rain down devilment all day DATE and all night TIME and all day some more. Carmena PERSON thought it had to do with her being ninety-one years old DATE and thinking she was closer to God than any human being in the world. Mrs. Garrett PERSON and Beatrice PERSON had once been so close that people joked they would be buried together in the same casket. Now Mrs. Garrett PERSON was forever after Beatrice ORG as if the final task standing between her and the key to heaven was to make Beatrice ORG suffer. Beatrice ORG , however, treated Mrs. Garrett PERSON as she would a child who didn’t know any better.



Toward five thirty TIME , not long after Mrs. Garrett PERSON had asked again what time the Reverend Doctor Sawyer PERSON was supposed to arrive, the telephone rang. Carmena PERSON answered and spoke but a few words before hanging up. She announced that it had been Reverend Sawyer PERSON ’s wife, that his car would not start and that he apologized to everyone for not being able to make the prayer meeting. Waving her hand over the table, she told her guests that there was no need to let the food go to waste, and one by one the women got up and helped themselves. The storm, the thunder and lightning, had stopped, but there was still the rain, a nuisance scratching at the window.

Once the women were seated again, the conversation took varied turns, and the autumn evening wore away. Mrs. Garrett PERSON , perhaps dulled by the food, had less to say than anyone. At one CARDINAL point, the Frazier ORG sister nearest the window commented on how particularly bad the weather had been lately. They all agreed, and Mrs. Garrett PERSON , capping one hand over her knee, said that she could not remember when Old Man Arthur PERSON and the Ritis PERSON boys had caused her so much pain, that sometimes she felt she would never walk again. The other women gave sympathetic nods, one CARDINAL or two CARDINAL mentioning their own aches and pains, and then they all began to exchange remedies. Beatrice ORG stuck her needle with finality into the piece she was working on and put it in a cloth bag at her feet. Looking about the room, she said quietly, “It all reminds me of one summer DATE back home. It was kinda GPE like it is now, day after day.”

“Oh, now, Atwell ORG , we ain’t gonna have one CARDINAL a your down-home, way-back-when stories, are we?” Mrs. Garrett PERSON said. “We ain’t had a evenin of prayer, but we been tryin to keep it as close to that as we can.”

“How, Bea PERSON ?” Carmena PERSON said, ignoring Mrs. Garrett PERSON . “How does this remind you of back home?” Mrs. Garrett PERSON rubbed the elbow of her bad arm, then put the bad hand in the center of her lap.

Beatrice ORG said nothing for several seconds TIME . “It thundered and lightened a lot then, too,” she said. “I guess I was sixteen DATE or seventeen CARDINAL and this fella I was keepin company with was sittin PERSON with me and my daddy on my daddy’s porch. There was a storm comin on while we were sittin PERSON there. There had already been a lotta rain, but not anough to do that much damage to the crops. I remember it was late in the evenin and so dark I could barely make out what was three feet QUANTITY in front a me. It was already rainin when the thunder and lightnin come up, and we was just sittin PERSON and talkin PERSON .

“Maybe a half hour or more into that storm, I started seein this figure, this thing, that kinda GPE just stood in that corn patch in my mother’s garden. If I didn’t know the garden, I woulda thought it was a scarecrow or somethin. It was no further than from here to that television there. I looked and looked, tryin to see into all that dark, and then I told myself it was just a big corn stalk leanin out heavy with the rain. It made a move a corn stalk ain’t supposed to make but I tried not to think about it. ‘It’s corn,’ I said to myself. But when this thing moved again—moved different from all the other corn—I said this real quiet ‘Oh.’ I touched the fella I was keepin company with and pointed and we looked together. My daddy looked, too. This corn stalk, this thing, said, ‘ Uncle…Uncle…Bea WORK_OF_ART …’ Then it moved a few steps toward us. It was this cousin a mine, John Henry PERSON . He came even closer and just dropped heavy to the ground, cryin like a baby.

“I said, ‘ John Henry PERSON , whas wrong? What is it?’ My daddy was already gettin up. ‘It’s them,’ he said. He was cryin so hard that I could barely make out what he was sayin. ‘It’s them,’ he kept sayin. ‘They just sittin there.’

“My daddy went down the steps to him, and when he touched John Henry PERSON , John Henry PERSON just jumped right up, real quick, like he was some doll and somethin had pulled him up by the neck. He took off down the path that led from his place to where we lived. The three CARDINAL of us—my daddy, me and this fella I was keepin company with—took off after him. It was rainin way harder than it is right now and we was soaked through fore we even took a few steps. All the way down there, I kept prayin, ‘Lord, don’t let me get struck by lightnin.’

“When we got to the house, John Henry PERSON was there lookin in the front door. ‘ John Henry PERSON ,’ my daddy said, ‘ John Henry PERSON .’ We got there and looked in too. Everybody was just sittin around like he had said. My Uncle Joe PERSON , his wife Ebbie PERSON , her mother, and my Uncle Ray. There was a pipe stickin in Uncle Ray’s PERSON mouth, not lit, just stickin there like he did sometimes. The only light was from a coal-oil lamp on the mantlepiece and from a real small fire in the fireplace. It never crossed my mind why they would have a fire burnin on a summer DATE evenin. But there it was—this one log that they kept there all spring DATE and all summer DATE , and it was steady burnin right in the center. I think I thought to myself how dark they all looked, but I put that to how feeble the light in the room was. They was all kinda GPE gathered around the hearth, which wasn’t too strange cause yall know how some folks use the fireplace for the center of the house all year DATE round. There was a buncha smells in that room. One CARDINAL was the kind you get when wood gets wet, and another was burnt hair. But around all of the smells was this one I hadn’t smelled before and ain’t smelled since. It was everything dead you had ever come across in your whole life piled at one CARDINAL time in that room.

“‘ Joe PERSON . Ray PERSON ,’ my daddy said to his bothers. Uncle Joe PERSON was sittin in that chair he’d made with his own hands, and he was starin at us. No, not really at us, kinda through us and around us at the same time. ‘ Joe PERSON .’ My daddy went over to him. ‘ Joseph PERSON !’ My daddy touched him and my uncle did nothin. Then my daddy pulled on my uncle’s shirt front and my uncle fell into my daddy’s arms, right into his arms, like some dime-store dummy. And that told us right then that he and everybody else was gone. It told me anyway. The fella I was keepin company with just said, ‘ Jesus PERSON Christ!’ I fixed my eyes on him when he said that. I was feelin all kinds of things standin there, and you know, one CARDINAL a them was this feelin that I couldn’t ever keep company with that boy again.

“I looked around the room. This long black line that had cut a rut in the floor went from the fireplace through that group a people right out the room to the kitchen—like somebody had took a big fireball of barbed wire and run cross the floor with it.

“They was just sittin PERSON there and they was all gone. You could see where Aunt Ebbie ORG ’s mother had been rockin the crib with Aunt Ebbie ORG ’s baby in it. A wind was coming down the chimney and through the door, and it was rockin the crib, rockin Aunt Ebbie ORG ’s mother’s hand right along with it. I thought the baby was dead, too, but when I saw a leg twitch, I knowed he was alive. I picked him up and he didn’t look surprised to see me, he didn’t look happy or sad or anything. Just a baby waiting for the next thing in his life to happen. I put Aunt Ebbie ORG ’s mother’s hand in her lap. I did it calm-like and I was surprised at myself, the way I was actin. I musta been scared somewhere inside, but it was a long time before I knowed it. And then it stayed and never went away.

“‘ Lightnin WORK_OF_ART ,’ the fella I was keepin company with said. ‘Lightnin.’ My daddy had put his brother back in the chair and he was standin there lookin down at him and my uncle Ray PERSON . The fella I was keepin company with pointed at the way the black line ran along the floor and out of the room. ‘Just came down the chimney, Mista Davenport PERSON ,’ he said, proud that he knew what he knew. ‘Look at it!’ And we looked again when he said that, not so much cause a what he said, but cause somethin in our heads told us to make a everlastin memory of it.

“ John Henry PERSON came into the house and went on out into the kitchen, his mud tracks walkin right over that black line. I followed him and I seen where the black line came to the kitchen table and hopped right up on it, threw everything every which way, then jumped back down to the floor and ran out the back door. One CARDINAL a the straightest lines you’d ever wanna see. John Henry PERSON ’s little sister was sittin at the table. Alma was alive. She was cryin real soft, and I don’t think she’d moved since it happened. John Henry PERSON sat down and put his head in his hands. He started cryin again. All of a sudden I got weak as that dishrag there. I held the baby and watched them children. Their whole family. My family too. People who’d never done a moment’s harm to a soul. Not one CARDINAL moment’s harm. Somethin in me was struck by that when I started thinkin of Uncle Ray’s PERSON pipe stickin in his mouth and when I saw that one of Alma ORG ’s plaits had come loose, like they do on little girls. I didn’t know what else to do so I leaned Alma ORG ’s head against my stomach. Then I told em that it would be all right, but it didn’t mean anything and I knew it. If somebody had told me to say that tomorrow would be Easter PERSON , I woulda said that instead. But I kept sayin that everything would be all right until my daddy came in and picked Alma up and told us he was takin us home….”



The other women in Carmena Boone LOC ’s apartment were all quiet, and they were quiet for a long time. The rain had long since stopped. Finally, Mrs. Garrett PERSON said, “The Lord works in mysterious ways.” Her dentures made a soft clicking sound as she spoke. “For good or for bad, the Lord seeks you out and finds you. There ain’t no two CARDINAL ways about that.” She looked about the room as if for confirmation, and when no one said anything, she seemed to fold up into silence.

They were all quiet again, until Mrs. Garrett PERSON began to talk about the eleventh of August, 1894, the night she was saved…. The others looked knowingly at one another. The story never changed: a huge tent and an itinerant preacher and a little girl who was overcome that night TIME with something she would years later DATE learn to call the Holy Ghost WORK_OF_ART . She had been frightened at first ORDINAL , with this thing that commanded without talking, she said, but it comforted her and led her down the aisle of the tent to the preacher’s outstretched arms. The story, after a thousand CARDINAL tellings, had ceased being an experience to share but was more like an incantation she had to chant to reaffirm for herself the importance of that night.

“He said I was the youngest person in five CARDINAL counties to ever be saved, to ever find the Lord,” she was saying. “Reverend Dickinson PERSON told me that, told everybody in the tent. And I’ve walked in the light of the Lord ever since….”

“Why don’t yall have some more a this cake?” Carmena PERSON said. “Or take it with you. I’ll never eat it all.” She provided aluminum foil and each woman put two CARDINAL slices in the foil and prepared to leave. At the door, as they said their good nights, Carmena PERSON asked Beatrice PERSON to tell that joke she had heard her tell once, the one CARDINAL about the dark night. Before Beatrice ORG had said a word, Mrs. Garrett PERSON made her way through the group and went to her apartment. After they heard Mrs. Garrett PERSON lock her door, Carmena PERSON asked again to tell about the dark night.

“Well, my daddy,” Beatrice ORG said, “my daddy and my uncle Joe PERSON would fun around a lot, mostly for us kids, like two CARDINAL fellas on a radio show. Every now and then my daddy would say, ‘ Joe PERSON , what’s the darkest night you ever knowed? Tell me, Joe PERSON .’ My uncle Joe PERSON would play with his chin for a bit, like he was thinkin. ‘ Les PERSON see,’ he’d say. ‘Les see…oh, yes. Oh, yes. I member this one night TIME I was sittin at home all by my lonesome, nobody for company but the four CARDINAL walls and the memory of company. It commenced to rain and rain, and I heard this knockin at my door. So I get up and opened the door. Well, sir, who was it but these raindrops—a whole passel of raindrops—lookin down at me, lookin PERSON scared and cold. And the one in front says to me in this real squeaky voice, ‘ Mista PERSON , it’s so dark out here, so very dark. Would you please mind tellin us which way it is to the ground?…And that,’ my uncle would say, ‘is the darkest night I ever knowed.’ And we all bust out laughin, specially the little kids, who thought it was the funniest thing in the world to have talkin raindrops.”

The women laughed, too. Then they all hugged good night, each saying that they would not be long out of bed.



About four CARDINAL that morning TIME the thunder and lightning began again. At the first ORDINAL blast of thunder, a sleeping Mrs. Garrett PERSON sprang up in her bed, like a puppet jerked suddenly to life by its master, her head turning first ORDINAL this way and then the other. Her heart, usually so docile, began to throw itself about its cage. “Oh, dear Jesus PERSON ,” she whispered. She flung back the covers with her good arm and swung her legs out of the bed, and in reaching for her glasses, she tipped over the plastic cup that contained her teeth. She did not bother to pick them up, but threw on her robe and took up her cane. The lightning lit her way to the door. Taking her key from a small table, she went out the door, and the wind closed it behind her with such viciousness that she nearly fell to the hall floor.

As she moved down the hall, an enclosed area with no windows, she could hear the clamor of thunder and the whistling of wind coming from under the doors of the apartments. With their half CARDINAL -globe coverings, the ceiling lights provided a long line of moons all the way down the hall. She knocked lightly at Beatrice ORG ’s door, and when Mrs. Garrett PERSON heard a thunder boom come from under the door of the next apartment, she knocked with greater insistence.

“Who is it?” Beatrice ORG asked.

“It’s me.”

There was a long, long pause, then Beatrice ORG asked again, “Who is it?”

“It’s me. Me!”

There was a pause again, but Beatrice ORG unlocked the door and took off the chain and cracked the door. Mrs. Garrett PERSON avoided Beatrice PERSON ’s eyes and stared into the heart of the flame of the candle Beatrice ORG was holding.

“ Bea PERSON , it’s me,” Mrs. Garrett PERSON said.

“Why you all the time knockin at my door, woman?” Beatrice ORG said. “We ain’t no friends no more, or did you forget that?” The candle’s flame swayed with each word she spoke.

“ Please, Bea WORK_OF_ART . You know how it can be. Please don’t leave me out here. Have some pity.”

With two CARDINAL thunderclaps, Beatrice ORG opened the door. “You lucky,” she said, shutting and locking her door. “I was just about ready to go in that bathroom, and you know when I go in there I don’t come out for a soul.” Her hair was in plaits and she wore a nightgown that swept the floor as she moved.

“Thank you,” Mrs. Garrett PERSON mumbled, still looking only into the flame. “Thank you so much.”

Beatrice ORG did not help Mrs. Garrett PERSON with her chair, and in the end, Mrs. Garrett PERSON had to drop her cane and drag the chair into the bathroom with her good arm. The cane hit the floor with a clatter.

“There are people sleepin!” Beatrice ORG said from inside the bathroom.

When Mrs. Garrett PERSON had made her way with the chair into the bathroom, Beatrice ORG closed the door, and as soon as she did there was the ripping sound of thunder that bounded across the outside room and found its way under the door of the windowless bathroom.

Beatrice ORG set the candle in the sink, then she spread a blanket across the door’s threshold, Mrs. Garrett PERSON put her chair beside the hamper made into the wall. With a sigh Beatrice put down the toilet cover and sat down.

“How long you think it might last, Bea PERSON . How long?”

“Why you always ask me such stupid goddamn questions!”

The blanket did nothing to moderate the violence of the thunder, and it continued to sound as if it were outside the door. “Ain’t you gonna blow out the candle?” Mrs. Garrett PERSON said. Beatrice ORG leaned over and blew lightly, and in the quickest of moments, the room was engulfed in darkness. Mrs. Garrett PERSON began to pray, a long, monotonous mumble of words. Once or twice a boom would produce a small yelp of surprise from each woman, but they did not comfort one another. Over time, the intensity of the thunder grew until it was like a pounding at the bathroom door. And each time it pounded, the women would look toward the door as if they were making up their minds whether to get up and answer it.





MARIE




Every now and again, as if on a whim, the federal government people would write to Marie Delaveaux Wilson PERSON in one CARDINAL of those white, stampless envelopes and tell her to come in to their place so they could take another look at her. They, the Social Security ORG people, wrote to her in a foreign language that she had learned to translate over the years DATE , and for all the years DATE she had been receiving the letters the same man had been signing them. Once, because she had something important to tell him, Marie PERSON called the number the man always put at the top of the letters, but a woman answered Mr. Smith PERSON ’s telephone and told Marie PERSON he was in an all-day DATE meeting. Another time she called and a man said Mr. Smith PERSON was on vacation. And finally one day DATE a woman answered and told Marie PERSON that Mr. Smith PERSON was deceased. The woman told her to wait and she would get someone new to talk to her about her case, but Marie PERSON thought it bad luck to have telephoned a dead man and she hung up.

Now, years after the woman had told her Mr. Smith PERSON was no more, the letters were still being signed by John Smith PERSON . Come into our office at 21st ORDINAL and M streets, Northwest ORG , the letters said in that foreign language. Come in so we can see if you are still blind in one CARDINAL eye, come in so we can see if you are still old and getting older. Come in so we can see if you still deserve to get Supplemental Security Income payments.

She always obeyed the letters, even if the order now came from a dead man, for she knew people who had been temporarily cut off from SSI for not showing up or even for being late. And once cut off, you had to move heaven and earth to get back on.

So on a not unpleasant day in March DATE , she rose in the dark in the morning TIME , even before the day DATE had any sort of character, to give herself plenty of time to bathe, eat, lay out money for the bus, dress, listen to the spirituals on the radio. She was eighty-six years old DATE , and had learned that life was all chaos and painful uncertainty and that the only way to get through it was to expect chaos even in the most innocent of moments. Offer a crust of bread to a sick bird and you often drew back a bloody finger.

John Smith PERSON ’s letter had told her to come in at eleven o’clock TIME , his favorite time, and by nine QUANTITY that morning she had had her bath and had eaten. Dressed by nine thirty TIME . The walk from Claridge Towers ORG at 12th DATE and M down to the bus stop at 14th ORDINAL and K ORG took her about ten minutes TIME , more or less. There was a bus at about ten thirty TIME , her schedule told her, but she preferred the one that came a half hour earlier TIME , lest there be trouble with the ten thirty TIME bus. After she dressed, she sat at her dining room table and went over still again what papers and all else she needed to take. Given the nature of life—particularly the questions asked by the Social Security ORG people—she always took more than they might ask for—her birth certificate, her husband’s death certificate, doctor’s letters.



One CARDINAL of the last things she put in her pocketbook was a seven-inch QUANTITY or so knife that she had, with the use of a small saw borrowed from a neighbor, serrated on both edges. The knife, she was convinced now, had saved her life about two weeks DATE before. Before then she had often been careless about when she took the knife out with her, and she had never taken it out in daylight, but now she never left her apartment without it, even when going down the hall to the trash drop.

She had gone out to buy a simple box of oatmeal, no more, no less. It was about seven CARDINAL in the evening, the streets with enough commuters driving up 13th Street FAC to make her feel safe. Several yards QUANTITY before she reached the store, the young man came from behind her and tried to rip off her coat pocket where he thought she kept her money, for she carried no purse or pocketbook after five o’clock TIME . The money was in the other pocket with the knife, and his hand caught in the empty pocket long enough for her to reach around with the knife and cut his hand as it came out of her pocket.

He screamed and called her an old bitch. He took a few steps up 13th Street FAC and stood in front of Emerson’s Market ORG , examining the hand and shaking off blood. Except for the cars passing up and down 13th Street FAC , they were alone, and she began to pray.

“You cut me,” he said, as if he had only been minding his own business when she cut him. “Just look what you done to my hand,” he said and looked around as if for some witness to her crime. There was not a great amount of blood, but there was enough for her to see it dripping to the pavement. He seemed to be about twenty, no more than twenty-five, dressed the way they were all dressed nowadays, as if a blind man had matched up all their colors. It occurred to her to say that she had seven CARDINAL grandchildren his age, that by telling him this he would leave her alone. But the more filth he spoke, the more she wanted him only to come toward her again.

“You done crippled me, you old bitch.”

“I sure did,” she said, without malice, without triumph, but simply the way she would have told him the time of day DATE had he asked and had she known. She gripped the knife tighter, and as she did, she turned her body ever so slightly so that her good eye lined up with him. Her heart was making an awful racket, wanting to be away from him, wanting to be safe at home. I will not be moved, some organ in the neighborhood of the heart told the heart. “And I got plenty more where that come from.”

The last words seemed to bring him down some and, still shaking the blood from his hand, he took a step or two CARDINAL back, which disappointed her. I will not be moved, that other organ kept telling the heart. “You just crazy, thas all,” he said. “Just a crazy old hag.” Then he turned and lumbered up toward Logan Circle PERSON , and several times he looked back over his shoulder as if afraid she might be following. A man came out of Emerson ORG ’s, then a woman with two CARDINAL little boys. She wanted to grab each of them by the arm and tell them she had come close to losing her life. “I saved myself with this here thing,” she would have said. She forgot about the oatmeal and took her raging heart back to the apartment. She told herself that she should, but she never washed the fellow’s blood off the knife, and over the next few days DATE it dried and then it began to flake off.



Toward ten o’clock TIME that morning Wilamena Mason PERSON knocked and let herself in with a key Marie PERSON had given her.

“I see you all ready,” Wilamena ORG said.

“With the help of the Lord,” Marie PERSON said. “Want a spot a coffee?”

“No thanks,” Wilamena ORG said, and dropped into a chair at the table. “Been drinkin so much coffee lately, I’m gonna turn into coffee. Was up all night TIME with Calhoun PERSON .”

“How he doin?”

Wilamena ORG told her Calhoun PERSON was better that morning TIME , his first good morning TIME in over a week DATE . Calhoun Lambeth PERSON was Wilamena GPE ’s boyfriend, a seventy-five-year-old DATE man she had taken up with six or so months before DATE , not long after he moved in. He was the best-dressed old man Marie PERSON had ever known, but he had always appeared to be sickly, even while strutting about with his gold-tipped cane. And seeing that she could count his days on the fingers of her hands, Marie PERSON had avoided getting to know him. She could not understand why Wilamena ORG , who could have had any man in Claridge Towers ORG or any other senior citizen building for that matter, would take such a man into her bed. “True love,” Wilamena ORG had explained. “Avoid heartache,” Marie PERSON had said, trying to be kind.

They left the apartment. Marie PERSON sought help from no one, lest she come to depend on a person too much. But since the encounter with the young man, Wilamena PERSON had insisted on escorting Marie PERSON . Marie PERSON , to avoid arguments, allowed Wilamena ORG to walk with her from time to time to the bus stop, but no farther.

Nothing fit Marie PERSON ’s theory about life like the weather in Washington GPE . Two days DATE before the temperature had been in the forties, and yesterday DATE it had dropped to the low twenties then warmed up a bit, with the afternoon TIME bringing snow flurries. Today DATE the weather people on the radio had said it would warm enough to wear just a sweater, but Marie PERSON was wearing her coat. And tomorrow DATE , the weather people said, it would be in the thirties DATE , with maybe an inch or so of snow.

Appointments near twelve o’clock TIME were always risky, because the Social Security ORG people often took off for lunch long before noon TIME and returned sometime after one. And except for a few employees who seemed to work through their lunch hours TIME , the place shut down. Marie PERSON had never been interviewed by someone willing to work through the lunch hour TIME . Today DATE , though the appointment was for eleven CARDINAL , she waited until one thirty TIME before the woman at the front of the waiting room told her she would have to come back another day DATE , because the woman who handled her case was not in.

“You put my name down when I came in like everything was all right,” Marie PERSON said after she had been called up to the woman’s desk.

“I know,” the woman said, “but I thought that Mrs. Brown PERSON was in. They told me she was in. I’m sorry.” The woman began writing in a log book that rested between her telephone and a triptych of photographs. She handed Marie PERSON a slip and told her again she was sorry.

“Why you have me wait so long if she whatn’t here?” She did not want to say too much, appear too upset, for the Social Security ORG people could be unforgiving.
